div1.head: PREFACE
div1.p: THESE plays are really dramatic pageants, and the various acts are, with few exceptions, episodes, with different characters and representing different periods of time. Many of the episodes are in themselves complete plays, and can be presented for Thanksgiving, Christmas, Flag Day, Washington's Birthday, and so on. For example, Act I of A Dream of Gold and Act II of The Man who bore the Burden are suitable for Christmas. Any one of the acts of A Dream of Freedom or of Troubles on Land and Sea could be used for Thanksgiving. For Flag Day, Fourth of July, and other patriotic celebrations, there is abundant material in The Boston Tea Party, When Courage was needed, and A Brave Deed by Brave Men. Any one of the episodes in The Man who bore the Burden could be used as a play for February 22.

Whether these plays are read in class or acted in costume, their influence will be strong. The nobility and courage of our forefathers, who stood forth so bravely for justice, become, through the medium of dramatic action, vital and real. Nor is it too much to believe that this very nobility and courage will be absorbed unconsciously and help to form the character of the boys and girls who read
and speak their words. Moreover, these plays, by their appeal to the imagination, will awaken a new and lively interest in American history.

Infinite pains were taken in the preparation of the plays. The research required to gather the material, with the setting of each scene and its true historic atmosphere, has been great. The best historical sources were sought and all facts verified by the highest authorities. For the correctness of the historic data I am indebted to Dr. Allen Johnson, Professor of American history, Yale University. His criticisms were most valuable, and enabled me to place certain characters and scenes in their true proportions.

A DREAM OF FREEDOM; OR, THE PURITANS OF SCROOBY 53
TROUBLES ON LAND SEA; OR, THE PILGRIMS AND THEIR JOURNEYS 97
THE BOSTON TEA PARTY; OR, DESCENDANTS OF THE PILGRIMS 145

div2.head:
A DREAM OF GOLD
OR
THE SETTLEMENT AT JAMESTOWN

div3.head: ACT I

item.hi:
LORDS, LADIES, SAILORS, RELATIVES, GALLANTS,
ARTISANS, BEGGARS.

div3.stage: (Interior of covered dock is seen, with deck of a sailing vessel lying close. Sailors are loading ship with bags, barrels, cases, boxes, etc., now piled high on dock. Groups of passengers-- all men-- stand about. Other passengers-- all men-- enter from land. All carry baggage, and all are well dressed. They wear long cloaks and fine hats with plumes, and bear themselves as gentlemen. All are young, none being over thirty. Captains NEWPORT, GOSNOLD, and RATCLIFFE are talking together as they watch loading of ship.)

sp.speaker: MATE
sp.p: These cases of oil to the Sarah Constant! These barley bags to the Sarah!

sp.speaker: SAILORS.
sp.p: Aye! Aye!

sp.speaker: MATE
sp.p: These vinegar barrels to the Goodspeed! These boxes to the Discovery! Load these craft across the decks of the Sarah.

div3.stage: (Sailors go with freight. Other sailors return from ships.)

sp.speaker: MATE
sp.p: These boxes of spice to the Goodspeed! These barley bags to Discovery! Vinegar barrels to Discovery! Oil cases to Goodspeed!

sp.speaker: GOSNOLD.
sp.p: Our passengers are arriving betimes.

sp.speaker: RATCLIFFE
sp.p:
'T is strange Sir Richard Hakluyt is not here. 'T was he who planned this voyage to America. He helped, too, with the
large expenses of sending these men and of settling them in a colony.

sp.speaker: NEWPORT.
sp.p: He hath been summoned to King James to hear who will govern them in Virginia.

sp.speaker: GOSNOLD.
sp.p: It hath pleased his Majesty to hold it back till the very last. There will be grumblings all the way over.

sp.speaker: NEWPORT.
sp.p: Nay, these gentlemen are going with the hope of finding gold. They care not who is leader.

div3.stage: (Enter other passengers of same class as those on deck. Many are accompanied by relatives.)

sp.speaker: A MOTHER
sp.p: Oh, I cannot bear to have you go, my son! 'T is a wild and fearsome country.

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: There is naught to fear, dear mother. Just think of the fortune I'll make in gold! I could ne'er make so much in England. And next year this time I'll be coming back, with presents for you of jewels and gold-- as much as I can carry.

sp.speaker: MOTHER.
sp.p: I truly believe you will, lad.

div3.stage: (They pass on. A brother and sister approach-- MOLLIE and CHARLES.)

sp.speaker: MOLLIE.
sp.p: And do you really think you'll be back in England, brother, just a year from now?

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Why, 't is certain, sister! And you will be wearing strings of pearls, and rings of gold on your fingers.

sp.speaker: MOLLIE.
sp.p: Oh! how wonderful! Will you really find jewels and gold there, Charles?

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Is it not said so by every one? I tell you, Mollie, I shall come home rich.

div3.stage: (They pass on. Master and Mistress TODKILL approach. They are young and have been but recently married.)

sp.speaker: MISTRESS TODKILL.
sp.p: Now, John, you must not work too hard. Digging gold is fatiguing.

sp.speaker: TODKILL.
sp.p: Methinks I shan't have to dig much, dear. I have beads enough to trade with the Indians for their golden kettles or saucepans.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS TODKILL.
sp.p: You might get both-- you can fit them into each other. I daresay they will have golden bowls, too, which you can fit into the kettles.

sp.speaker: TODKILL.
sp.p: I will place them together nicely. And you shall have them all next year, dear wife.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS TODKILL.
sp.p: Oh, that will be splendid, John! Splendid!

div3.stage: (They pass on. PHETTIPLACE and son approach. PHETTIPLACE is a fat country squire; is gayly dressed in a red hunting suit. His son, a youth of twenty, wears a rich velvet suit, velvet cloak, and plumed hat.)

sp.speaker: PHETTIPLACE.
sp.p: Now, son, don't forget to send me gold by the very first ship that returns.

sp.speaker: SON.
sp.p: I'll not forget, father. So just go on with your hunting. Keep your mansion filled with guests, and give not one thought to your debts.

sp.speaker: PHETTIPLACE.
sp.p: Oh, I shan't let debts trouble me now. Methinks I shall borrow some on the gold you will find in Virginia.

sp.speaker: SON.
sp.p: Borrow as much as you choose. I shall come back home worth millions.

sp.speaker: PHETTIPLACE.
sp.p: I'm glad America was discovered. It comes in very handy when one is down in fortune.

div3.stage: (They pass on, laughing. Enter Sir GILBERT MANLOVE. He is seventy-five years old; is elegantly dressed; is a dandy of the period.)

sp.speaker: FIRST GENTLEMAN
sp.p: Look you- there is Sir Gilbert Manlove of the king's court. Think you he is going?

div3.stage: (Others looking. Sir GILBERT sees them; joins them hastily.)

sp.speaker: SIR GILBERT.
sp.p: Gentlemen-- a boon I crave! A favor I would ask you!

sp.speaker: FIRST GENTLEMAN.
sp.p: You have only to speak, Sir Gilbert.

sp.speaker: SIR GILBERT.
sp.p: 'T is said you will sail to a land where the rivers flow o'er golden sands.

sp.speaker: SECOND GENTLEMAN.
sp.p: That is true, my lord.

sp.speaker: SIR GILBERT.
sp.p: 'T is said these rivers feed a fountain of marvelous cures-- a fountain that will give eternal youth to all who bathe in its waters.

sp.speaker: THIRD GENTLEMAN.
sp.p: We expect to see this fountain, my lord, but know not its location.

sp.speaker: SIR GILBERT.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, find this fountain of
youth for me and you shall have half of my fortune. I'll come in a ship of my own, I will! I'll come as soon as you write me.

sp.speaker: FIRST GENTLEMAN.
sp.p: We'll make it our first business, my lord.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Aye, we will!

div3.stage: (They pass on, talking earnestly. Enter from land HENRY SPELMAN, a bright and well-dressed boy of twelve years. He has fine and courteous manners. He carries no baggage; looks about as if half frightened; joins a group, doffing his cap politely.)

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: I give you good day, Masters. Be that the ship for Virginia?

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: All three are bound for Virginia.

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: Will they be sailing soon?

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: Presently-- within the hour.

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Hour!

sp.speaker: YOUNG PHETTIPLACE.
sp.p: Is that not soon enough for you?

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: I want to sail at once.

sp.speaker: SQUIRE PHETTIPLACE.
sp.p: Bless me! Be you going, lad?

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: Aye, Master.

sp.speaker: PHILLIPS.
sp.p: Perchance your parents will sail with us?

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: Nay--

sp.speaker: SIMPSON.
sp.p: Perchance you have relatives going?

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: Nay--

sp.speaker: WALTERS.
sp.p: Some older friends or neighbors, then?

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: Nay, I be alone.
Hath Captain John Smith not come? 'T was said he would sail to America.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: Oh, ho! So that is what hath brought you!
He hath heard of Captain Smith's adventures in foreign lands and looks upon him as a hero.

sp.speaker: WALTERS.
sp.p: What know you of John Smith, lad?

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: He is indeed a hero. When he was a boy no older than I, he would not play with other boys, but built him a hut in the forest. And there he studied many books, and did practice much with his horse and lance.

sp.speaker: SQUIRE PHETTIPLACE.
sp.p: But how does that make him a hero?

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: Why, he went away to foreign lands, and fought in their wars, and received great honors from queens and kings for bravery in battle.

sp.speaker: SIMPSON.
sp.p: Pooh! So have hundreds of others.

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: But Captain Smith fought for the weaker ones-- for those who needed help. My father himself hath told me.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: They be only trying to tease you, lad. Captain Smith is indeed a brave man. But you must not follow him to America. Hath your father consented to it?

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Nay-- not exactly.

sp.speaker: PERCY
sp.p: Have you run away from home, my boy?

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: I have fallen into displeasure at home.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: So you will run away to America?
That won't do, my lad. Come, we'll tell Captain Newport about it.
Where is the Captain? Do any of you gentlemen see him?
sp.stage: (As the gentlemen look about, HENRY slips away and hides among cases and barrels.)
sp.p: Ah, there he is!
Why, the lad is gone!

sp.speaker: SQUIRE PHETTIPLACE.
sp.p: He has hidden himself away somewhere.

sp.speaker: SIMPSON.
sp.p: He's very likely slipped to the ships.

sp.speaker: PHILLIPS.
sp.p: Oh, well, let him go. He'll have an easy life in Virginia.

sp.speaker: WALTERS.
sp.p: And he can come back with gold enough to start him up in business.

div3.stage: (Many passengers now turn toward land waving hats and handkerchiefs.)

sp.speaker: PERCY
sp.p: 'T is Captain Smith who is coming!

div3.stage:
(Enter Captain JOHN SMITH, a handsome young man of twenty-seven. He bears himself as a
thorough soldier; has a noble,frank countenance; shows unusual intelligence, shrewdness, and courage; is modest, courteous, friendly. He now removes his plumed hat and bows to all. NEWPORT crosses to him.)

sp.speaker: NEWPORT.
sp.p: Ah, Captain Smith-- I feared you would fail us.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: I never fail when once my promise is given.

sp.speaker: NEWPORT.
sp.p: You be a man of your word, I know; and yet this venture is enough to frighten the stoutest heart. I will return, but you must remain-- at least till another ship makes the voyage.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: So must these others, Captain.

sp.speaker: NEWPORT.
sp.p: What know they of danger? They have never been away from home-- they do not know what a wilderness means. But you have traveled far and wide-- you know to what you are going. You know, also, that not a single person hath ever returned from that other colony that went to America so long ago. Nor hath any trace of them been found. They have disappeared entirely.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: I do know, and I mean to hunt for them. That is my chief reason for going. I feel that it is a disgrace to England that one hundred English men, women, and children could disappear so utterly. The others may dig for gold if they choose; I know a soldier's duty. No painted warrior can frighten me, nor tomahawk, nor arrow that hath been poisoned.

sp.speaker: NEWPORT.
sp.p: How can you search among those hordes of savages? We are not taking an army.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: I shall rely upon honesty in our dealings with them. Have you not beads and trinkets for trading?

sp.speaker: NEWPORT.
sp.p: Aye, a goodly cargo.
sp.stage: (Other passengers enter-- many gallants,in their fine cloaks and hats, and a few workmen and artisans, who wear woolen blouses and caps. SMITH looks at them, then looks at other groups keenly. He turns to NEWPORT.)
sp.p: Why, nearly all do seem to be gallants!

sp.speaker: NEWPORT.
sp.p: Aye, indeed.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Are there no other workmen going than these?

sp.speaker: NEWPORT.
sp.p: Only these few were listed.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: How many masons are there? And blacksmiths, carpenters, farmers?

sp.speaker: NEWPORT.
sp.p: Some two masons, one blacksmith, four carpenters, and no farmers at all.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: No farmers!
sp.stage: (His indignant voice attracts attention. The others approach and surround him and NEWPORT.)
sp.p: Why, we should have fifty! These gallants know not how to saw, or hew, or till the soil. Are there no skilled artisans among us?

sp.speaker: NEWPORT.
sp.p: One-- a goldsmith.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Ha, ha! A goldsmith to fashion us elegant ornaments from the gold we have n't found!

sp.speaker: FIRST GALLANT.
sp.p: The gold is there in plenty. And pearls are there, by bushels. 'T would be wisdom to take six goldsmiths, say I.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: 'T would be wisdom to take six blacksmiths. But more than anything else we need farmers to teach us how to plant our grain.

sp.speaker: SECOND GALLANT.
sp.p: 'Tis not necessary. The Indians will furnish us with food.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: The Indians may not be friendly.

sp.speaker: THIRD GALLANT.
sp.p: They are said to be gentle and loving.

sp.speaker: FOURTH GALLANT.
sp.p: And if they are not, we have our arms-- we can compel obedience.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Aye!

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: We'll have no time for fighting, men. We must build cabins, and a store room and a fort.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Methought we should live in the open. 'T is said the air is soft and mild-- in winter the same as summer.

sp.speaker: WILLIAM.
sp.p: And we can sleep upon beds of moss with which the ground is covered.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Aye!

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: 'T is all very pretty, and I wish it were true; but there's no land where one can live so, not even in the tropics. I know we will need cabins. And for these we must cut down trees and hew them into lumber.

sp.speaker: TODKILL.
sp.p: Hew them ourselves?

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Who else do you think will do it?

sp.speaker: PHETTIPLACE.
sp.p: Why, we'll make the Indians work for us.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Aye! We will! Of course!

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: We must not make slaves of Indians. And unless we treat them fairly, we shall be ourselves undone and perish as did those others.

sp.speaker: TODKILL.
sp.p: How know you so much about Virginia, sir? You have never been there.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: I have had experience in many lands.

sp.speaker: TODKILL.
sp.p: Ah, but Virginia is different. Have not fishermen told us what they saw on fishing trips there? They beheld luscious fruit hanging from the trees all ready to be eaten.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PHETTIPLACE.
sp.p: And the beautiful forests were filled with game. The shores were covered with oysters. Why, 'tis a land of plenty, men-- a paradise-- a garden of milk and honey!

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: I am sorry for you, gentlemen. Your eyes will have been opened by this time next year.

sp.speaker: MOLLIE.
sp.p: I fear I'll get no pearls after all-

sp.speaker: MISTRESS TODKILL.
sp.p: Nor I my golden kettles--

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Indeed and you will!

sp.speaker: TODKILL.
sp.p: Of course you will!

sp.speaker: WILLIAM.
sp.p: You need not be troubled, mother. We know as much about Virginia as Captain Smith.

sp.speaker: FIRST GALLANT
sp.p: Look! Sir Richard Hakluyt comes!

sp.speaker: SECOND GALLANT.
sp.p: And our chaplain--

sp.speaker: THIRD GALLANT.
sp.p: And lords and ladies from the king's court--

div3.stage: (Enter Sir RICHARD HAKLUYT and Chaplain HUNT, who wears his clerical robes. Sir RICHARD carries a small metal box conspicuously. Enter many lords and ladies in rich attire. Enter many of the poor of London in rags. NEWPORT crosses to Sir RICHARD and bows.)

sp.speaker: NEWPORT.
sp.p: We have been expecting you, Sir Richard.

sp.speaker: SIR RICHARD.
sp.p: I was detained at the palace, Captain, by his Majesty, King James.
Gentlemen, Voyagers to Virginia, his Majesty hath commanded me to bear you his farewells and to wish you God-speed on your voyage.

sp.speaker: VOYAGERS.
sp.p: King James! Long live King James!

sp.speaker: SIR RICHARD.
sp.p: And, my friends, his Majesty bids you to set claim to all lands you behold, in the name of England's sovereign, King James. His Majesty urges you further to dig diligently for gold and to search for pearls and jewels.

sp.speaker: VOYAGERS.
sp.p: We will! We will!

sp.speaker: SIR RICHARD.
sp.p: These lords and ladies have all contributed to the setting up of your colony. They also bid you search for gold that you may reward their confidence.

sp.speaker: VOYAGERS.
sp.p: Aye! Aye!

sp.speaker: SIR RICHARD.
sp.p: Chaplain Hunt will accompany you and will care for your souls in the wilderness.

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN
sp.p: My heart burns to keep you with God and to convert the savages also. I will labor diligently to that end-- no trouble will I spare me.

sp.speaker: SIR RICHARD.
sp.p: And, gentlemen, King James hath chosen a leader for you-- a president-- to govern you in America.

His name, however, I cannot reveal. The king hath placed the name in this box, which must not be opened till your journey is ended. I give it now to the Senior Captain in command. 'Tis his Majesty's explicit order.

sp.speaker: NEWPORT.
sp.p: I shall see to it, Sir Richard.

sp.speaker: SIR RICHARD.
sp.p: Be you ready to sail?

sp.speaker: NEWPORT.
sp.p: Aye, we be.

sp.speaker: SIR RICHARD.
sp.p:
Then just one word more. Let nothing dishearten you, gentlemen-- neither storms, nor cold, nor sickness. Remember you go to a land where there is eternal sunshine; where stately trees spread their branches out over carpets of velvet mosses; where rivers flow over golden sands; where jewels lie in profusion; where a wonderful fountain will keep you young, if you but bathe in its waters. And the people who dwell in this fairy land are said
to be gentle and loving. You journey, then, to a Heaven on earth, to a beautiful Garden of Eden.

sp.speaker: VOYAGERS.
sp.p: Aye! Aye!

sp.speaker: SIR RICHARD.
sp.p: Chaplain, will you bless them?

div3.stage: (Chaplain lifts his hand: all bow heads. Enter a woman from land, running. She is well dressed and refined; is excited.)

sp.speaker: WOMAN.
sp.p: Captain! Captain Newport!

sp.speaker: NEWPORT.
sp.p: Why, what is it, Madam?

sp.speaker: WOMAN.
sp.p: My nephew hath run away from home! 'T is said he came here! Find him-- I pray you to find him ! He's only a lad and hath blue eyes and fair hair.

sp.speaker: NEWPORT.
sp.p: Hath any one seen such a boy?

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: Aye, I did and spake with him. He said he would make this voyage.

sp.speaker: WOMAN.
sp.p: Oh, but he must not! His parents are distracted. Indeed, they both are ill now with the shock.

sp.speaker: NEWPORT.
sp.p: What is the boy's name?

sp.speaker: WOMAN.
sp.p: Henry Spelman. His father is Sir Henry Spelman.

sp.speaker: SIR RICHARD.
sp.p: Sir Henry! Why, I know him well. He is an eminent scholar.

sp.speaker: NEWPORT
sp.p: Henry Spelman! Henry Spelman!
Come hither, Henry Spelman!
Search the ships! Make haste-- we should be sailing!

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: I'll help them search for the lad.

sp.speaker: WOMAN.
sp.p: The boy was vexed because his father would not permit him to ride full tilt amongst the young trees in the orchard.

sp.speaker: SQUIRE PHETTIPLACE.
sp.p: Ha, ha! He was trying to imitate Captain Smith!

sp.speaker: WOMAN.
sp.p: Aye, he was. And he said he would run away to strange lands, but we didn't think he would do it.

sp.speaker: A SAILOR.
sp.p: We could n't find him, Madam.

sp.speaker: NEWPORT.
sp.p: He very likely came down for a look at the ships. He's no doubt back home by this time.

sp.speaker: WOMAN.
sp.p: But if he is not? What then, Captain? What then?

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: If he sails with us, I shall care for him as if he were my own son, madam.

sp.speaker: WOMAN.
sp.p: Oh, bless you for that! God bless you!

sp.speaker: NEWPORT
sp.p: Give the call for sailing!

sp.speaker: MATE
sp.p: Now sails the Sarah Constant! The Goodspeed! The Discovery! Now sail they to America!

div3.stage:
(There is great confusion. There are embraces, good-byes, kisses, and tears. Voyagers going to
ships with baggage. Friends on dock waving to them. HENRY slips to ship unseen.)

sp.speaker: SIR RICHARD.
sp.p: A happy voyage to you all!

sp.speaker: OTHERS ON DOCKS.
sp.p: Farewell! Farewell!

sp.speaker: VOYAGERS.
sp.p: Farewell! Farewell!

div3.head: ACT II

p.hi: TIME: Winter of 1609-- New Year's week.

div3.p: (The council room in Chief POWHATAN'S house is seen. At one end, on a raised platform covered with reed mats, sits POWHATAN. He is a slender but powerful man of sixty years; has a keen and shrewd face; is now sad and thoughtful; stares gloomily into afire which burns on ground before platform. He does not notice entrance of TOCOMOCOMO, a young brave, who waits quietly. At last the Chief sees him.)

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: Welcome, Tocomocomo! What news bring you of the white men ? Speak!

sp.speaker: TOCOMOCOMO.
sp.p: I went to their village, Powhatan. I slept in their fort, but ever mine eyes were open, as Powhatan did command.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: What saw you?

sp.speaker: TOCOMOCOMO.
sp.p: Little food have they now, Powhatan. Only sour barley for all.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: How long. will that last?

sp.speaker: TOCOMOCOMO.
sp.p: Three days-- no more.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN
sp.p: And the game hath left the forest! And the fish lie hidden in ice-covered streams! 'T is for this time I have waited! Now, they must depend on us, or starve!

sp.speaker: TOCOMOCOMO.
sp.p: Powhatan hath spoken.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: Watch they still by day and by night?

sp.speaker: TOCOMOCOMO.
sp.p: Their chief hath an eye ever open.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: Which way looks their cannon?

sp.speaker: TOCOMOCOMO.
sp.p: To the forest, Powhatan.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: Call the braves to council.

div3.stage: (Exit TOCOMOCOMO. Enter POCAHONTAS, a pretty and very small girl of twelve. She carries a basket filled with corn. POWHATAN stares into fire.)

sp.speaker: POCAHONTAS.
sp.p: Father Powhatan, 't is Pocahontas who waits.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN
sp.p: What will you, Pocahontas?

sp.speaker: POCAHONTAS.
sp.p: I go to the white men with corn.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN
sp.p:
Go no more to Jamestown.
Give them no more of your presents-- no corn-- no fruit-- no venison. Nothing give them-- nothing!

sp.speaker: POCAHONTAS.
sp.p: Methought them friends--

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: No! Enemies, Pocahontas.

sp.speaker: POCAHONTAS.
sp.p: Captain Smith is friend--

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: No! Enemy like his men. Speak no more words with him. Powhatan has spoken.

sp.speaker: POCAHONTAS.
sp.p: I obey, Father Powhatan

div3.stage: (She goes out, frightened. A drum heard off. Enter braves. They form in circle about room. Drum ceases. Silence. Pause.)

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p:
My children, long have we been happy here in the land of our fathers. Many generations of our people have tilled this soil-- have hunted in these forests. The neighboring tribes are at peace with us and pay us their yearly tribute. And so it hath been during my lifetime-- happiness prosperity. And now behold what hath happened! Strange men have come unbid to our fair home. They have seized our land which hath come to us from our fathers. They cut our trees, they hunt where they choose, they ask not Powhatan for permission. They come to our village-- they speak as friends, but they cannot deceive us longer. They said they had landed here to mend their ships and would go when that was finished. But the ships have gone and they have remained. And then, after many moons, came other ships with
other strange men. And with them came a woman and girl. And their ships have gone and they also remain. Soon others will come, and then others. Do you see now what will happen? We will be driven back to bare mountains while they take our richest valley. Shall we endure this, braves? Shall we sit by and permit it? Speak.

sp.speaker: FIRST OLD BRAVE.
sp.p: Long have I wished to war upon them.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: Have you forgot their arms that throw out fire? Have you forgot their cannon?

sp.speaker: SECOND OLD BRAVE.
sp.p: Hath Powhatan forgot those other strange men who came to our shores? Were we not victorious?

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: We cannot take these by surprise. Their chief is ever watching. We must drive these away by cunning.

And, my children, our time hath come. They must come to us soon for corn. Well, we will give them corn, but no more trading for beads or bells or any kind of trinkets. For each basket of corn, a musket or sword. Do you hear? A weapon for every basket! If they refuse, we will starve them.

sp.speaker: THIRD OLD BRAVE.
sp.p: It is a shrewd plan, Powhatan.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: Should an Indian disobey, death will be the penalty.
Go to all our dependent tribes-- tell them what I have spoken. Say Powhatan will war upon them, should they give food to the strangers.

sp.speaker: TOCOMOCOMO.
sp.p: I go, great Powhatan.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN
sp.p: Now where is that warrior who played on his pipe when these same white men were landing? Step forth, Wochinchopunck?
sp.stage: (A stalwart but frightened young brave steps from circle. POWHATAN looks at him with scorn.)
sp.p: And so-- you made sweet music, did you, to welcome our worst enemy?

sp.speaker: WOCHINCHOPUNOK.
sp.p: I did but go down to the shore, Powhatan, playing upon my reed pipe. 'T is said I play it very well--

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: Shall I flay you alive or burn you?

sp.speaker: WOCHINCHOPUNCK.
sp.p: I knew not they were enemies then--

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: All white men are enemies!

sp.speaker: WOCHINCHOPUNOK.
sp.p: Powhatan had not told me that.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: Well, I tell you now to hate them.

sp.speaker: WOCHINCHOPUNCK.
sp.p: My heart is bursting to revenge our wrongs and drive them from our country. Let me live, Powhatan, and you shall see their scalps on my belt! Let me live, great chief! I will fight to my death! No mercy will I show any white man.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN
sp.p: You may live, but no more music, mind you.

sp.speaker: WOMAN.
sp.p: Powhatan! The white men have come! They are here, at your door! They say they come for trading.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: Comes their chief with them?

sp.speaker: WOMAN.
sp.p: He is here, Powhatan.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: Bring them before me here.
Give them no welcome, braves! Let there be no smiles, no words, no presents! Who disobeys me shall die ! Powhatan hath spoken.

div3.stage: (Enter Captain SMITH and twelve men. All are heavily armed, wearing swords and carrying muskets.)

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Greetings to you, King Powhatan! Greetings to your warriors!
sp.stage: (Pause. POWHATAN and braves look at white men coldly. White men show surprise.)
sp.p: Why, what is this! You do not welcome us, Powhatan!

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: Why have you come to Powhatan?

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: What hath come between us? Are we not friends and brothers?

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: Why come you armed to my village?

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: 'Tis our custom to go always armed. Came we not armed on our other visits to you?

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: Friends go not so to each other.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Your braves come armed to Jamestown. They enter our fort; they eat with us, yet never without their weapons.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: 'T is because they fear your firearms. Why brought you arms to this land at all, if you came here as our brothers?

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: We must kill the deer, just as you must; and we cannot use the arrow.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: You need not cannon for hunting.

sp.speaker: SMITH
sp.p: Our cannon was to protect us on the sea from pirate and from Spaniard.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: So you have told me often, but I have seen no pirates here, nor hath any Spaniard sailed this way. You said also you would not remain long-- just till your ships were mended. Your ships have gone-- twelve moons have paled, but you remain in my country. And other ships have come and gone, and there are more of you now than ever.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Such is our great love for this land, we cannot bear to leave it. And our friends who have come do love it too, and likewise cannot bear to go.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN
sp.p: How long do you mean to stay here?

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Why should we not remain and continue to live as brothers? For your corn we will give beads--

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: No longer will we sell corn for beads! You shall give a musket or sword for each basket.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p:
We cannot do that, Powhatan. We have
only enough for our own use. Come to our fort, and you can see I do speak the truth.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: No-- never will Powhatan bite at such a bait!

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: You cannot think we would harm you! Did you not spare my life when I was captured by your braves?

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: 'T was not I. 'T was my daughter Pocahontas.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: You yielded to her pleadings, even when the club was lifted.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: 'T is our custom to save a prisoner from death when claimed by one of our women.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: But it hath made friendship between us. And in peace have we lived for more than twelve moons, and visits have I made you.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: Give me a weapon for each basket of corn. It is that, or no trading with strangers.

sp.speaker: SMITH
sp.p: Then there will be no trading. But we shall not starve as you think and hope. With our muskets we can get all we need. They can kill while the arrow is flying. Our cannon, too, is ready. Do not forget that, Powhatan. And, Powhatan, what hath become of our young boy, Henry Spelman?

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: How should I know aught of him?

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Because your men did seize him, as he was fishing one day in the river.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: Powhatan knows nothing.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: He is here in your village-- one of my men hath seen him.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: Give boy for musket-- and powder.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: We cannot trade our arms. I tell you that for the last time.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN
sp.p: Musket for boy-- and powder--

sp.speaker: SMITH
sp.p: Cover them, men!

stage.hi: (Men aim muskets at POWHATAN and braves.)

sp.p: Will you give us the boy and corn?

sp.speaker: POWHATAN
sp.p: Bring corn-- basket for each man.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: Powhatan bring boy--

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Wait! What became of those white men who came here many years ago with their wives and children?

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: Many times you ask that. Powhatan knows nothing. They died of fever, perhaps.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Or were massacred by Indians--

sp.speaker: POWHATAN.
sp.p: Powhatan knows nothing--

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: My king will avenge their murder in time. Many ships will he send, with many soldiers and cannon.

sp.speaker: POWHATAN
sp.p: Powhatan king of this land! Powhatan king-- no other!

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Comrades, prepare to defend your lives! I fear they will surround us.

sp.speaker: TODKILL.
sp.p: We could make a dash for our boats--

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: We dare not go without the corn-- 't would mean starvation to us. And I will not stir till I have the boy or know he can escape them.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Think you they mean to kill us here?

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Fear of our muskets may save us. But they hate us bitterly and no longer try to conceal it.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: Can you blame, them, Captain? We're taking the best they have in land and food, and giving them naught but trinkets.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: We are obeying our sovereign's orders. Be on the alert every instant, men! They may rush in upon us. Guard the door, Simpson.

div3.stage: (Pause; the men look after their arms. SIMPSON watches at door.)

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: A beautiful New Year's this is, forsooth! I thought to be on a visit back home, with pearls and gold for my sister.

sp.speaker: WILLIAM.
sp.p: I, too, thought to be back, with jewels for my mother.

sp.speaker: TODKILL.
sp.p: And I expected to be giving golden saucepans to my wife, and golden bowls and kettles.

sp.speaker: PHETTIPLACE.
sp.p: And look you at the contrast! We're all half starved and have naught to eat but sour barley. And not one nugget of gold have we found, nor any pearls or jewels.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p:
Too much time was spent in searching for
"COVER THEM, MEN"
them. We should have been planting corn and get- ting stores for the winter.

sp.speaker: TODKILL.
sp.p: We can see that clearly now, Captain. But we would not follow your advice; we have only ourselves to blame.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Well, I will blame those in London somewhat, We were told it was summer here throughout the year.

sp.speaker: PHILLIPS.
sp.p: And where is the river that runs over golden sands?

sp.speaker: WALTERS.
sp.p: And where is the wonderful fountain of youth?

sp.speaker: PHETTIPLACE.
sp.p: All lies,-- spun just to entice us hither.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Nay, not that. Such things are ever thought of all lands far away. A halo of romance surrounds them. No one deceived us purposely.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: But it is unfortunate for us that they continue to believe such things in London. Look at that shipload lately arrived! They had consumed their stores on their voyage and brought not one thing to our larder.

sp.speaker: WILLIAM.
sp.p: And worst of all they will not work, and they grumble about our barley, even though we divide it with them.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p:
It is a serious situation. If the Indians do not help us we cannot survive this winter, my friends. Indeed, we may not survive this day, even. But if any of you live to see England again, I pray
you to say that I have sought far and wide for the lost Englishmen and have found no trace of them anywhere. I now believe that Powhatan did have them killed.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: 'T is my thought also, Captain.

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: Pocahontas approaches!

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Let her enter-- I am certain she is friendly to us. She hath come so often to Jamestown and hath always brought us presents.
Ah, Princess--

sp.speaker: POCAHONTAS.
sp.p: Sh! Speak not my name! I warn you-- Powhatan will kill you all as you load the corn on your canoes-- when your backs are bent in the labor.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: We thank you, little Princess. For the second time you have saved my life, and now the lives of my comrades. Accept this chain of beads, I pray.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: Here is a ring I would give you.

sp.speaker: POCAHONTAS.
sp.p: Nay, Powhatan would know-- it would be my death.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Well, then, we will not press you. But tell us of Henry Spelman, maid. Does he live? Is he well?

sp.speaker: POCAHONTAS
sp.p: He is here- he is well. He takes care of Powhatan's youngest children.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p:
Will you not help him to escape? His
life is in danger with ours. Let him get away tonight.

sp.speaker: POCAHONTAS.
sp.p: This night I will help him. And you, Captain-- I pray you to be watchful; turn not your back at the loading.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Be ready, men, but fire not till I command. We must avoid bloodshed if possible.

div3.stage: (Enter several young braves with baskets of corn, which they place on floor.)

sp.speaker: FIRST BRAVE.
sp.p: Powhatan no come again-- send boy Henry Spelman to Jamestown.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Then here are beads, and bells, and jingles.
Stay! you will carry the corn to our canoes and load it on them for us.

sp.speaker: FIRST BRAVE.
sp.p: Powhatan did not command--

div3.stage: (They start off. SMITH and men, by a quick Movement, reach door first and face Indians with leveled muskets.)

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Take the corn to our canoes. Refuse, and our muskets will speak.

div3.stage: (Indians take up corn and go. SMITH and men follow them with leveled muskets.)

div3.head: ACT III
div3.stage: (The one narrow street is seen with tiny cabins on either side, and fort at one end. Palisades made of logs and saplings surround the town. Through open gate of palisade is seen the woods. In the street are many young gallants playing quoits. Many others are watching or lounging about. Enter Master FORREST from a cabin. He, too, is a young gallant, but carries an axe. He looks at others with displeasure.)

sp.speaker: FORREST.
sp.p: Men, men, this idling will not do! The sun is high; even now the axe rings in the woods.

sp.speaker: FIRST GALLANT.
sp.p: 'T is no axe of ours that rings, Master Forrest.

sp.speaker: FORREST.
sp.p:
Nay, 't is the older settlers who have
gone to work, and we should be working with them. We are living on their bounty; on the food they had stored away for their own use this winter.

sp.speaker: SECOND GALLANT.
sp.p: We came to find gold, not to hew and chop in the forest.

sp.speaker: THIRD GALLANT.
sp.p: And behold, Captain Smith forbids us to dig!

sp.speaker: FORREST.
sp.p: Those who came with him did nothing else for many months. And they found 't was all in vain.

sp.speaker: FIFTH GALLANT.
sp.p: That proves nothing! We might dig in a different place and at once unearth a fortune.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Of course; certainly--

sp.speaker: FORREST.
sp.p: Be that as it may, your duty now is plain. Captain Smith asked us to help the men who are now clearing the ground of timber. He will hold us to account when he returns from Powhatan.

sp.speaker: FOURTH GALLANT.
sp.p: Out upon Captain Smith! I can't abide his orders.

sp.speaker: FIFTH GALLANT.
sp.p: We should refuse to obey him, say I.

sp.speaker: SIXTH GALLANT.
sp.p: We could depose him easily. We outnumber his supporters. So 't would be merely a matter of seizing him and putting him in irons.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Yes-- yes!

stage.hi: (Enter Chaplain HUNT in his clerical robes.)

sp.speaker: FORREST
sp.p:
You are doing a most
contemptible thing! You are traitors-- every one of you!

sp.speaker: FIRST GALLANT.
sp.p: Use not such words to us, sir!

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I pray you, let your quarrel be done!

sp.speaker: FORREST.
sp.p: They plan to depose Captain Smith!

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: Why, that is madness! He hath not harmed you in any way. Indeed he protects your very lives. He stands between us all and the Indians, over whom he has great power. Have they not given him corn when none of us could get it from any Indian of any tribe? He hath kept us from starvation, time and again.

sp.speaker: FIRST GALLANT.
sp.p: I fancy we could control Indians quite as well as he does. We heard all about them in England.

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: But the Captain hath had many dealings with them and understands their language.

sp.speaker: FOURTH GALLANT.
sp.p: We could use signs and gestures.

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: We cannot risk experiments. We have Mistress Forrest with us now and the little maiden, Ann Burras.

sp.speaker: THIRD GALLANT.
sp.p: We can protect them, Chaplain.
I say we seize Smith upon his return!

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Yes-- yes! Seize him! Seize him!

sp.speaker: FORREST.
sp.p: I'll tell the men in the woods your plan!

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: Men, I pray you to be discreet and to take no sudden action. We are surrounded by dangers. The Indians have lately become unfriendly to us, and I believe would attack us, did they not stand in awe of Captain Smith.

sp.speaker: SECOND GALLANT.
sp.p: And why are they unfriendly? They were peaceful enough at first, I hear. Indeed, they fairly bowed down to you as if you were gods come among them. They gave you food in abundance and entertained you in their wigwams.

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: That is true, but lately they have changed.

sp.speaker: SIXTH GALLANT.
sp.p: 'T is my opinion the trouble lies in the Captain's method of trading. He gives them beads and such trumpery stuff.

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: They set great value on our beads at first.

sp.speaker: SIXTH GALLANT.
sp.p: Well, they are refusing them now. I would give them what they want and keep them in a good humor.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Of course! Yes-- yes!

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: Do you know what the Indian really wants? Our swords and muskets and powder.

sp.speaker: FIRST GALLANT.
sp.p: And why does Smith refuse them? Suppose they do get a few of our arms. They would n't know how to use them.

sp.speaker: FIFTH GALLANT.
sp.p: 'T would be a laughable thing, methinks, to see a naked savage with a sword at his side.

sp.speaker: FIRST GALLANT.
sp.p: Or carrying a musket forth to the hunt.

div3.stage: (Other gallants laugh heartily. Enter ANN BURRAS from the FORREST cabin. She is a sweet-looking girl of fourteen. She carries an empty water pail; crosses to woods; stops.)

sp.speaker: ANN
sp.p: Look-- look! Indians!

div3.stage: (Gallants seize muskets. ANN retreats to cabin, where she stands at door. Enter six Indian braves carrying twelve turkeys and a deer. They lay down their bows and arrows.)

sp.speaker: FIRST BRAVE
sp.p: Trade-- white men-- trade--

sp.speaker: FOURTH GALLANT.
sp.p: 'T is the first game we've seen since we came. We must get it, comrades.

sp.speaker: OTHER GALLANTS.
sp.p: Yes-- yes--

sp.speaker: FIRST BRAVE.
sp.p: Turkey for musket--

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: No! no! We will not trade our muskets.

sp.speaker: FIRST BRAVE.
sp.p: Turkey for musket or no trade.

sp.speaker: SECOND BRAVE.
sp.p: Game scarce-- long, long hunt for these.

sp.speaker: SECOND GALLANT.
sp.p: 'T is fair enough, I say.

sp.speaker: OTHER GALLANTS.
sp.p: Yes-- yes--

sp.speaker: SECOND GALLANT.
sp.p: I'll get the arms from the storehouse--

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: No-- no ! You must not--

sp.speaker: FIFTH GALLANT.
sp.p: Would you have us live on sour barley?

sp.speaker: THIRD GALLANT.
sp.p: We do not mean to starve, sir.

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: You must not put weapons into their hands! They will use them against us later.

sp.speaker: FIRST GALLANT.
sp.p: Pooh! We're not afraid of Indians.
Come, I'll help you get the arms.

stage.hi: (They go up street. Exit ANN to cabin.)

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN
sp.p: Gentlemen, I pray you! Do not permit this thing! Can't you see the danger?

sp.speaker: THIRD GALLANT.
sp.p: We don't agree with you, Chaplain.

div3.stage: (Gallants turn away from Chaplain. Enter Mistress FORREST and ANN from cabin. Mistress FORREST is about thirty; is a refined and courageous woman. She crosses to Chaplain and speaks with him aside. ANN follows her.)

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORREST.
sp.p: Ann told me what they would do. Can't you stop them, Chaplain?

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: I fear only force could stop them now, Mistress Forrest.

div3.stage: (Enter gallants with weapons. Mistress FORREST runs to them.)

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORREST.
sp.p: Do not give them our arms! I entreat you, men,-- I implore you!

sp.speaker: FIRST GALLANT.
sp.p: You may trust to us, Mistress. We know how to deal with Indians.

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: I command you to put those weapons down.

sp.speaker: SECOND GALLANT.
sp.p: Nay, Chaplain. We're taking things into our own hands.

div3.stage: (They give arms to Indians who give turkeys, but keep deer; show they will trade that for powder.)

sp.speaker: THIRD GALLANT.
sp.p: I understand-- they want powder for the deer. I'll fetch it.

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: Again I forbid you to give powder or arms!

sp.speaker: THIRD GALLANT.
sp.p: And we will not obey you.

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN
sp.p: We must call in the men from the wood. You know the signal. Get your musket. They will not suspect you.

div3.stage: (Mistress FORREST nods and goes into her cabin. Enter Third Gallant with powder; gives it to Indian for deer. Indians go. Enter Mistress FORREST with musket; slips to edge of woods and fires in air. Gallants rush to her.)

sp.speaker: FIRST GALLANT.
sp.p: What are you doing, Mistress? Are you firing at those Indians?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORREST.
sp.p: I am calling our men from work. They will punish you for what you have done.

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: There's no punishment that will fit such a deed. 'Tis a crime unspeakable.

sp.speaker: FOURTH GALLANT.
sp.p: Do not speak of punishment or crime to us. We outnumber the others.

sp.speaker: GALLANTS.
sp.p: Aye!

div3.stage: (Enter men from woods running. They. carry axes and muskets. Enter FORREST with them and BURRAS, the brother of ANN.)

sp.speaker: FORREST.
sp.p: What is it? What has happened?

sp.speaker: BURRAS
sp.p: Sister! You are trembling!

sp.speaker: FIRST GALLANT.
sp.p: Mistress Forrest was unduly excited and fired her musket in the air. We were merely trading with Indians.

sp.speaker: SIXTH GALLANT.
sp.p: And the trading was peaceful and friendly.

sp.speaker: OTHER GALLANTS.
sp.p: Of course! Yes-- yes--

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: Silence! I will tell you the truth, friends.

sp.speaker: BURRAS.
sp.p: Hark! What is that noise?
Men are running this way from the river!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORREST.
sp.p: The Indians come back to attack us!

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: Seize your muskets, men! Be ready!

div3.stage: (All lift muskets, even Mistress FORREST. The Chaplain unsheaths a sword. Pause. Enter Captain SMITH with his men. Others show relief; throw down arms; cries of welcome from his friends.)

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Why, what is this? You seem prepared for war.

sp.speaker: FORREST.
sp.p: We thought Indians were upon us. We did not expect you so soon.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: But we heard a shot as we landed. What is the trouble here?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORREST.
sp.p: Those men have betrayed us to Indians!

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: For this game they gave powder and arms.

sp.speaker: SMITH
sp.p: You should be shot down where you stand!

sp.speaker: FIRST GALLANT.
sp.p: Captain Smith, you are under arrest. Seize him, men, and put him in irons!

div3.stage: (Gallants rush at SMITH, who is instantly surrounded by his own men. FORREST and comrades rush to his aid. Gallants fall back.)

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Give up your swords! Refuse, and my men will fire.
And now, hark-- You will be held as prisoners till the next ship arrives. You will then be returned to England.

sp.speaker: FIRST GALLANT.
sp.p: We have powerful friends there, sir.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p:
Who have sent you here to be rid of you. Oh, I know all about you. You were wild and worthless in London, but you shall not ruin this colony. In the mean time, until a ship comes, you shall go
to work and clear land like the others. Give them your axes, men. Throw them down here.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Take up those axes!
Three counts I will give and not one instant over. Cover them with your muskets, men!
One-- two--
Now, then, march to the woods. And he who works not, shall not eat. Nay, not if he be starving! Go!

stage.hi: (Gallants go sullenly. SMITH turns to others.)

sp.p: I am most anxious, friends, about our arms. 'T was all planned by Powhatan methinks.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: He was shrewd enough to send his braves while you were away.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Well, we must demand that he return them. To-morrow we will go to his village with more men. And if Henry Spelman be not back by that time, we'll compel Powhatan to produce him.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Yes-- yes! To-morrow!

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: All hands now to bring corn from the boats!

div3.stage: (They start to river. Enter HENRY from woods. Be is pale and exhausted.)

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORREST.
sp.p: Why, 'tis Henry-- little Henry!

stage.hi: (Running to him. Others gather about him.)

sp.p: Fetch water, Ann!

div3.stage: (ANN runs to cabin. Mistress FORREST rubs the boy's hands and head. Enter ANN with water. HENRY drinks and revives.)

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: I got away last night-- Pocahontas helped me. It was terrible alone in the woods. I thought I would die of fright.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORREST.
sp.p: Don't think of that, child. You're at home again and we're all rejoiced to see you.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Aye!

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: Go no more to Powhatan, Captain. He will kill you. Pocahontas told me. She said he meant to kill us all.

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: So it has come to war at last!

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: We have barely escaped it this twelve-month. Can you tell us, Henry, whether Powhatan means to attack Jamestown?

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: Not now. He will kill us one by one as we work and fish and hunt.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: We must pursue those Indians at once, comrades, and take our arms by force. We cannot wait till to-morrow.

sp.speaker: TODKILL.
sp.p: I am ready, Captain.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: I am ready.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: And I! And I! And I!

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: It will be a dangerous pursuit. They may lie in wait for you now.

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: 'T is a chance we must take. Keep a close watch here, Master Forrest. Close the gate in the palisades, and sleep with your muskets ready. Guard also those worthless gallants in the field, lest the Indians attack them. Are you ready, men?

sp.speaker: SMITH'S MEN.
sp.p: Aye!

sp.speaker: SMITH.
sp.p: Come, then!

div3.stage: (He plunges into the woods. The men follow in single file.)

div3.head: ACT IV
div3.stage: The fort and street in front of it are seen. Cabins and palisades are half torn down. Everywhere is ruin and desolation. A miserable fire burns in street. By it sits GEORGE PERCY, sick, weak, starved. Pause. Enter HENRY SPELMAN from fort. He also is weak from starvation; walks feebly.)

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: You should stay in the fort, Henry. 'Tis safer in there.

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: I could not bear it; their suffering is terrible. They are starving to death, Master Percy.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: We can none of us last much longer.

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: And when we are too weak to fire our cannon, the Indians will attack us openly. And that will be the end of us all.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: Yes, lad, the end of us all.

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: I would we could do something for the women and children.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: We can do nothing. There is n't a morsel of food, and the Indians will give us nothing.

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: This trouble would not have come had Captain Smith been with us.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: Nay, and it would not. His strong hand controlled things better than we knew till he was gone from among us.

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: The Indians were afraid of him. They did not dare to destroy our fields while he was here.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: We can count our misfortunes from the day that he sailed to England.

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: I pray he hath recovered from the wound which made it necessary for him to go. Could I know that, I would die happier, Master.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: I rejoice you love him so, lad. He is my beloved hero, too.

stage.hi: (Long pause. Both sit staring into dying fire.)

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: Will you do me a favor, Master?

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: I will serve you in any way possible, lad.

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: If you survive and get to England again, please go to see my parents. Tell them I am sorry I ran away; tell them I love them dearly.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: I will, Henry, I promise you.

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: I would the chaplain were here to pray for us.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: He blessed us with his last breath.

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: I know--

div3.stage: (Pause. They stare into fire as before. Enter Mistress FORREST from fort. She is thin, pale, starved; walks feebly to woods. Men stagger to their feet.)

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: Mistress Forrest-- where are you going?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORREST.
sp.p: To beg food from the Indians.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: Nay, you must not!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORREST.
sp.p: Shall I let my husband starve before mine eyes?

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: The Indians will give you nothing.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORREST.
sp.p: I'll kneel in the dust before them; I'll beg them for one grain.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: Madam-- stay! I have something to tell you.
Other women have gone forth to beg. Do you know what happened to them?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORREST.
sp.p: Nay, I know not.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: They came back fearfully wounded-- and died.

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: They will treat you the same way, Mistress.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORREST.
sp.p: What will become of us! Are we all to perish here in this wilderness?

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: I would I could help you, Mistress.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORREST.
sp.p: Poor child-- you are scarce able to stand yourself. Poor little runaway Henry!
sp.stage: (Smooths his hair. Pause. Men's voices are heard off. All start in alarm.)
sp.p: Did you hear those voices?

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Aye--

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: Indians! Come, come to the fort!

div3.stage: (They start. HENRY stumbles and falls. The others lift him and assist him to fort; close door. Voices heard nearer. Pause. Enter Sir THOMAS GATES and sailors. They look about in astonishment.)

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS.
sp.p: Why, look you, everything is in ruins!

sp.speaker: FIRST SAILOR.
sp.p: Their cabins are half torn down!

sp.speaker: SECOND SAILOR.
sp.p: The palisades are almost gone!

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS.
sp.p: 'T is desolation unspeakable! And they told us in London we would find some two hundred colonists here, busy in their fields and happy.

sp.speaker: FIRST SAILOR.
sp.p: The Indians must have killed them all.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS.
sp.p: I fear it. Oh, 't is a piteous sight! It fills mine heart with horror.

sp.speaker: THIRD SAILOR.
sp.p: Their fort seems to be still in good condition, Sir Thomas. They may be within, in hiding.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS.
sp.p: I pray they may!

stage.hi: (Crosses quickly to fort; knocks on door.)

sp.p: Open, friends! I am Sir Thomas Gates of London. Open! Open!

div3.stage: (Door is opened. PERCY comes out, followed by HENRY, TODKILL, PHETTIPLACE, FORREST and his wife, ANN, and others-- men, women, children. All are feeble, but show joy. They hold out their arms in welcome.)

sp.speaker: COLONISTS.
sp.p: Englishmen! Englishmen!

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS.
sp.p: My friends-- my friends-- what hath happened to you here in Jamestown?

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: Food-- food-- or we perish!

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Food-- food!

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Bring food-- quick-- quick!
sp.stage: (Sailors go running. Some colonists sink to ground. Others lean against trees weakly.)
sp.p: Be of good cheer, friends, we have supplies in our ship for all of you.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: There are others in the fort who are worse off than we.

div3.stage: (Sir THOMAS hastens to fort; looks in; turns away sadly.)

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS.
sp.p:
Oh, this does grieve me sadly!
Only a handful left! Died the others of starvation?

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: Mostly, they did. But many were killed as they worked in the fields, and many while hunting or fishing. Lately we have not dared to stir from here, not even to get firewood.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS.
sp.p: So you have used your cabins for firewood, and likewise your palisades!

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: Dying men are reckless.

div3.stage: (Enter sailors with food which they give to colonists.)

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS.
sp.p: Feed those within-- assist them with all tenderness.
sp.stage: (Sailors enter fort with food. Sir THOMAS turns to colonists who are slowly reviving.)
sp.p: Can you tell me how this hath come upon you? Captain Smith reported the colony to be in good condition, when he arrived in England six months ago. He said many acres had been cleared, and an abundant harvest was certain.

sp.speaker: TODKILL.
sp.p: And so it was. But no sooner was the Captain gone than the Indians lost their fear of us. They destroyed our fields and shot all who tried to replant them.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS.
sp.p: Shot you? How can that be? Indians have no firearms.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PHETTIPLACE.
sp.p: They at one time got some of our muskets, which we never could take from them, though Captain Smith did go in pursuit.

sp.speaker: WILLIAM.
sp.p: And then, as time went on, there seemed to be always some traitor among us who would secretly give them our muskets in trade.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: And there were certain other traitors-- three Germans who came in the last ship. They left us and went to Powhatan and taught his braves how to use our muskets.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS.
sp.p: Could anything be meaner! Alas, that I did not come sooner! I expected to arrive three months ago, but was blown out of my course by a hurricane. In this delay we have almost consumed our stores, so we cannot supply you for many days. What, then, do you wish me to do?

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Take us back to England, sir.

sp.speaker: ANN.
sp.p: Take us home, sir.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORREST.
sp.p: Take us home-- home.

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.p: Home-- home.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS.
sp.p: It seems the only thing to do, but 't will cause much sorrow in England. The king hath set great store on this colony here.

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: We cannot starve that King James may own Virginia. Leave us here and we die.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS.
sp.p: Why, I would not leave you. The colony must be abandoned, of course. We will sail for England at once. If you have possessions, please to get them now.

stage.hi: (Enter sailors from fort. Colonists return to fort.)

sp.p: Go and prepare the ship for them, lads. You others may assist the sick from the fort.
sp.stage: (Sailors go hastily; some to river, others to fort. Pause. Sailors return from fort supporting the sick colonists.)
sp.p: Friends, we are going back to England.
sp.stage: (Murmurs of joy from colonists. Enter other colonists with small bundles.)
sp.p: Well, are you ready?

sp.speaker: COLONISTS.
sp.p: Aye--

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS.
sp.p: Then, come. And look your last on Jamestown.

stage.hi: (All start off to river. Enter Third Sailor from river hastily.)

sp.speaker: THIRD SAILOR.
sp.p: Hold! Stay!

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS.
sp.p: Why, what is this?

sp.speaker: SAILOR.
sp.p: Lord Delaware hath just landed!1 He hath brought three ships with supplies!

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS.
sp.p: Lord Delaware! Why, I can scarce believe mine ears! Lord Delaware here-- here on these shores?

sp.speaker: SAILOR.
sp.p: Aye, and spake with me. He said to keep the people here and he would come straight-way.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS.
sp.p: This be good news, friends. Lord Delaware is a great and noble man. Besides, he will be able to care for you far better than I could with my one small ship and scanty stores.

div3.note: 1 Lord Delaware actually met the colonists at the mouth of the river.
div3.stage: (Enter Lord DELAWARE with escort of soldiers. DELAWARE is handsomely dressed in velvet. The soldiers wear smart uniforms.)

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Welcome, Lord Delaware!

sp.speaker: DELAWARE.
sp.p: Sir Thomas-- friends-- I greet you. The sailors have told me of your sad estate, and it doth grieve me sorely. Praise God, I have come in time! Three ships of supplies have I brought, and many men and women. Will you not remain and begin anew? Will you not try again to make this land a fit abode for Englishmen?

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: 'T is my desire to live here if conditions can be bettered.

sp.speaker: DELAWARE.
sp.p: Conditions will be bettered. There will be no more mistakes. Captain Smith hath advised us at every step.

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: Hath Captain Smith recovered?

sp.speaker: DELAWARE.
sp.p: He is out of danger, my lad, and will return here as soon as he is able.

One thing more, my friends-- the dream of gold is over. The king no longer desires you to search for it. He bids you plant fields and build homes. Indeed, his Majesty hath sent with me many masons, carpenters, and farmers. Not a single gallant was allowed to come. And with each ship other Englishmen will come with their wives and children. And together you will grow in wealth and strength. The Indians will submit to you peaceably and will no doubt become Christians in time.
So remain, friends. A glorious future awaits you. Out of the ashes of your failures, your tears, and your sorrows, many English colonies will arise in this land. So do not think of to-day. Think of the happy to-morrow. Come, will you not make the sacrifice?

sp.speaker: PERCY.
sp.p: I will stay.

sp.speaker: MRS. FORREST.
sp.p: I am willing to remain if my husband consents.

sp.speaker: FORREST.
sp.p: I do consent and heartily.

sp.speaker: BURRAS.
sp.p: We will stay-- my sister and I.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: I will remain! And I! And I!

sp.speaker: DELAWARE
sp.p: May God bless you and keep your hearts as courageous in health as they are in this hour of your weakness. May He bless this New Colony of Jamestown till it shall arise in majesty-- the majesty of manhood the finest and best, of womanhood the bravest and purest. Again I say, God bless you!

div2.head:
A DREAM OF FREEDOM
OR
THE PURITANS OF SCROOBY

div3.head: ACT I

p.hi: PLACE: England. King's Church at Southwell, a village about fifteen miles from Scrooby.

div3.stage: (The vestry is seen dimly lighted. A large table is in center. Behind table, and facing it, are seven large chairs. Over center chair is a red velvet canopy. A heavy, barred door at right opens into churchyard. A smaller door at left opens into vestibule. In center chair sits the Beadle, asleep. He is a peaceful-looking old man with gray hair. There is a loud knock at door to yard. Beadle sleeps on. Knocking is repeated vigorously. Beadle wakes.)

sp.speaker: BEADLE
sp.p: Who knocks? Who knocks, I say?

sp.speaker: VOICE
sp.p: The bailiff knocks! The bailiff!

div3.stage: (Beadle shows alarm; rises; hastens to door walking feebly.)

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: Bailiff, said you?

sp.speaker: VOICE
sp.p: Aye! Bailiff of the High Court!

sp.speaker: BEADLE
sp.p: Presently, sir-- presently--
sp.stage: (Opens door. Enter the Bailiff, a large and powerful man. The Beadle trembles before him.)
sp.p: I crave your pardon, Master Bailiff,-- I knew not you would return to-night. It might be I fell into a doze, sir,-- it might be I was sleeping, sir.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Cease your chatter, Beadle. The Court of the High Commission will convene in extra session to-night.

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: Eh! Extra session! To-night!

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Come, come, the lights! There's no time to lose.

div3.stage: (Beadle scurries about, lighting candles, talking all the while.)

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: 'T is a strange thing, Master Bailiff, this night session.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: 'T was ordered by the king himself. A special post came from London a half-hour ago.

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: Why, 't is a thing unheard of! For twenty years have I been beadle here. For twenty years have I prepared this vestry for the High Courts of the Commission. And not once, sir, hath there been a night session.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: His Majesty is sending one of his own officers to sit with the Court to-night.

sp.speaker: BEADLE
sp.p: His own officer, say you?

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Aye. Now, then, light the chapel and the vestibule. And make haste, Beadle, make haste!

sp.speaker: BEADLE
sp.p: Aye-- aye--

div3.stage: (Exit to chapel. Bailiff removes hat and cloak. Enter Beadle.)

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: I can't understand it, sir. There must be fresh trouble with the Puritans--

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Is n't there always trouble with them?

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: It may be the king himself hath turned Puritan.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF
sp.p: The king turned Puritan! Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: There be many turning, these days.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF
sp.p: Aye, even our nearest kin.

sp.speaker: BEADLE
sp.p: Kin? Kin, say you?

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Come, now; come, now; you know what I mean well enough.

sp.speaker: BEADLE
sp.p: No one can question my loyalty to the king's church, sir,-- no one! I turn Puritan! Ha, ha! I detest them! The king is far too good to them, say I. I'd give them no trials at all. I'd hang them from the nearest tree, I would!

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: All of them?

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: Every one in this land!

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: So--! You would hang your son, would you?

div3.stage: (Beadle starts; clings to table for support. His voice trembles.)

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: My son! What do you say? My son!

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Come, now; come, now, Beadle. Your son hath turned Puritan, and you know it.

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: No-- no! Who told you that? Lies, sir,-- naught but lies!

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Why, then, does he go to Scrooby every Sunday?

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: Eh? To Scrooby?

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Aye, to Scrooby.

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: He-- he hath friends there. He-- he visits them on Sunday.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: And these friends are Puritans. And they are holding secret meetings there in spite of the king's order against it. Why, your son hath gone to Scrooby now!

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: He-- had business there--

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Business! Bah! Why, then, did he walk? His horse is in the stable now. The proof against your son is strong, Beadle,-- enough to send him to prison.

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: Well, what do you want of me?

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p:
Why did your son go to Scrooby to-day? 'T is a Thursday, and the Puritans meet only on
Sunday. And why did he walk the fifteen miles instead of riding as he always does? Tell me what you know, Beadle, and I'll protect your son.

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: You'll protect him? Your promise on it, sir! Give me your promise!

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: I give you my promise. Now, then,-- speak.

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: I didn't know he was a Puritan till to-day, sir. He confessed the truth this morning. He said the Puritan faith was the most beautiful thing in the world, and he hoped I'd find it out for myself some time.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF
sp.p: But what took him to Scrooby to-day?

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: He said they would meet together to-night.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: To-night, eh! Where?

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: At William Brewster's house, sir.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: This Court forbade William Brewster to hold another Puritan meeting in his house.

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: I reminded him of that, sir, and I begged him not to go, but he said there was something important to be discussed-- something he dared not tell me.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: 'T is a good chance to get them all! I'll inform the Court of this meeting.

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: Remember your promise, Master Bailiff--

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Your son shall go free.
'T is the Judge and Commissioners! Open the door to the vestibule.

div3.stage: (Beadle opens door at left. Enter Judge and six Commissioners. All wear black robes and white wigs. They cross to chairs; sit, Judge in center under canopy.)

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: Bailiff, bring in the prisoners-- those Puritans you arrested in the woods near Scrooby. We'll try them all together.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: One moment, please your Honor. I have just had important news in regard to the other Puritans of Scrooby.

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: We'll take that up in good time, Bailiff,-- the trial first. Bring in the prisoners.
sp.stage: (Exit Bailiff to yard. Beadle stands unnoticed in gloom of a dark corner. Judge turns to Commissioners.)
sp.p: Gentlemen, we may speak freely, now that we be alone. I confess to be amazed at his Majesty's message. This Court was created for the sole purpose of crushing Puritans. Therefore I see no reason for the sending of a special officer to sit with us, even though he be Sir Jasper-- the king's favorite general.

sp.speaker: FIRST COMMISSIONER.
sp.p: Could there be any dissatisfaction with our findings, your Honor?

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: We have fined and imprisoned every Puritan we could lay our hands on. And we have spies watching suspected ones constantly.

sp.speaker: SECOND COMMISSIONER.
sp.p: Perhaps Sir Jasper comes to compliment us on the zeal we show in crushing them.

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: Well, however it be, we have done our duty, gentlemen.

div3.stage: (Enter Bailiff with prisoners-- several Puritan men and women. They wear the Puritan dress; are guarded by soldiers.

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: Bailiff, what is the charge against these prisoners?

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: They are all members of the Puritan church at Scrooby, your Honor, and are therefore disobedient to his Majesty, King James. We found them stealing through the woods last Sunday on their way to their secret meeting-place.

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Have you a spokesman amongst you?

sp.speaker: PURITAN
sp.p: I will act as spokesman, your Honor.

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: Do you plead guilty to the charge against you?

sp.speaker: PURITAN.
sp.p: We do.

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: Did you know King James had forbidden the Puritans to meet together?

sp.speaker: PURITAN.
sp.p: We did.

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: Why, then, did you persist?

sp.speaker: PURITAN.
sp.p: We believe we have the right to worship as we choose, your Honor.

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: The law of England makes but one church legal-- the church of the king. Do you think you have the right to be lawless?

sp.speaker: PURITAN.
sp.p: We are all law-abiding citizens, your Honor.

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: You call it law-abiding to belong to a church prohibited by your king?

sp.speaker: PURITAN.
sp.p: No king can tell us what or what not to believe. We are Englishmen, your Honor, not slaves.

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: Ah! You defend your Puritan church, do you?

sp.speaker: PURITAN.
sp.p: I will yield up my life for my faith.

sp.speaker: PURITAN WOMAN.
sp.p: The same would I!

sp.speaker: OTHER PURITANS.
sp.p: And I! And I!

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: To jail with them, Bailiff! To-morrow take them to the dungeons at the Castle of York.

div3.stage: (Bailiff goes with Puritans and soldiers. The Puritans walk firmly, and show no fear. Renter Bailiff.)

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Your Honor, Sir Jasper hath arrived!

div3.stage: (Judge and Commissioners rise quickly. Bailiff opens door. Enter Sir JASPER and escort of soldiers. Sir JASPER is military in voice, manners, and carriage. He wears uniform of an English general. Judge and Commissioners bow.)

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER
sp.p: Be seated-- be seated, gentlemen! I have no time for ceremony.

Your Honor, I will come to the point at once.
The king is displeased with you. He hath granted you absolute power to destroy the Puritan church in this part of England. Have you done this? Speak.

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: We are doing it, my lord. Scarcely a day passes that some of the heretics are not sent to jail.

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: Then why does the Scrooby church still exist? The Puritans have been crushed in every other part of England. But word hath come to the king that here they still dare to meet. Explain this, your Honor.

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: I cannot understand it, my lord. We have had them watched and followed, and still they continue to meet; but every Sunday in a different place. And so secretly is this managed that our spies have not been able to find them all together.

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: You must find them, and speedily. That is his Majesty's command. Bailiff, I halted your prisoners just outside. You may bring them back. I would question them a little.

div3.stage: (Exit Bailif. Pause. Enter Bailiff with Puritans and guards.)

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: The prisoners are of Scrooby, my lord.

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER
sp.p:
I come from the king who commands you to answer my questions truthfully. Indeed, his Majesty promises freedom to those of you who will give information concerning your places of meeting. You have only to tell me where you have met since the king's proclamation was issued declaring such meetings illegal.
And I wish you to consider that, in giving this information, you are merely performing a duty you owe to your sovereign, who holds your fate in his hands. I wish also to remind you that his Majesty's patience with your sect is exhausted. You need expect no further clemency from him.

sp.speaker: SPOKESMAN.
sp.p: We have never received any clemency from King James.

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: Silence! I came not to argue with you. I came for information, which you will give if you value freedom and safety. I await your reply.
Freedom, remember, to the one who will inform.
I command you to speak.
I command you to tell me if one William Brewster be not your leader in all things. Doth he not allow you to meet in his house for service every Sunday?

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: We have stopped that, my lord. There will be no more meetings at Master Brewster's.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: May I speak, Sir Jasper?

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: Speak.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: I have just had secret information regarding a Puritan meeting. It will be held at Master Brewster's house in Scrooby to-night.

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER
sp.p: What know you of this meeting?
Again I command you to speak.
Sentence them for five years, your Honor.

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: So be it, my lord.

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER
sp.p: Who was your informant?

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: The beadle, my lord.

stage.hi: (Points to corner. Beadle comes down slowly.)

sp.p: His son hath turned Puritan. The beadle had it from him about the meeting to-night.

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: Is that the way of it, Beadle?

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: Yes, my lord. But the bailiff did promise to save my son--

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER
sp.stage: (to his aides and ignoring the Beadle's remark.)
sp.p: To your saddles, men! Lead the way, Bailiff! There's an extra horse for you.
We'll have them all in prison by morning, your Honor!

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: The bailiff promised to save my son--

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: Out of my way!

div3.stage: (Pushes Beadle aside and starts off. Judge and Commissioners rise: look after him. Puritan spokesman crosses quickly to Beadle: plucks at his sleeve. Beadle turns. Bailiff and soldiers make ready to depart with Puritan prisoners.)

sp.speaker: PURITAN.
sp.p: Sh! Would you save your son?

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: Aye-- I would--

sp.speaker: PURITAN.
sp.p: Go to Scrooby-- warn them!

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: 'T is too late--

sp.speaker: PURITAN.
sp.p: Take your son's horse-- ride across the fields. Will you not go?

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: Aye, I will!

div3.stage: (Puritan slips back to his place. Beadle slips out by chapel door just as last soldier disappears.)

div3.head: ACT II
div3.stage:
(The large living-room is seen well lighted with candles. A heavy barred door at back opens into yard. A smaller door at left leads to inner rooms. The windows are covered with thick curtains. There is a high paneled wainscoting around the
walls. There are large chairs, a handsome table, and a picture or two. In fact, the room and its furnishings show the BREWSTERS to be people of culture, with a comfortable income. Many Puritans, men and women of all ages, are seen talking earnestly in groups. There are a number of children, all of whom listen solemnly to their elders. All wear the simple Puritan dress, men, women, and children, and all carry bundles of various sizes. Many pieces of baggage are piled about room. WILLIAM and Mistress BREWSTER talk with JOHN ROBINSON, the pastor, and his wife. WILLIAM BREWSTER is a fine-looking man of about forty years. He is educated and cultured; is pleasant and courteous. JOHN ROBINSON, also, is a cultured gentleman; is gentle and sympathetic; wears clerical garb of Puritans. Mistress ROBINSON and Mistress BREWSTER are refined women of thirty years or so. They show determination and courage. JONATHAN BREWSTER, a boy of fifteen, stands close to door at back. He seems to be listening to a sound without.)

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: Well, Master Brewster, the time so long looked forward to hath come, and no one seems to regret it.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: All do seem calm and courageous, Master Robinson. But they know the danger full well.

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p:
Father! Some one
comes! I heard steps on the stones at the gate. May I draw the bars?

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Wait, Jonathan, till our signal is given.

sp.speaker: JONATHAN.
sp.p: 'Tis Master Wexton-- the beadle's son.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: How know you that so surely?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN.
sp.p: All of our people are come but he.

sp.speaker: ROBINSON
sp.p: 'T is true-- he alone is lacking.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Nevertheless, we must wait for our signal. 'T would be dangerous to open without it.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: 'T is strange the signal is not given.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Methinks 't was one of our guards he heard. They are watching closely to-night.

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: 'T is well, for 't is a most important night to us.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS ROBINSON.
sp.p: The most important in our lives! I wonder if we shall get safely away.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS CARVER.
sp.p: That is my thought, too, Mistress Robinson.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: So far our plans have carried. It all depends now on our boatmen-- whether they can get the barge here without being seen by the king's spies.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: They were not to come till the night grew dark.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: And so they will not, Master Carver. Master Bradford hath the matter in charge.

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: Then all will be performed as was planned. William Bradford is a young man to depend on.

sp.speaker: WINSLOW.
sp.p: Is it not time for the barge, friends?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS WINSLOW.
sp.p: 'T is after midnight, and the night is dark.

div3.stage: (A knock at door, back ; then two short knocks.)

sp.speaker: JONATHAN.
sp.p: 'T is our signal, father!
'T is not Master Wexton! 'T is Master William Bradford!

div3.stage: (Enter WILLIAM BRADFORD. He is an intelligent, earnest youth of eighteen.)

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Ah, Master Bradford! You bring us news?

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: The barge is here, friends We have landed just below your orchard, Master Brewster, where the shadows on the river are deepest.
