sp.speaker: BREWSTER
sp.p: Are you ready?

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Yes-- yes--

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: I'll call the guards-- they are waiting without to carry the heaviest baggage.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: One moment-- Is it certain no spies are about?

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: We have seen no one, Master Carver. Certain of our men are now patrolling the river shore and orchard. Others, the roads and all by-paths.

sp.speaker: WINSLOW.
sp.p: Every precaution hath been taken, it seems.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: We can do no more than watch. Call the guards, William. Friends, prepare to depart.

div3.stage: (There is much commotion, all hastening to select bundles. BRADFORD opening door; six guards entering. ROBINSON crosses to door; faces others.)

sp.speaker: ROBINSON
sp.p: My people-

Think again what you are doing! Reflect, ere it be too late. You are leaving your homes forever. You are going to a foreign land with nothing of your possessions save the little you carry in your hands. You are leaving your lands; even your means of making a livelihood. No one knows what the future will bring to us in Holland. 'Tis like we shall find it hard to make even enough for a few years to provide us with food and shelter. Shall we be able to endure such poverty? Think again on these things, my people. Shall we not remain? It is not too late.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: There is no longer hope for any Puritan in England. The king himself is our most bitter enemy.

sp.speaker: WINSLOW.
sp.p:
And he is spreading the net about us
rapidly. Soon we shall all be caught and commanded to renounce our faith. Could we do that?

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: No! NO!

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: I would rather leave my worldly goods than give up my freedom of conscience.

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: Aye! To keep a good conscience is a thing to be preferred even before life itself.

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: But think of the danger we run in trying to get away from England. Every port is closed against us.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: But we shall sail secretly, at night, and from a place near by, and many miles from the king and his court. Besides, the captain hath been paid double the usual passage, and is willing to take the risk.

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: And besides, and best of all, we go to Holland, where we shall be free-- free to talk-to think, and to worship.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Yes-- yes-- to be free-- free--

sp.speaker: ROBINSONN--
sp.p: I see you are determined. May God in his mercy guide us.

sp.speaker: BRADFORD
sp.p: The heavier pieces, men, at once.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p:
One moment, please you-- 'Tis well we should speak of our plans again, lest there be some miscarriage. The guards will load the baggage on and will then return for the women and children,
who will, as you know, go in the barge, with only a boatman or two. We men will walk, and will meet the barge near Boston. You know the place-- where a neck of land juts into the sea.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Aye-- we know!

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Come, then, we must move with dispatch.

div3.stage: (BRADFORD and guards take baggage out. BREWSTER closes and bars door. JONATHAN crosses to him; speaks with him aside.)

sp.speaker: JONATHAN.
sp.p: 'T is strange about Master Wexton, father.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: I fear he has met with trouble. But 't were best to say nothing. We must not alarm the others.

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: It might cause them to lose heart.

stage.hi: (Knock at door-- then two shorter knocks.)

sp.p: 'T is the signal, father!
sp.stage: (Opens door. Enter RALPH WEXTON, a sturdy, serious young man: does not wear Puritan dress.)
sp.p: 'T is Master Wexton!

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: I feared you were not coming, Ralph.

sp.speaker: WEXTON.
sp.p: A spy followed me from Southwell, sir.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: Followed you here! 'T will be the undoing of us and our plans.

sp.speaker: WEXTON.
sp.p: Nay, I hid in the woods so long a time he lost the scent, and returned whence he came.

sp.speaker: WINSLOW.
sp.p: 'T is strange you were followed. You are not wearing the Puritan dress.

sp.speaker: WEXTON.
sp.p: I dared not. The High Court hath begun its sessions at Southwell, in the church where my father is beadle.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS ROBINSON.
sp.p: Have they tried our people as yet?

sp.speaker: WEXTON.
sp.p: Many of them, Mistress Robinson.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: We need not ask their sentences--

sp.speaker: WEXTON.
sp.p: Fines and prisons for every one.

sp.speaker: A GIRL
sp.p: My father-- did he speak of me?

sp.speaker: WEXTON.
sp.p: He sent you his love and said he would join you as soon as he was free again.

sp.speaker: A BOY.
sp.p: Did you see my mother, sir?

sp.speaker: WEXTON.
sp.p: I did, lad. She was praying to be with you soon.
They were all praying to join us in Holland.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: And they shall! Their fines shall be paid, and their passage to Holland shall be arranged as soon as it is possible. I pledge myself to that.

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: And I. And I. And I.

div3.stage: (Puritan signal heard at door. BREWSTER opens door. Enter BRADFORD. BREWSTER closes door; bars it.)

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: We are ready now for the women and children. The guards wait at the river.

div3.stage: (Women and children cross to door. Men fall back.)

sp.speaker: JONATHAN.
sp.p: Mother, let me go with the men.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: Nay, they have fifty miles to walk.

sp.speaker: JONATHAN.
sp.p: I can do it.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: You might be a hindrance to your father. Come with me, Jonathan.

div3.stage: (JONATHAN follows her to door obediently. The pastor crosses; faces them.)

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: Sisters, again I would speak. You know well that I am with you heart and soul; and yet I would not see you walk deliberately into danger. Do you fully realize what it would mean should your barge be discovered as it floats to the sea? You would be sent straightway to prison. No compassion would be shown you or your children.

sp.speaker: FIRST WOMAN.
sp.p: I am not afraid.

sp.speaker: SECOND WOMAN.
sp.p: The thought of prison does not frighten me.

sp.speaker: THIRD WOMAN.
sp.p: No, nor me.

sp.speaker: FIRST CHILD.
sp.p: I fear nothing.

sp.speaker: SECOND CHILD.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: OTHER CHILDREN.
sp.p: Nor I! Nor I!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS ROBINSON.
sp.p: How could we be afraid when these children show no fear?

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: You are fully prepared then for the worst that may befall?

sp.speaker: ALL WOMEN.
sp.p: Aye!

sp.speaker: ROBINSON
sp.p: So be it. I can say no more.

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: 'T is not our signal.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Who knocks?

sp.speaker: VOICE
sp.p: Open! Open!

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Who are you?

sp.speaker: VOICE
sp.p: Open--

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: What is your errand here?

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: Open-- quick-- open!

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: We open to no stranger. Who are you? Speak your name, sir!

sp.speaker: VOICE
sp.p: Beadle-- beadle--

sp.speaker: BREWSTER
sp.p: "Beadle," he says. Could he be--

sp.speaker: WEXTON
sp.p: Father! Be it you?

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: Aye--

div3.stage: (BREWSTER opens door. Enter Beadle exhausted.)

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: Fly-- fly! They come! Sir Jasper-- the bailiff-- soldiers!

div3.stage: (Sinks into a chair.)

sp.speaker: WEXTON.
sp.p: Where are they? Speak, father, speak! Are they close upon us?

sp.speaker: BEADLE
sp.p: Aye-- close-- close-- Ralph-- your horse-- fly-- fly--

div3.stage: (Leans back almost unconscious. RALPH and ROBINSON attend him. Women bring water.)

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: 'T would be foolhardy to go to the barge now. There is only one means of escape, and that is the secret passage.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: We will be caught like rats in a trap should they by chance discover it.

sp.speaker: BRADFORD
sp.p: They are crossing the bridge! They 're coming on the gallop!

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: They will be here in a moment!
sp.stage: (Crosses; slides back a panel in wainscoting. A small opening is disclosed.)
sp.p: Into the passage-- quick! 'T is your only chance! Quick,-- quick!

div3.stage: (Men step back, allowing women and children to enter first.)

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: They are dismounting! Quick! We dare not keep them waiting.

div3.stage: (Beadle is led into passage. Enter all but the BREWSTER family and BRADFORD.)

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Master Bradford-- come!

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: I will stay here with you--

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: No one but my family must be found here. 'T would excite suspicion. Come.
sp.stage: (Loud knock at door. BRADFORD enters passage. BREWSTER slides panel into place. Mistress BREWSTER throws off wraps and sits. JONATHAN stands by her. Knock repeated. BREWSTER crosses to door.)

figure.p: "INTO THE PASSAGE-- QUICK! 'TIS YOUR ONLY CHANGE"

sp.p: Who knocks?

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: Open in the name of King James!

div3.stage: (BREWSTER opens door. Enter Sir JASPER, Bailiff, and soldiers.)

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: Be you William Brewster?

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: I am, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: William Brewster, I am Sir Jasper of the king's court.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER
sp.p: Well, my lord--

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: I have been commissioned by his Majesty to make certain accusations against you.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Of what am I guilty, my lord?

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: I accuse you of disobedience in matters of religion. I accuse you of permitting Puritans to meet here in your home, in spite of the king's proclamation against such meetings. Finally, I accuse you of harboring Puritans here to-night. What have you to say to that, sir?
Well, do you deny it?

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Of what use to deny, my lord?

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: Where are these Puritans? I command you to produce them.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: The house is open to you.

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: Search every room, Bailiff!
sp.stage:
(Bailiff and soldiers go to interior. Sir JASPER walks about, looking at everything with suspicion; thrusts sword up fireplace; looks behind window curtains; finally halts before panel leading
to secret passage; points to JONATHAN with his sword; speaks gruffly.)
sp.p: Come here, boy!
sp.stage: (BREWSTER and wife show alarm, but JONATHAN crosses bravely.)
sp.p: So you be a Puritan, be you?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN.
sp.p: Aye, sir, I be.

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: Do you know that I have the power to punish you?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN.
sp.p: Aye, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: Do you know that I can take you away from your parents to-night and put you in prison wherever I choose?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Aye, sir.

div3.stage: (BREWSTER is alarmed: his wife is trembling with fear.)

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: Well, then, my boy, I will tell you how to save yourself. You have merely to tell me where these Puritans have gone and you shall go free. And so shall your father and mother.

div3.stage: (Pause. JONATHAN looks at his parents; then turns to Sir JASPER.)

sp.speaker: JONATHAN.
sp.p: My father told you to search the house.

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER
sp.p: I command you to tell me-- this instant!

sp.speaker: JONATHAN.
sp.p: I will not tell you anything!

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER
sp.p: Oh-- ho! I've a mind to punish your impudence!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER
sp.p: He does not mean to be impudent, my lord. He hath been brought up a Puritan-- he knows nothing else.

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: You had best teach him something else, and quickly.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER
sp.p: That, my lord, is a matter that concerns us alone.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: There's not a sign of them, my lord.

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: Did you search the garrets and cellars?

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Thoroughly, my lord.

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: We have failed this time, Master Brewster, but we will come again. Your house will be watched. Yourself will be followed whene'er you stir from your door. We will make you conform, or we'll harry you into a dungeon. You can't escape us, sirrah. Try it at your peril.
sp.stage: (Starts off; turns at door; shakes finger at BREWSTER.)
sp.p: Try it at your peril, sirrah!

div3.stage: (Exit, followed by Bailiff and soldiers. JONATHAN slips out after them unnoticed. BREWSTER closes and bars door; crosses to panel.)

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: You had best wait a little-- they might return.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: It would be safer--
Where is Jonathan?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: He was here but a moment ago.
Jonathan!
Jonathan!
William! Could they have taken him?

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Oh, no! That's impossible. I'll look through the house.

div3.stage: (Exit. Pause. Mistress BREWSTER moves about anxiously. Enter BREWSTER alarmed.)

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: You did not find him!

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: No, Mary-- I cannot understand it.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: Then they have taken him! Sir Jasper said he would punish him! William-- what shall we do? What shall we do!

sp.speaker: BREWSTER
sp.p: We'll find a way to get him back-- I'll go to the king myself--
Who can it be? The guards would not venture here now-- I fear Sir Jasper hath returned--

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: He may bring us news of Jonathan! Let him enter, William!

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: But what if he hath compelled Jonathan to disclose the secret of that panel? Can we allow our brethren to be discovered and driven off to prison?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p:
Jonathan would not tell
them. I would stake my life on that. He is a staunch little Puritan. Open! I beg you to open!

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Who knocks?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: Tell them they must give our boy back to us!

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Who knocks, I say?

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: 'T is I-- I! Jonathan!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: Open! Open!
Jonathan! Did they take you?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN.
sp.p: Take me! Ha, ha! They did n't even know I was there. I hid behind the bushes to see if any should stay to spy. But they all rode away-- you can't even hear their horses.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: My brave boy!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: My courageous little Puritan!

div3.stage: (Brewster slides back panel: speaks into opening.)

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Come, 't is safe now.
sp.stage: (Enter Puritans and Beadle from secret passage.)
sp.p: The way is clear-- go quickly.

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: Come, I will lead you. We'll creep down through the orchard. Keep well in the shadows, and go as silently as possible.

div3.stage: (Puritans go. Beadle lingers.)

sp.speaker: WEXTON.
sp.p: Come, father.

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: I be no Puritan.

sp.speaker: WEXTON.
sp.p: You can't return now to your church. They would clap you into prison.

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: But I say I be no Puritan.

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: Come with us-- Puritan or no. We'll care for you as if you were, for we owe you a debt of gratitude. Remember you have saved us all this night.

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: I'll come, but 't is only because I must, for I say I be no Puritan.

div3.stage: (Goes with son. The BREWSTERS are last. They turn at door and look back into room.)

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER
sp.p: Just a last look, William--

sp.speaker: BREWSTER
sp.p: Aye, Mary, just a last look--

div3.head: ACT III
div3.p: PLACE: On board an English sailing vessel just off Boston, a village on east coast of England.
div3.stage: (A flaming torch lights deck. First Mate is seen peering out into darkness. Enter Second Mate; looks about cautiously; crosses quickly.)

sp.speaker: SECOND MATE.
sp.p: A word with you, Mate!
They have changed the course! Have you marked it?

sp.speaker: FIRST MATE.
sp.p: Aye, we be headed for land now.

sp.speaker: SECOND MATE.
sp.p: 'T is contrary to agreement. We shipped for Holland direct.

sp.speaker: FIRST MATE.
sp.p: And here we be putting into Boston.

sp.speaker: SECOND MATE
sp.p: Look you! We'll not be landing at Boston! There's the lights of the town a half-mile below.

sp.speaker: FIRST MATE
sp.p: 'T is a neck of land we be making!

sp.speaker: SECOND MATE.
sp.p: It looks like a bit of smuggling, I say.

sp.speaker: FIRST MATE.
sp.p: Nay, that's too risky these days.

sp.speaker: SECOND MATE.
sp.p: Risky! Pshaw! That's naught to me if I get my share of the booty.

sp.speaker: FIRST MATE
sp.p: Sh! The Captain!

div3.stage: (Exit Second Mate quickly. Enter the Captain, a sullen, surly Englishman. First Mate salutes.)

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Well, have you noticed we're headed for land, Mate?

sp.speaker: FIRST MATE.
sp.p: Aye, Captain.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: And you're suspicious about it, eh?

sp.speaker: FIRST MATE.
sp.p: I was just wondering, sir--

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: I've made arrangements to take on some passengers here-- some Puritans, in fact.

sp.speaker: FIRST MATE
sp.p: Puritans! That's dangerous business, Captain.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: I've charged them well for the risk.

sp.speaker: FIRST MATE.
sp.p: But there's a law against taking the heretics away.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: I've arranged against that.

sp.speaker: FIRST MATE.
sp.p: Maybe you can save yourself, Master, but I am a poor man, and I have no hankerings for prison. Besides, I've a family to think of.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: It's all arranged, I tell you. There will be no danger for any one. I have written the Boston magistrate about these Puritans.

sp.speaker: FIRST MATE.
sp.p: You have written the magistrate!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: I am only protecting myself. If the officers wish to prevent their escape, they may. It is none of my affairs. So as soon as we land, you will go ashore and report our position to his Honor.

sp.speaker: FIRST MATE.
sp.p: I cannot do that, Captain.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: You refuse! You dare to refuse!

sp.speaker: FIRST MATE.
sp.p: Aye. I be no Puritan, but I'l not help to betray them and throw the women into prison.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Come, come; there'll be a bit of gold for you. I have arranged that with the magistrate.

sp.speaker: MATE.
sp.p: There's no gold can make me do it.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Seize this man!

stage.hi: (Sailors hesitate: look from Captain to Mate.)

sp.p: Seize him, I say! To the cell with him! If he struggles, put him in irons.
sp.stage: (Sailors seize and take Mate off. Enter Second Mate. Captain turns to him.)
sp.p: Come to my cabin. There 's certain work for you to-night.

div3.stage: (They go. Enter other sailors: work at ropes. Go, dragging ropes off. Pause. Bells ring. Captain and Second Mate hurry on.)

sp.speaker: OFFICER.
sp.p: She's anchored, sir.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Man a boat for Boston at once-- get the best oarsmen. Send the other boats to the shore at this point. We 're taking on some passengers.

sp.speaker: OFFICER.
sp.p: Aye, sir.

stage.hi: (Exit officer. Captain turns to Second Mate.)

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Go quickly, and keep your boat well away from the shore, lest the Puritans see you.

sp.speaker: SECOND MATE.
sp.p: What about my share of the spoils?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: I said nothing about spoils.

sp.speaker: SECOND MATE.
sp.p: I demand my share-- I'll not stir without.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: Name your price.

sp.speaker: SECOND MATE.
sp.p: One tenth of the gold paid to you by the magistrate.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: 'T is robbery!

sp.speaker: SECOND MATE.
sp.p: I'll not go for less.

div3.stage: (Pause. Captain glares at Mate, who stands his ground.)

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: I agree. Now, go, and make haste. Tell his Honor I'll hold the ship for a time.

sp.speaker: OFFICER.
sp.p: The first boat hath returned with passengers.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Send it back-- keep all the boats going.
sp.stage: (Exit officer. Enter many Puritans. Captain receives them cordially; bows to women; shakes hands with men; pats children's heads.)
sp.p: Welcome-- welcome to you all! Here you be in safety, and the king is none the wiser. Ha, ha! I said it would happen thus. I told Master Brewster so from the start.
Where is Master Brewster?

sp.speaker: A MAN.
sp.p: He will come with the last load.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: That's the proper spirit for a leader! The last boat always. And now will it please you to go below? We must make room for the others.
sp.stage: (Puritans go. Enter other Puritans, Captain greeting them as before.)
sp.p:
Welcome-- welcome! Why, this is better luck
than e'en I hoped for. No mishaps-- everything exactly as we had arranged. 'T is remarkable, I say-- remarkable!
sp.stage: (Enter other Puritans, including ROBINSON, BRADFORD, CARVER, WINSLOW, and the BREWSTER family.)
sp.p: Welcome-- welcome-- welcome! Ah, Master Brewster! I was just asking for you.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Every one is safely on. You can get away at once, Captain.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: I am sorry, Master, but we shall be delayed a little.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Delayed!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: A slight leakage. It won't keep us long-- a few minutes at the most.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Every moment is full of danger to us.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Is there not danger for me as well?

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: You will suffer with us, of course.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Of course. 'T would be prison for me and my officers.
Will you please to go below? I need the deck clear for sailing.
sp.stage: (Puritans go. Captain at once shows surliness. Enter an Officer.)
sp.p: Watch for boat there! Watch sharp!
sp.stage: (Officer peering out into darkness. Captain pacing deck. Long pause. Captain speaks sharply.)
sp.p: There should be a boat coming out from Boston. Don't you see it?

sp.speaker: OFFICER.
sp.p: Nay, I see nothing as yet.

div3.stage: (Enter BREWSTER, BRADFORD, and RALPH WEXTON.)

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: How much longer shall we be delayed, Captain?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: The accident was worse than I thought. But within the hour--

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Hour! We must get away at once. The leakage can be stopped at sea.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: 'T would be most unsafe.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: 'T will be safer than staying here. There's a good breeze. Unfurl your sails quickly.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: That is impossible--

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: You must!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Must? That's a strong word, sirrah!

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: We have the right to use it. We have paid you a large sum of money-- in fact, we have overpaid you, as you very well know. We demand you set sail instantly.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: I am master of this ship. I shall sail whenever it pleases me.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER
sp.p: Unfurl the sails! Come!

div3.stage: (Puritans run to sails. Captain draws sword, barring their way.)

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Back ! You 'll not touch the sails ! Back-- back, I say!
Officer, bring men! We'll put these fellows in irons!

sp.speaker: OFFICER.
sp.p: Aye, aye, sir!
The boat, Master! 'T is here-- at the ship's side!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: Unfurl the sails, Puritans. Little good 't will do you now.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: You have betrayed us!

div3.stage: (Enter Second Mate with Magistrate and soldiers.)

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Seize these fellows, your Honor! They are the ringleaders.
sp.stage: (Magistrate motions to soldiers, who seize Puritans. They struggle in vain.)
sp.p: The others are below, your Honor.

sp.speaker: MAGISTRATE
sp.p: Force them up!
sp.stage: (Soldiers go. Pause. Women and children heard screaming off. BREWSTER, BRADFORD, and WEXTON renew struggles to escape. Enter Puritans driven by soldiers. The men are angry; women frightened; children cry with fear.)
sp.p: Search them! Tear open their bundles!
sp.stage: (Soldiers search men; take money from them; tear bags from women and open them, finding rings, silver spoons, etc. They open larger bundles, finding books in many.)
sp.p: Throw the books overboard!

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: I beg you-- let us keep our books!

sp.speaker: MAGISTRATE.
sp.p: Over with them! We'll have none of their Puritan books in England.
Now, then,-- to jail with them all!

div3.stage: (Soldiers go, driving Puritans along with jeers and sneers.)

div3.head: ACT IV
div3.p: PLACE: London-- Council Chamber in the king's palace.
div3.stage: (Three Councillors are seen seated at a massive table, busy with papers. Enter Usher.)

sp.speaker: USHER.
sp.p: My lords, Sir Jasper is impatient-- he has waited long in the ante-room.

sp.speaker: FIRST COUNCILLOR.
sp.p: Say to Sir Jasper that we regret this delay, but his Majesty hath not come, nor hath he sent us any word in reply to our request for his presence. Pending that, we cannot admit him, though we be the king's own councillors.

sp.speaker: USHER
sp.p: Yes, my lord--

sp.speaker: SECOND COUNCILLOR.
sp.p:
You may tell Sir Jasper also
that we have read his report with interest, and have discussed the matter among us.

sp.speaker: THIRD COUNCILLOR.
sp.p: Perhaps we should have told his Majesty the nature of the matter to be discussed.

sp.speaker: SECOND COUNCILLOR.
sp.p: Nay. 'T would have angered him so greatly he would not even counsel with us.

sp.speaker: FIRST COUNCILLOR.
sp.p: Aye, it is better to get him here, and then declare the matter.

sp.speaker: USHER.
sp.p: His Majesty, King James!

div3.stage: (Councillors rise. Enter KING JAMES-- a small man, ugly in face and figure. Councillors bow. King crosses; sits in great chair at head of table; motions others to sit.)

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Well, what business is it that demands my attention at once?

sp.speaker: FIRST COUNCILLOR.
sp.p: Your Majesty, the Puritan question hath come up again.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Those heretics again! I thought we had crushed them out of existence.

sp.speaker: FIRST COUNCILLOR.
sp.p: Sir Jasper brought the news. He waits without to see you.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Admit Sir Jasper.
sp.stage: (Usher opens a door; stands aside. Enter Sir JASPER. He bows to King and Councillors. Exit Usher.)
sp.p: Now, what is this about the Puritans, Sir Jasper? Where are they making trouble this time?

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: In Scrooby, Sire.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Scrooby! How can that be? We sent every one of those Scrooby heretics to jail last fall-- when they tried to run away to Holland.

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: 'Tis true, your Majesty, but they were gradually released until all of them were free again. They managed to pay their fines in some way.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: And now they are holding their meetings again, I suppose. Well, I'll crush them this time. They'll not dare show their heads again in England. Proceed against them at once, Sir Jasper. Seize them wherever you find them; throw them into prison. And this time permit no one to pay a fine-- they can be released only at my pleasure. You understand, Sir Jasper?

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: Sire, it is useless--

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Useless! What mean you--?

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: They have run away again, your Majesty.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Eh! What is this? Run away again, you say?

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: Aye, only last night, your Majesty. They had arranged with a Dutch captain to take them to Holland this time. He was to meet them at--

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Did you get them? That's all I want to know.

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: Only the women and children.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: What! Why-- How is that?

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: It seems the men had walked to the coast from Scrooby, while the women and children were sent down the river in a barge-- just as they arranged the first time.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Well-- well-- go on--

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: The men arrived first, and the captain sent out a boat and took them on to save time.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: The rascal! Go on--

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: By that time the barge had arrived, and the captain was just sending out a second boat when he saw our soldiers coming.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: And then--! What happened?

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: Then he sailed away, your Majesty.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Sailed away!

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: Aye, Sire-- with the men, leaving the women and children on the shore. The soldiers seized them and took them off to jail, in spite of their tears and pleadings. And now the magistrates know not what to do with them.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Why, keep them in jail, of course.

sp.speaker: FIRST COUNCILLOR.
sp.p: Your pardon, Sire, but the people will sympathize with these unfortunate women and children. They will say they are not to be blamed because their husbands are Puritans.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Suppose they do say so? What comes of that?

sp.speaker: SECOND COUNCILLOR.
sp.p:
Just this, Sire,-- more
Puritans. Their attempt to leave England last fall attracted much attention to them and their cause and made many converts for them.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: I would I could be rid of the very name of Puritan!

sp.speaker: THIRD COUNCILLOR.
sp.p: Then let these women go to Holland, Sire. Let them join their husbands. That will end the trouble for good and all, and they will very soon be forgotten.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: No! I'll keep them here and make an example of them. I'll have them severely punished.

sp.speaker: FIRST COUNCILLOR.
sp.p: And every punishment will make so many new Puritans, your Majesty.

sp.speaker: SECOND COUNCILLOR.
sp.p: And besides, their husbands who have gone to Holland will be in a position to harass you. They will flood all England with their petitions for the release of the prisoners. They will soon arouse the whole land with their controversies.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: How does it seem to you, Sir Jasper?

sp.speaker: SIR JASPER.
sp.p: They can cause unending trouble for your Majesty.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Well, I suppose I must. There seems to be no other way out of it.
Let the women and children go to Holland.

div4.head: FIRST TABLEAU
div4.p: Puritan men of Scrooby are seen on the docks in Holland. They are looking out to sea and waving handkerchiefs joyfully. Many Dutch people stand near by, showing interest.

div4.head: SECOND TABLEAU
div4.p: Puritan women and children of Scrooby are seen on deck of a sailing vessel, waving to their friends on the docks. All show great joy.

div2.head:
TROUBLES ON LAND AND SEA
OR
THE PILGRIMS AND THEIR JOURNEYS

div4.head: SCENE I
div4.p: PLACE: Leyden, Holland. Office of city officials.
div4.stage: (The Burgomaster is seen writing at a table in his private office. Enter his Secretary.)

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: Your Honor--

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER.
sp.p: Yes, Jan--

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: Will your Honor receive the English Ambassador?

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER.
sp.p: When does he wish an appointment?

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: His lordship is waiting, your Honor. He says his mission is important and hopes you will see him at once.

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER.
sp.p: Admit him without delay.

div4.stage: (Exit Secretary. Pause. Renter Secretary showing in the English Ambassador.)

sp.speaker: SECRETARY
sp.p: Sir Dudley Carleton!

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER
sp.p: My lord-- you honor me.

sp.speaker: AMBASSADOR
sp.p: Nay, 't is you who honor me, sir. You receive me without the usual formalities of making a fixed appointment.

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER.
sp.p: 'Tis a pleasure to receive England's Ambassador at any time. Please you to be seated, Sir Dudley.

sp.speaker: AMBASSADOR.
sp.p: Your Honor will pardon the abruptness of my call when you know 't was made necessary by certain letters received just now from his Majesty, King James of England.

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER.
sp.p: I am deeply interested, my lord.

sp.speaker: AMBASSADOR.
sp.p:
Briefly, then, the matter is this: It hath recently come to the king's knowledge that certain books are being printed here in Leyden--
books which offend his Majesty greatly. In fact they are written by Puritans and printed by Puritans and glorify the Puritan faith.

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER.
sp.p: Holland permits the free publication of religious books by any sect or society.

sp.speaker: AMBASSADOR.
sp.p: But these books are being shipped to England, where the printing and sale of Puritan books hath long ago been prohibited. His Majesty therefore asks that your Honor suppress their publication here in Leyden.

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER.
sp.p: We have no jurisdiction over that, Sir Dudley.

sp.speaker: AMBASSADOR.
sp.p: Your Honor, the king requests that the press and type be seized, and the publisher be imprisoned.

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER.
sp.p: But, my lord, 't is beyond my authority! Besides, this publisher is a man who is much respected here. He is one William Brewster, an Englishman, who hath been here many years.

sp.speaker: AMBASSADOR.
sp.p: But he hath offended King James-- and this is not the first time. He was one of those Scrooby Puritans who defied the king and then ran away with his fellows. And so, with all these things, the king is exceedingly wroth and desires you to imprison him.

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER.
sp.p:
'T would offend the whole body of Puritans who have all made splendid citizens. For twelve years have they been here, and in all that time not one case of trouble hath arisen amongst
them or between them and the Dutch people. They are industrious, and so honest that, if any desire credit, he has only to say he is a Puritan.

sp.speaker: AMBASSADOR.
sp.p: Be that as it may, his Majesty desires that a way be found to arrest this Brewster, even to the creating of a new law to cover the case.

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER.
sp.p: I have no power to create new laws. That rests with our reigning prince, my lord.

sp.speaker: AMBASSADOR.
sp.p: I have written your prince recently in regard to the matter.

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER.
sp.p: I have not heard from his Highness.

sp.speaker: AMBASSADOR.
sp.p: Then, pending his letter, I ask that you hold this Brewster as a prisoner.

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER.
sp.p: Did I consent to that, I would soon have a mob of howling students about me, for the Puritan pastor, Master Robinson, is very popular at the University. He is frequently asked to debate with the professors, who hold him in great esteem and declare him to be one of the most intellectual men in all Europe. Do you see, then, what a hornet's nest I would be stirring up by the arrest of one of his chief elders?

sp.speaker: AMBASSADOR.
sp.p:
Nevertheless, a way must be found. I have never known his Majesty more determined in any matter. Indeed, if Holland does not yield to him in this matter, he threatens to give her no
support should Spain declare war against her-- as does now seem likely.

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER
sp.p: Hath his Majesty said that?

sp.speaker: AMBASSADOR.
sp.p: Aye, and bade me tell you so, should all other arguments fail. Holland cannot afford to lose England's friendship now, your Honor. Spain is a rich and powerful country and could crush you out of existence, if England did not help you.

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER.
sp.p: Did you mention this point in your letter to the prince?

sp.speaker: AMBASSADOR.
sp.p: Yes, your Honor, I made it very clear.

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER.
sp.p: There may be by now a letter from his Highness. Your pardon-- I will inquire.
Have any letters come from the Prince of Orange?

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: One has just arrived by special post, your Honor.

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER.
sp.p: I would have it now.
sp.stage: (Exit Secretary: renters at once with a letter. Exit.)
sp.p: Your pardon, my lord.

Sir Dudley, the prince hath taken up your matter favorably. He desires me to have the press and type of William Brewster seized, and Brewster himself arrested. Furthermore, he is to be held in prison
until King James's pleasure be known concerning his disposal.

sp.speaker: AMBASSADOR.
sp.p: I shall report this to King James. His Majesty will take much pleasure in your prince's courtesy, sir.

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER.
sp.p: I will send an officer to Brewster's print-shop at once.

sp.speaker: AMBASSADOR.
sp.p: I thank your Honor in the name of my king. I wish you now good day.

div4.stage: (Bows.)

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER
sp.p: Good day, my lord.
sp.stage: (Exit Sir DUDLEY. Burgomaster sighs as he rings bell. Enter Secretary.)
sp.p: Send the bailiff to search William Brewster's house in the Puritan quarter,1 for a printing-press and type and books, and make out a warrant for the arrest of Master Brewster.

sp.speaker: SECRETARY
sp.p: Master Brewster!

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER.
sp.p: 'T was ordered by our prince, Jan.

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: I'll see to it, your Honor, at once. But I must say I regret it.

sp.speaker: BURGOMASTER.
sp.p: Not more than I, Jan-- not more than I.

div4.note: 1 The Puritans all lived in a certain part of Leyden. Their houses were clustered about the residence of Mr. Robinson, their pastor. Their chapel was in this residence.

div4.head: SCENE II

p.hi: PLACE: Leyden. Home of William Brewster in the Puritan quarter.

div4.stage: (The printing-shop is seen. BREWSTER sits at a rough table, reading freshly printed sheets. He is now past middle age and shows the effect of twelve years of worry and hardship. RALPH WEXTON is printing with a hand-press. Several Puritan boys are setting type. Puritan men are binding loose sheets into books and pamphlets. The old Beadle carries sheets from the press to BREWSTER, looking at each sheet with interest and pride; forgets himself; stops; reads sheet. BREWSTER waits for him; then speaks pleasantly.)

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Well, Beadle, doth it interest you?

sp.speaker: BEADLE
sp.p: Eh! Oh! I crave your pardon, Master Brewster. I forgot myself entirely.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: And do you approve what you read?

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: I do approve-- indeed I do! Be I not a Puritan now?

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Indeed you be, and a faithful.

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: Well, 'twas these writings that made me one. 'Twas reading these sheets day by day, as Ralph turned them out from the press there. They should convert all who read them, say I.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: That is their purpose, Beadle. I regret we had not this print-shop long ago, instead of but recently.

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: And I regret it too, Elder. 'T is said our Puritan friends in England were much pleased with your first batch of books.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: They were, indeed, and they are now spreading them secretly among the king's own churchmen.

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: May they convert all England, say I!

sp.speaker: BINDER.
sp.p: These pamphlets are finished, Master.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER
sp.p: And most skillfully done, too. Pack them at once. There's a ship sailing for England to-night.

sp.speaker: BINDER.
sp.p: Shall we pack them as we did the others?

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Yes. And conceal them well in the merchandise lest the king's officers find them. Address the package to Master Cathkin, London,-- just as you did the other. Let all the binders assist you, and those who are setting type.

sp.speaker: BINDER.
sp.p: It shall be done exactly.

div4.stage: (Crosses; speaks with other workers aside. They all go to a room, off. RALPH and Beadle continue work at press, and BREWSTER at desk. Enter from street WILLIAM BRADFORD, now a man of thirty years. He is grave-- anxious.)

sp.speaker: BREWSTER
sp.p:
Good day to you, Master Bradford!
Good day, Elder! I trust I am not disturbing you, sir, but I have brought you news of great importance.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: I do perceive you are troubled--

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: Our pastor hath just had letters from friends in England telling of Master Cathkin's arrest.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Master Cathkin's arrest!

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: The king's officers found out that Master Cathkin was receiving our books in London and giving them out secretly to others. So he hath been put in prison.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Oh, it doth grieve me to hear that! I will arrange to pay his fine in some way!

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: The king would not permit it, even if you could do so. His Majesty hath said openly that Master Cathkin shall suffer for this-- and, moreover, that you shall suffer with him.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: King James cannot touch me here. Holland would not permit it.

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: But Holland hath never as yet been tested. King James hath made no demand on her for the arrest of any Puritan.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: No, nor is he like to. He knows Holland will not betray us.

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: In spite of that I am troubled, and so is Master Robinson. Indeed, he would have come to you himself but Captain Standish called.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p:
There is no need of alarm for me.
Our whole thought should be directed now to the saving of Master Cathkin. We must contrive his escape from England.

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: Aye, we might! I'll write our friends in Scrooby this night, to see if it can be arranged.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Say that he must come to Holland and that I will bear all expenses.

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: No, Elder, I will furnish all moneys. You have spent almost all your earnings in caring for our unfortunate brothers-- those who could not make a living here in Holland.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: We have all helped each other-- you as much as any.

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: Ah, but I have recently inherited property near Scrooby, and am now in a position to help Master Cathkin.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Well, then, William, do what you may. I'll not deny that I must count the pennies.

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: It hath been a hard twelve years for us all.
sp.stage: (Enter Mistress BREWSTER from an inner room. She, too, shows the effect of years of worry and hardship: is now anxious. BRADFORD bows.)
sp.p: Good day to you, Mistress Brewster--

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: Good day to you, Master Bradford!
I regret to interrupt, William, but our pastor has come. He says he must see you at once.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Ask him to come in, certainly.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: Enter, Master Robinson.

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: Hath Master Bradford told you?

sp.speaker: BREWSTER
sp.p: Aye, but you are needlessly alarmed, Master Robinson. I will continue to publish our Puritan books, and publish them in safety.

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: Nay, I am not so sure of that. Captain Standish hath just told me of a certain agreement that is now being made between England and Holland-- an agreement that will affect the safety of us all.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: This be news, indeed!

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: It seems there is some danger of a war between Holland and Spain within the next year or two. And England hath offered to aid Holland who hath accepted her terms. So now Holland must do aught that England commands-- even to the delivering up of a Puritan.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: I cannot think Holland would give us up.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Nay, nor can I, Mary.

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p:
A country will do acts in time of war that it would not do in peace. So we must prepare for the worst. Captain Standish hath gone now to
acquaint our brethren with these facts and to call them here to a meeting, as soon as they come home from work.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: 'T is well. Ralph, bid the binders and packers come and all who do assist them.

sp.speaker: RALPH.
sp.p: Aye, Elder, I will.

div4.stage: (Exit to room, off. Beadle, who has been listening, turns to ROBINSON.)

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: And do you think King James will make me go back to England, sir, and act as beadle in his church again?

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: He may compel us all to return, Beadle.

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: Oh, 't is a dreadful state of affairs! Is there no country in all the world where we may live in freedom?

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: There is no civilized country any where where we may worship as we choose, saving here in Holland. And that may soon be denied us.

div4.stage: (Enter RALPH, binders, packers, and boy assistants from packing-room. Enter JONATHAN BREWSTER from street with a dinner pail. He is now a rather delicate young man of twenty-seven.)

sp.speaker: JONATHAN.
sp.p: Father-- what is this I hear about your being in danger? Captain Miles Standish is telling all the Puritan workers as they come home from the weaving mills.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: I fear sad days are in store for us, son.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Our pastor will explain, Jonathan.

div4.stage: (Enter from street, many Puritan men and women of all ages. Among them are Master and Mistress CARVER and Master and Mistress WINSLOW. All are grave and quiet. Pause. ROBINSON faces them.)

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: My people, Captain Miles Standish hath told you of this new trouble that hath arisen for us in England's recent treaty with Holland, and you understand our danger. If King James sees fit, we may be all taken back to England and thrown into dungeons. Therefore, we must act quickly that we may escape this fate.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: King James hath most likely forgot us-- it hath been twelve years.

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: He hath only recently declared that Master Brewster should suffer with Master Cathkin because of our Puritan books.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: Then there is, indeed, great need of action with us. We cannot remain in Holland.

sp.speaker: WINSLOW.
sp.p: Unless we renounce our faith. And that, of course, we can never do.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: No, never! 'T was for that we came in poverty here and have endured so many hardships.

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: Aye!

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p:
Then we must leave Holland, my people. We have often spoken of this before, especially in our first years here. But always we gave up the thought. Now necessity compels it. We must go to
a land where our faith can be preserved from generation to generation. And that land, friends, as you know full well, is America.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS WINSLOW.
sp.p: But 't is a wilderness and inhabited by savages!

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: 'T is the only place where we may continue to worship as we will.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: And, besides, the opportunity is ours of converting the savages there to our belief.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: To spread our faith is ever our bounden duty.

div4.stage: (Murmurs of assent from others.)

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: I favor going to America as soon as ships can be got.

sp.speaker: WINSLOW.
sp.p: I favor it likewise, and urge it.

sp.speaker: FIRST MAN.
sp.p: I oppose it strongly. We have just begun to make fair wages here. We have our homes here-- we are able to care for our children. And it hath taken us twelve years to arrive at this point. Shall we leave all this and begin again the fight for merely enough to eat and to wear? I tell you, I oppose it!

sp.speaker: SECOND MAN.
sp.p: And I, sir, oppose it too! What can we do in a new land? We came very near to making an utter failure here.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: Ah, but the case is different. We were, nearly all of us, farmers in England, and we found the trade here was weaving.

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p:
And we found also, that we could not
compete with the skilled weavers here until we had years of experience. But in America we can be farmers again, and teach our sons to be farmers.

sp.speaker: THIRD MAN.
sp.p: But suppose they refuse to be farmers. They have gotten a taste of the sea here and many of them are sailors.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS CARVER.
sp.p: That is the pity of it! They are going away from us and forgetting their faith.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS WINSLOW.
sp.p: Our children are forgetting they are English. They speak the Dutch language-- they play the Dutch games-- they are begging to wear the Dutch dress.

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: And that is not the worst of it! On the last Sabbath day, I myself saw some of our Puritan boys go forth to join Dutch games. On the Sabbath, mind you-- the SABBATH!

sp.speaker: FIRST WOMAN.
sp.p: My boy ran away in spite of me.

sp.speaker: SECOND WOMAN.
sp.p: Many times I have followed and have brought mine home, but 't is a struggle I'm very weary of.

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: It hath, indeed, become a grave question-- this bringing up of our children in Puritan ways when customs around us are different. That alone would give us reason for leaving Holland were there not the other matter.

sp.speaker: FOURTH MAN.
sp.p:
But, Master, nothing hath really
happened as yet. 'Tis all conjecture with us. Methinks 't would be unwise to leave Holland till we know for a certainty that King James means to oppress us.

sp.speaker: THIRD WOMAN.
sp.p: So it seems to me--

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: And to me! To me! To me!

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: But we cannot combat a danger when it hath overthrown us.

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: No, indeed, we cannot.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: We should leave Holland as soon as we can make the necessary arrangements, friends. I am convinced of that.

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: And I! And I! And I!

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: No! No! No!

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: We can scarcely come to a decision so long as we are of such divergent opinions. But consider this, my people. The information came to us through Captain Miles Standish, who is known to you all as a man of the highest honor.

sp.speaker: FIRST MAN.
sp.p: But he is not a Puritan.

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: He frequently attends our church and is most friendly to us. Besides, being an English soldier stationed here in Leyden, he hath unusual means of obtaining information. And he hath advised us to leave Holland at once.

sp.speaker: WINSLOW.
sp.p: We should listen to Captain Standish, friends. He is not the man to speak lightly.

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: Aye!

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: I note that some of you are silent.

sp.speaker: THIRD MAN.
sp.p: I'll not agree to leave Holland till war is actually declared.

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: No! Nor I! Nor I!

stage.hi: (Knock at street door. JONATHAN opens door.)

sp.speaker: JONATHAN.
sp.p: Enter, Captain Standish!

div4.stage: (Enter Captain MILES STANDISH. He is short of stature but strongly built and athletic. He shows alarm.)

sp.speaker: STANDISH.
sp.p: Master Brewster-- the bailiff is coming this way with his men!

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Hath he entered this street?

sp.speaker: STANDISH.
sp.p: Not as yet, but he is in the Puritan quarter, and that in itself is strange, for no bailiff is ever needed here. I fear it means trouble for some of you.

sp.speaker: JONATHAN.
sp.p: I'll watch in the garden and warn you if they enter.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: I fear they come for you, William!

sp.speaker: STANDISH.
sp.p: I would advise you to escape, sir.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER
sp.p: I beg you to hide! Come, enter this closet! Quick!

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: I beg you to take no chances!

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: If they come for me they will search the house, so there is no safety in hiding.

sp.speaker: JONATHAN.
sp.p:
The bailiff hath stopped at our gate!
I heard him giving directions to his men. And he spoke your name, father! I am certain he comes for you. Hide-- quick-- quick!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER
sp.p: Come, William, for my sake!

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Well, then, to please you, I will.

div4.stage: (Enters closet. Mistress BREWSTER closes door: stands in front of it. Knock is repeated. JONATHAN opens street door. Enter Bailiff and two Deputies.)

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Doth not William Brewster reside here?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN.
sp.p: He doth.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: I have a warrant for his arrest. Step forth, William Brewster!
William Brewster, I command you to declare yourself.
Then I must take you by force.
Come along, Master! And you need not deny you are Brewster. I knew you from the first, sir.
Now, where are your Puritan books and pamphlets? I have been ordered to take them, but I see none of them about.

stage.hi: (RALPH is silent. Bailiff turns to his Deputies.)

sp.p: Search the house for these books, men, and bring them to me-- all you find.
Come, Master Brewster, your hat and cloak.

div4.stage: (Enter Deputies with books and pamphlets. RALPH getting hat and cloak.)

sp.speaker: FIRST DEPUTY.
sp.p: We have them, Master Bailiff! They were packed in merchandise.

sp.speaker: SECOND DEPUTY.
sp.p: They'll make good witnesses, Master.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Bring them all. Come now, Master Printer!

div4.stage: (He goes with RALPH. Deputies follow with books. JONATHAN closes street door and bolts it. Mistress BREWSTER opens door to closet.)

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: They have gone, William.

sp.speaker: BEADLE
sp.p: The bailiff mistook my son for you.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: I know. I could hear plainly all that passed. I think he will be discharged as soon as the Burgomaster sees him, but if he is not, I will give myself up, of course.

sp.speaker: STANDISH.
sp.p: Nothing will be done till morning. The Burgomaster hath left his office now for the night.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: We must contrive a way to hide Elder Brewster among us, friends.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Yes-- yes!

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: That might succeed for a time, but it cannot continue indefinitely. The bailiff will find me sooner or later.

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: I fear he will, Elder. Do you not see now, my people, that the very thing some of you thought unlikely but a moment ago hath come to pass? The blow hath fallen. We are as completely in King James's power as if we were in England. No one of us is safe. Shall we wait, then, for other calamities to befall? Speak, all you who objected to our removal from this land. Are you of the same mind still?

sp.speaker: FIRST MAN.
sp.p: I withdraw my objection. I see now that we must, indeed, leave Holland, if we would continue to practice our faith.

sp.speaker: SECOND MAN.
sp.p: Aye, we must. Mine eyes be opened now.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: And mine! And mine!

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p: Do you all, then, consent to go to America?

sp.speaker: ALL OTHERS.
sp.p: Aye! We do! We do!

sp.speaker: ROBINSON.
sp.p:
So be it, then,-- we will go. It only remains now for us to put our savings together that we may obtain a ship and stores. Then we will again go forth from our homes with little save what we can carry in our hands-- just as we did from Scrooby. Again we will become Pilgrims, but ever with the same desires-- that we may have freedom in our religion, and that our children, and our children's children, and their descendants in the years to come, may continue our faith and worship in peace and security. My people, let us
pray together now that God may bless our new pilgrimage.

div3.head: ACT II

p.hi: PLACE: On board the ship Mayflower.

div3.stage: (Captain JONES and the First Mate are seen on deck, looking out into distance.)

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: 'T is land, Mate, or mine eyes do deceive me.

sp.speaker: MATE.
sp.p: Aye, Captain, 't is land! 'T is shadowy as yet, but 't is land.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Say naught to the passengers. Wait till it can be clearly seen.

sp.speaker: MATE.
sp.p: Aye, sir.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Tell the pilot I would speak with him. You may relieve him at the wheel.
Well, Pilot, here's land at last. And 't is the shore of America.

sp.speaker: PILOT.
sp.p: There's no doubt of that, sir.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: The time hath come, then, to work our plans; that is, if you be still certain of the matters you but recently told me.

sp.speaker: PILOT.
sp.p: I had my information from fishermen who have sailed this way. And each declared the country here abounded with gold mines, which we could buy from the savages for a string or two of beads.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Perhaps gold mines will be found also to the south in Virginia, whither these Puritans are going.

sp.speaker: PILOT.
sp.p: Nay, 't was just here, they said, in exactly this location.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: 'T is a thought that dazzles my brain! Gold mines! Why, 't will make us as rich as King James!

sp.speaker: PILOT.
sp.p: And forget not the wondrous Indian city, with its streets of gold and its jeweled towers. The fishermen said it was beautiful beyond anything seen by mortals.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: 'T would be pitiful to pass it by. Are the sailors with us?

sp.speaker: PILOT.
sp.p: To a man. They talk of the gold mines constantly and of the riches they will win. It would be hard to persuade them to sail past this point.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: We might land these Puritans here whether they would or no.

sp.speaker: PILOT.
sp.p: The sailors are urging that, Captain.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: But the Puritans are well armed and outnumber our crew.

sp.speaker: PILOT.
sp.p: I believe we can count on certain Puritans themselves, sir.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Why, how is that?

sp.speaker: PILOT.
sp.p: I have just learned, from one of the crew, that there are at least a dozen men here pretending to be Puritans who are not such at all. They came aboard at the last moment when the ship touched at the English port. And now they are planning to overthrow the Puritans as soon as they have landed, and imprison William Brewster and the other Puritan elders.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: They were, no doubt, sent by certain enemies of the Puritans in England.

sp.speaker: PILOT.
sp.p: No doubt. But we can count on them, sir. Indeed, I have caused reports of gold to be spread secretly among them. And now they be talking among themselves in low tones and whispers.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: 'T is a good sign.

sp.speaker: PILOT.
sp.p: Then land these Puritans here, Captain. I can complain to them of the shoals to the south. Every pilot who ever came to this land hath reported them as rough.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: They could be avoided by sailing out to sea.

sp.speaker: PILOT.
sp.p: 'T is true, but that need not be spoken. These Puritans are not seamen.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Well, I will suggest that they land here. If they refuse, we might seem to comply and sail on into the shoals a bit.

sp.speaker: PILOT.
sp.p: And then turn back?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Yes, with excuses of the water. Call the passengers now, from below.

sp.speaker: PILOT
sp.p: Land ho! Land ho!

sp.speaker: MATE
sp.p: Land ho! Land ho!

div3.stage: (Enter Puritan men, women, children, excited, and calling out joyously.)

sp.speaker: PURITANS.
sp.p: Land! Land! Land!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: America lies before you, friends!

sp.speaker: FIRST WOMAN.
sp.p: Oh, it is a welcome sight!

sp.speaker: FIRST MAN.
sp.p: It gladdens mine eyes!

sp.speaker: SECOND MAN.
sp.p: And mine!

sp.speaker: SECOND WOMAN.
sp.p: I have prayed these many weeks to behold it.

sp.speaker: THIRD WOMAN.
sp.p: So have we all, sister. Three long months on the water!

sp.speaker: SECOND MAN.
sp.p: Three long months of hardship and storm!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS WINSLOW.
sp.p: We can forget that now in the peace of land.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: 'T will bring happiness to those who lie below ill, and weakened with the voyage.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS WINSLOW.
sp.p: Aye, it will.

div3.stage: (Women and men talk aside, looking and pointing to shore.)

sp.speaker: FIRST GIRL.
sp.p: It seems a lonesome place to me-- 't is not like Holland at all.

sp.speaker: SECOND GIRL.
sp.p: I hope the savages will not kill us the moment of our landing.

sp.speaker: FIRST BOY
sp.p: No one of us may know that till later.

sp.speaker: SECOND BOY.
sp.p: 'T is certain to be full of wild beasts.

sp.speaker: THIRD BOY.
sp.p: So be it. We came here to suffer willingly.

sp.speaker: CHILDREN
sp.p: Aye!

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: A welcome sight it is, friends, but 't is not our destination.
According to your chart below, we are much to the north of our lands in Virginia.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: 'T is true, we are to the north, Elder, but the water is deep and quiet here. 'T is a suitable place for landing.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p:
Nay, 't is most unsuitable. Here, it is even now cold and wintry. We can plant nothing
till next spring. To the south, we may yet plant and harvest a crop.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: But there are shoals to the south. The pilot was just warning me.

sp.speaker: PILOT.
sp.p: Every pilot who hath sailed this way hath reported them as dangerous.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: 'T would be cruel to take your sick into such rough seas.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: 'T would be more cruel to let all die of starvation here. We have about exhausted our stores from being so long on our voyage. On what, then, are we to subsist this winter? I do not see how we can land here. What say you, brothers?

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: I agree with you, Elder.

sp.speaker: WINSLOW.
sp.p: And I!

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: And I!

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: And I! And I!

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: You will sail on to Virginia, Captain.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: I like it not, but to please you we'll try the shoals. To the southward, Pilot!
Explain to the crew that we mean to turn back.

div3.stage: (Pilot nods and goes. Sailors go with ugly looks at Puritans.)

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: How happy 't would make our pastor to know we had crossed the waters safely!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS CARVER.
sp.p: I would he were with us this day.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS WINSLOW.
sp.p: He longed to come, I know, but he thought it his duty to stay in Leyden with those who were obliged to remain because of sickness or poverty.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BRADFORD.
sp.p: But they will all join us later. That is a pleasant thought to hold.

div3.stage: (Others murmur assent.)

sp.speaker: DR. FULLER.
sp.p: Brethren, the wind blows cold. 'T would be better to go below, methinks.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: It would, Doctor; so many are weak from illness during the voyage.

div3.stage: (As they go, the First Conspirator crosses to Second Conspirator and speaks with him aside.)

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: Call our men together. I have a plan to propose.

sp.speaker: SECOND CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: I'll whisper them now.

div3.stage: (He goes about, whispering to this man and that. All Puritans go but some twelve men, who wear Puritan dress but who seem far below the others in intelligence and worth. They gather around First Conspirator.)

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: Men-- hark! The time hath come for us to act and take things into our own hands. No longer do we need to keep up this pretense of being Puritans like the rest. We can come out boldly now and snap our fingers at them.

sp.speaker: THIRD CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: Methought we had agreed to wait till we were safely landed and had roofs over our heads.

sp.speaker: FOURTH CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: Aye, and 't was agreed to by all.

sp.speaker: FIFTH CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: Should we come out now against them, we would find ourselves in irons. We are only a handful-- they have some fifty men.

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: Be patient till I explain. Their grant of land lies to the south in Virginia. Therefore, they cannot set up their Puritan government here, for here they have no title.

sp.speaker: SIXTH CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: Why, and so they have not! This land belongs to any one! Any one who will claim it.

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: Aye, indeed! And so we must force them to land here. Remember we are to have a handsome sum of money from their enemies in England as soon as we succeed in overthrowing them and imprisoning their leaders.

sp.speaker: SECOND CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: Besides, 't will give us the chance of holding these gold mines for ourselves.

sp.speaker: FIFTH CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: That is all very well, but on what shall we live in the mean time?

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: We will compel the Indians to give us food.

div3.stage: (Murmurs of assent from others.)

sp.speaker: FOURTH CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: But how can we force the Puritans to land here? Have you a plan for that?

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: Why, we can pretend the shoals to the south are not safe for the sick.

sp.speaker: SECOND CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: 'T is a very good plan. We can make a strong case to the Captain.

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSPIRATORhi>.
sp.p: Do you all consent?

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Aye! We do! We do!

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: Then come. We'll go to the Captain at once!

div3.stage: (They go. Pause. Enter BREWSTER; paces deck; shows he is deeply troubled. Enter Dr. FULLER with medicine case; crosses quickly.)

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: One moment, Doctor Fuller-- I would speak with you.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR.
sp.p: I have only a minute, Elder--

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: How be our sick? Tell me frankly, Doctor.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR.
sp.p: 'Tis bad with them, Elder. Some lie very low, indeed.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Is there any hope?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR.
sp.p: Very little, if this rough voyage continues.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Would it be better for them to land at once?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR.
sp.p: If they could be cared for ashore, it would. We are likely to have more storms in these shoals, and then the cabin must be shut tight-- no fresh air can enter. And 't is lack of air during the storms, that hath made them ill in the first place.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: 'T is a dreadful situation!

sp.speaker: DOCTOR.
sp.p: I will speak with you anon, Elder. I am now on my way to a patient.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Master Brewster, I have sent for all your men. There are certain things I have to say.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER
sp.p: Why, what hath happened, Captain?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Puritans, I feel it my duty to tell you that some of your number are dissatisfied. Indeed, many have come to me privately to complain of this sailing south. They urge the condition of the sick, who may not survive the rough waters of the shoals.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Cannot these shoals be avoided by sailing out to sea some miles?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Well-- that might be done, but 't would take too long a time-- and my sailors are impatient.

sp.speaker: FIRST SAILOR.
sp.p: Land them here, Captain! Put them off with their goods and let them shift for themselves.

sp.speaker: OTHER SAILORS.
sp.p: Aye! Aye!

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: That would be outrageous! You must not leave us till we have built a house, or at least a roof to shelter our sick.

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: Some desire to land here in spite of Master Brewster.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: What is that? You say you desire to land here ! Don't you realize we are likely to starve?

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: We can trade with the Indians for food.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: But suppose they are hostile to us?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: That was the risk you took when you came. I tell you, sirs, I will land you here. You can make your plans accordingly.

div3.stage: (Exit. Sailors go, pleased.)

sp.speaker: STANDISH.
sp.p: Shall we submit to this, Elder?

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: We are so encompassed with difficulties, I see nothing else but to yield.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: 'T is all we can do, brother.

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: Have you thought of this-- that, having no grant to this land, you have no right to set up any laws or government here?

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Then, sirs, we will make an agreement, which shall serve in place of a grant. This agreement will give to every man a voice in the government. of our colony, and will provide that none amongst us shall be supreme, and that all of us are equals. Do you approve of this, brothers? 'T is a thing we have often discussed.

sp.speaker: PURITANS.
sp.p: Yes-- yes! I approve! I approve!

div3.stage: (Conspirators are silent. BREWSTER looks at them keenly.)

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Will you draw up this agreement, Master Carver?

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: I will, and gladly. I will prepare the paper at once.

sp.speaker: BEADLE.
sp.p: I'll sign, I will! Did you hear that, Ralph? All men here are equals--

sp.speaker: RALPH.
sp.p: 'T is our Puritan belief, father.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: The paper will soon be ready to sign. So go you now to the cabin, friends.

div3.stage: (All go but BREWSTER, STANDISH, and conspirators. BREWSTER turns to them.)

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Why do you not go below to sign?

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: I do not mean to sign it.

sp.speaker: SECOND CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: No, nor I!

sp.speaker: OTHER CONSPIRATORS.
sp.p: Nor I! Nor I! Nor I!

div3.stage: (Enter Captain JONES.)

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: We have anchored, Masters, and a boat is ready to take any ashore.

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: We'll go, captain, at once.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Nay, but you will not!

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: You have no right to give orders here. We'll go ashore if we choose.

sp.speaker: OTHER CONSPIRATORS.
sp.p: Aye! We will-- We will!

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Call our men, Captain Standish.
sp.stage: (Exit STANDISH. BREWSTER turns to the conspirators.)
sp.p: We have suspected you from the first, and are fully prepared to deal with you. You think you can harass and embarrass our plans, but you shall not. Captain Jones, not a man will leave this ship till all have signed the agreement. Furthermore, we will enforce this request. Our men are ready with muskets, and are fully prepared for revolt.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: 'T is well. No one shall leave till you speak the word.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Now, will you sign or no?

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSPIRATOR.
sp.p: What if we refuse, sir?

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: We will seize you and put you in irons.

div3.stage: (Conspirators go, sullenly, followed by Puritans with muskets. BREWSTER is alone. He sighs and stands looking to land. Enter Mistress BREWSTER; crosses to him.)

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: 'T is a beautiful land, this America!

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: 'T is very beautiful, Mary.

stage.hi: (Pause. Mistress BREWSTER looks at him keenly.)

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: You do seem dispirited, William.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Only for the moment. In my heart I rejoice that we came. I feel certain that we shall prosper here and that our faith shall live triumphant.

sp.speaker: MARY.
sp.p: I pray God that it may be so.

div4.head: SCENE I
div4.stage: (The narrow street is seen leading to gate of palisade, which is made of saplings. On both sides of street are log houses. A few children play quietly in the small dooryards. RALPH WEXTON is on guard at gate which is open, showing the forest beyond. A Puritan woman comes from house on right and crosses to gate. She carries an empty water pail. A second Puritan woman enters gate from forest; carries pail filled with water.)

sp.speaker: FIRST WOMAN.
sp.p: I give you good morrow, Mistress.

sp.speaker: SECOND WOMAN.
sp.p: Good morrow to you, Mistress. You go to the spring?

sp.speaker: FIRST WOMAN.
sp.p: Aye, and you have been there before me. I thought to be first,-- 't is so early.

sp.speaker: SECOND WOMAN.
sp.p: I must rise early these days,-- there is so much work to do.

sp.speaker: FIRST WOMAN.
sp.p: With so many sick, there is double work for us all.

sp.speaker: SECOND WOMAN.
sp.p: Doctor Fuller hath just told me that the worst of the sickness is over. I saw him as he passed by this morning, from watching in the hospital house.

sp.speaker: FIRST WOMAN.
sp.p: He hath been a devoted nurse.

sp.speaker: SECOND WOMAN.
sp.p: And so hath Elder Brewster and Captain Standish. No woman could have done better.

sp.speaker: FIRST WOMAN.
sp.p: 'T is strange all the women were taken so ill. There are scarcely half of us left.

sp.speaker: SECOND WOMAN.
sp.p: And not more than half of the men.

sp.speaker: FIRST WOMAN.
sp.p: 'T is God's mercy that any live. It seemed, for a time, that all of us would die of starvation in those terrible winter months.

sp.speaker: SECOND WOMAN.
sp.p: And so we would, had it not been for the corn our men found, hidden in the ground by Indians.

sp.speaker: FIRST WOMAN.
sp.p: 'Twas that alone that saved us. And now the game hath come back to the woods, and the spring air hath revived us.

sp.speaker: SECOND WOMAN.
sp.p: Aye, the worst is surely over.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: I come to see Governor Carver.

sp.speaker: GUARD.
sp.p: He hath gone to the fields to work, Captain Jones.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Hath Elder Brewster also gone?

sp.speaker: GUARD.
sp.p: Nay, he is nursing the sick.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Where will I find him at this hour?

sp.speaker: SECOND WOMAN.
sp.p: I know, Captain. I will tell him you have come.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: I thank you, Mistress.
sp.stage: (Exit second woman up street. First woman passes through gate into forest. Other women and girls now appear and pass through gate with their water pails. Boys pass through and return with wood for fire. Captain turns to RALPH.)
sp.p: How is your good father, the beadle?

sp.speaker: GUARD.
sp.p: He died, Captain, only recently.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: I am sorry to hear that, Master Wexton.

sp.speaker: GUARD.
sp.p: This climate was too cold for him, after being weakened with the voyage.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: That hath seemed the trouble with all. And is it not strange that those who plotted to overthrow all law and order were taken among the first!

sp.speaker: GUARD.
sp.p: Of them all not one remains. But the good and useful were taken, too.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: And I have lost almost half of my crew.

sp.speaker: GUARD.
sp.p: It hath been a terrible sickness.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Good morrow, Captain. I have sent your message to Governor Carver, who will no doubt come to see you.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: I thank you, Master Brewster.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: How fare your sick sailors?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Many are well now, and the others are much better. They one and all send their thanks to you and yours for the kindness you have shown them. You have nursed my men and brought many back to life and health. We are all most grateful to you.

div4.stage: (Enter Governor CARVER from forest. He carries a musket.)

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: You wished to see me, Captain?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p:
Aye, Governor Carver. I wish your
permission to return to England with the Mayflower. 'T is the first day in all these months I have felt that my crew was able to sail.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: You have, indeed, had a grievous time, and I would we could grant your request. But we cannot, just at present. Indeed, we may need the ship as a refuge-- we fear the Indians will attack us.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: Why-- how is that? Methinks they would have attacked you long ago, if such had been their purpose.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: We cannot guess their purpose. They come not to trade, nor to hold any discourse with us. Of late they lurk about, but disappear if we approach. Recently, some appeared on yon hill and made threatening gestures to us. So now we go armed to the fields and keep a guard here constantly.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: They run from my sailors, who have been exploring the coast for gold mines.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: Have you found any gold?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: No, nor any trace. We have given it up entirely.

div4.stage: (Enter BRADFORD from forest, running. He carries a musket.)

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: An Indian comes! All in the fields did see him. And no other did we see but one.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: It may be a trick-- to put us off our guard. Ralph, give the signal to call all in from the fields and spring.
sp.stage: (RALPH fires into air. Enter women and children from cabins. Enter women and children from forest. Enter men from forest with muskets. Enter Dr. FULLER and STANDISH from a cabin.)
sp.p: An Indian comes! Men, have your muskets ready. 'T is the first visitor we have had from them-- we must be prepared for treachery.

sp.speaker: RALPH
sp.p: He comes!

div4.stage: (Pause. An Indian brave, SAMOSET, appears at gate; looks about; enters and lays his bow and arrows upon ground. He then holds out his hands in welcome.)

sp.speaker: SAMOSET.
sp.p: Welcome-- Englishmen--

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: Why-- you speak English!

sp.speaker: SAMOSET.
sp.p: English fishermen here before. Me call Samoset.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: We are your friends, Samoset. We have not come here to harm your people. We wish to be friends with them.

sp.speaker: SAMOSET.
sp.p: 'T is well. Massasoit come to see you. Massasoit great chief-
Massasoit near-- he come soon-- to-day.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: Comes he for peace or war?

sp.speaker: SAMOSET.
sp.p: Massasoit come to see white chief-- come here to your wigwam.

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: Come his warriors with him?

sp.speaker: SAMOSET.
sp.p: Massasoit come with braves. See--

sp.speaker: BREWSTER
sp.p: Forty braves! They could easily overpower us-- with so many of our number sick.

sp.speaker: CARVER
sp.p: We dare not re fuse to see them, but we can ask them to enter unarmed.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: By all means!

sp.speaker: CARVER
sp.p: Tell Massasoit that we are his brothers. Tell him we will welcome him and his followers here, and that we will make a treaty with him-- a treaty that will be just to the Indians. Do you understand, Samoset?

sp.speaker: SAMOSET.
sp.p: Samoset know-- good treaty-- Samoset tell Massasoit.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: And tell him that we will pay him for the corn we found hidden in a mound. We were starving, and obliged to take it. But we will make amends.

sp.speaker: SAMOSET.
sp.p: Samoset tell Massasoit--

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: Tell your chief one thing more-- If he and his braves will come unarmed, we will lay down our arms likewise.

sp.speaker: SAMOSET.
sp.p: 'T is well-- Massasoit wait by brook. Englishmen-- good-bye.

sp.speaker: STANDISH.
sp.p: The brook is near. They will be here within a few minutes.

sp.speaker: DR. FULLER.
sp.p: We should use every means in our power to make a friend of this chief. Our safety depends upon it.

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: We must make a treaty that will please him. I would suggest that we draw up a set of rules to govern all trading between Indians and whites.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Yes-- yes!

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: I will appoint you, Masters Bradford, Brewster, and Winslow, to draw up this treaty at once, with rules such as Master Bradford suggested.

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Come to my cabin, Masters.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN JONES.
sp.p: 'T would be well to present this chief with some finery. Think you not so, Governor?

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: I do, indeed. 'T will please him mightily.

sp.speaker: DR. FULLER.
sp.p: I have a fancy coat that belonged to an English officer. 'T is bright red, and 't is trimmed with gilt buttons and lace.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: Fetch it to me, Doctor. I will present it with ceremony.
And I, as governor, should appear in state, with drummer and with trumpet.
