And then we will conduct our guests to the new cabin being built. It lacks only the doors and roof. We can call it our council hall.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Yes-- yes--

sp.speaker: MISTRESS BREWSTER.
sp.p: I'll fetch a rug and cushions for the chief to sit upon.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS CARVER.
sp.p: And I will fetch some meat for him.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS WINSLOW.
sp.p: And I will fetch some fruit.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: Why, then, we will have a feast for the chief. But we cannot feed the warriors-- there is not enough food in Plymouth.
Captain Standish, have your men ready. Fire at the first sign of treachery. If, however, they lay down their arms, receive them with military honors.

sp.speaker: STANDISH.
sp.p: We will watch them, Governor.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: Come, friends, let us prepare!

div4.stage: (All go but children and STANDISH and his men. These the Captain forms in two lines on either side of gate.)

sp.speaker: RALPHM
sp.p: They come, Captain! Look-- there at the border of the woods!

sp.speaker: STANDISH
sp.p: Aye! They are laying their bows and arrows down! Go, Ralph, tell the Governor! Stack your muskets, men!

div4.stage: (Exit RALPH up street. Men stack muskets. Pause. Enter SAMOSET.)

sp.speaker: SAMOSET.
sp.p: Massasoit here-- Englishmen!

div4.stage:
(Pause. Enter MASSASOIT and forty braves. STANDISH and men salute them. A drum and a trumpet heard of in village. Enter Governor CARVER, preceded by the drummer and trumpeter.
Puritans follow. Governor CARVER bows to MASSASOIT, who bears himself with great dignity.)

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: Great Chief, we salute you. We welcome you with open arms, and present you our love and greetings.

div4.stage: (SAMOSET mutters a few words to MASSASOIT, who nods head gravely and mutters to SAMOSET.)

sp.speaker: SAMOSET.
sp.p: Massasoit say 't is well-- Massasoit greet white chief.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: Will the great chief come now to our council hall? We would discuss a treaty of peace that shall last as long as we live in this land.

div4.stage: (SAMOSET speaks with MASSASOIT in Indian language as before.)

sp.speaker: SAMOSET.
sp.p: Massasoit say 't is well-- he counsel with white chief.

div4.stage: (CARVER motions to drummer and trumpeter to play, and the procession starts up street; CARVER walking with MASSASOIT. Others follow.)

div4.head: SCENE II
div4.stage:
(No one is seen except guard at gate-- RALPH WEXTON. Pause. Drum and trumpet heard of. Enter Captain STANDISH and his men marching. They form in two lines on either side of gate.
"WILL THE GREAT CHIEF COME NOW TO OUR COUNCIL HALL?"
Enter drummer and trumpeter playing. Enter Governor CARVER and MASSASOIT, who wears his red coat proudly. Enter leadiny Puritans and SAMOSET. Enter Indian braves-- then all Puritans-- men, women, children.)

sp.speaker: CARVER
sp.p: Tell Massasoit we wish him to come again.

sp.speaker: SAMOSET.
sp.p: Massasoit come again-- he pleased-- say white chief his brother.

div4.p: Massasoit say he hope treaty last--

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: 'T is our hope, too, Samoset. And we will keep it (pointing to sky), as there is a God in Heaven.

div4.stage: (SAMOSET translates to MASSASOIT, who nods and speaks, also pointing to sky.)

sp.speaker: SAMOSET.
sp.p: Massasoit say Great Spirit watch over treaty. Massasoit say good-bye.

div4.stage: (CARVER bows to MASSASOIT, who makes a dignified and graceful motion of farewell. He goes,followed by SAMOSET and braves.)

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: Praise be to God that peace is made!

sp.speaker: WINSLOW.
sp.p: Aye, praises and thanksgiving!

sp.speaker: BRADFORD.
sp.p: The treaty is as fair to the Indian as to us, and I believe they realized it.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p:
'T is a thing, I think, to be proud of. And now, brothers, another matter must claim our
attention. Captain Jones wishes to return at once to England. What say you? Now that this peace hath been made, and that all our sick are better, is there any reason why we should keep the Mayflower here?

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: I know no reason for it.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Nor I! Nor I!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN JONES.
sp.p: Are you all willing, then, to let the ship return?

sp.speaker: ALL PURITANS.
sp.p: Aye!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN JONES.
sp.p: Your goodness to me hath made me loth to leave you here without the refuge of my ship. But I feel that I must return now.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: You may set sail, Captain, as soon as it pleases you. And bear our love to our friends at home.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: I will do so, Governor, and I will sail to-morrow. But 't is with the deepest regret I go. It saddens my heart to leave you here with only savages for neighbors. Do you not wish to return? I'll take any, or all of you gladly.

sp.speaker: CARVER.
sp.p: If any wish to go, they may, and with honor. No one of us knows what the future holds in store for us. At present, the Indians are friendly. How long will they remain so? We know life cannot be easy here. There will be both hardships and dangers. So, my friends, you have only to speak, and you shall return to England.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: 'T will be a fair journey back at this time of year, with no such storms as accompanied us.
Do you realize that the nearest white man is in Virginia-- five hundred miles to the south?

sp.speaker: BREWSTER.
sp.p: God hath brought us here to do his work. If we live, our faith will live. If we die, untimely, it may be some poor savage will then have our faith and convert his savage brothers. So, no matter what fate befall, we will give thanks to God with hearts full of joy that He hath permitted us to come to this land.

sp.speaker: PURITANS
sp.p: Amen!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: So be it, then. I shall tell all England that I left you singing your songs of joy. And now, farewell, my dear friends! May God protect and guide you! Farewell!

sp.speaker: PURITANS.
sp.p: Farewell! Farewell!

div4.p: On a great sweep of coast, stand a small group of Puritan men, women, and children-- not more than sixty in all. They are waving to the Mayflower, which is sailing out to sea.

div2.head:
THE BOSTON TEA PARTY
OR
DESCENDANTS OF THE PILGRIMS

div3.head: ACT I
div3.stage:
(An open square is seen with many leafless elm trees and shrubs. In center is a large elm that towers above them all. Opening into the square are several narrow streets with houses built close
together. Men, women, and children pass through square to church. Enter four girls with their Bibles. Enter a young man with placards. He crosses to large elm in center and tacks a placard to it. Church-goers stop; look at him astonished.)

sp.speaker: FIRST GIRL.
sp.p: Look! He is putting up a notice!

sp.speaker: SECOND GIRL.
sp.p: Has he forgot it is the Sabbath?

sp.speaker: THIRD GIRL.
sp.p: He must be a Tory. It is like them to commit such an unseemly act.

sp.speaker: FOURTH GIRL.
sp.p: They are announcing, perhaps, a parade of the king's troops to-day.

sp.speaker: THIRD GIRL.
sp.p: Who will march past our church to annoy us.

sp.speaker: FIRST GIRL.
sp.p: Just as they did recently, when they played Yankee Doodle outside, during an entire service.

sp.speaker: FOURTH GIRL.
sp.p: Well, we need not read their placard. If we take this path to the right, we will not even pass it.

div3.stage: (They turn away from tree. Young man with placards has now finished his work: starts off; overtakes girls.)

sp.speaker: YOUNG MAN
sp.p: Have you read the placard?

sp.speaker: SECOND GIRL
sp.p: No, and we do not care to read it.

sp.speaker: FOURTH GIRL
sp.p: We do not read Tory notices.

sp.speaker: YOUNG MAN.
sp.p: It is not a Tory notice! The tea is coming!

sp.speaker: GIRLS
sp.p: Tea!

sp.speaker: YOUNG MAN.
sp.p: Tea. The Patriots are calling a meeting. The placard there on that old elm tree will tell you all about it.

div3.stage: (Exit. Girls run to tree. Others hasten to tree from all parts of square. All read placard.)

sp.speaker: FIRST CITIZEN
sp.p: Do you see that? It is indeed the hour of our destruction!

sp.speaker: SECOND CITIZEN.
sp.p: It is an insult to every Patriot in this land!

sp.speaker: THIRD CITIZEN.
sp.p: We should rise as one man to defend our rights!

div3.stage: (Cries of "Yes-- yes-- we should-- we should!")

sp.speaker: OLD LADY.
sp.p: Will some one please read it for me? I have forgotten my glasses.

sp.speaker: FOURTH CITIZEN
sp.p: "Friends! Brethren! Countrymen! That worst of plagues, the detested Tea shipped for this port from England, is about to arrive in the harbor. The hour of Destruction stares you now in the face! Every friend to his Country, to Himself, and to Posterity is now called upon to meet in the square when the town crier shall ring his bell-- to make united resistance to this last and worst of the king's oppressions."

sp.speaker: OLD LADY.
sp.p: Well, I for one, shall drink none of that tea.

sp.speaker: FIFTH CITIZEN.
sp.p: I doubt if you'll have a chance, Mistress. Mr. Samuel Adams has declared it shall never be unloaded here in Boston.

sp.speaker: OLD LADY.
sp.p: A blessing on Samuel Adams! He is a Patriot through and through!

sp.speaker: SIXTH CITIZEN.
sp.p: A nobler man has never lived.

sp.speaker: SEVENTH CITIZEN.
sp.p: No, nor a more intelligent. He is a keen politician, too,-- no man in this country is shrewder.

sp.speaker: EIGHTH CITIZEN.
sp.p: It is said Governor Hutchinson offered him a large sum of money to forsake us in this quarrel and go over to the Tories.

sp.speaker: NINTH CITIZEN.
sp.p: It is true. It happened only yesterday. And Mr. Adams refused him with scorn.

sp.speaker: TENTH CITIZEN.
sp.p: The governor is a Tory, and is a mere tool for King George. He has no sympathy for us.

sp.speaker: ELEVENTH CITIZEN.
sp.p: He has said the tea shall be landed.

sp.speaker: TWELFTH CITIZEN.
sp.p: We shall soon see who will win-- the governor or Mr. Adams. The first tea-ship will be in to-day.

stage.hi: (A hand bell is heard of in distance.)

sp.speaker: A BOY.
sp.p: It is the town crier! I saw him in another place.

sp.speaker: OLD LADY.
sp.p: He comes this way!

div3.stage: (Bell heard just off. Enter the Crier ringing hand bell. Stops ringing ; calls out--)

sp.speaker: CRIER.
sp.p: Hark ye, citizens! The dreaded ships are coming! One ship has been sighted! So come you now to the old elm tree! Come, if you be Patriots!

div3.stage: (Exit, ringing bell. Enter many men, women, and young people of all ages and classes.)

sp.speaker: FIRST CITIZEN.
sp.p: Look you! Mr. Samuel Adams is coming!

div3.stage: (Enter SAMUEL ADAMS. He is accompanied by DR. WARREN, JOHN ADAMS, JOSIAH QUINCY, and other men of prominence. All are men of unusual intelligence, and of noble and dignified demeanor. They cross to elm in center. Enter other citizens, till square is packed. SAMUEL ADAMS steps forward; lifts hand. There is instant silence.)

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: Brothers-- countrymen! We have not forgot it is the Sabbath day, but for once we must lay our Puritan scruples aside. As that placard told you-- the hour of the destruction of our liberties is indeed at hand. The first ship bearing the taxed tea will be in our harbor to-day. Two other such ships will arrive by to-morrow. Is it not time then, that we should come to some agreement, despite this holy day?

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: Yes-- yes! We should! We should!

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p:
We must prepare ourselves for action. Long have we talked of this fatal day-- when the first tea-ship should come. Many meetings have we held, and this committee (indicating
men with him), appointed by the Patriots of Boston, has waited again upon Governor Hutchinson. And again has his Excellency advised us to receive the tea.

Long ago, when first we knew that a tax had been placed on our tea by King George and his obedient Parliament, we declared such a tax unjust to us. But, despite our protests, England has not only willfully fixed this tax, but has sent us tea, as if she would compel us to take it.

His Majesty evidently does not think we can be in earnest when we say we will not pay taxes to the English government unless we can be represented in that government. For many years have we petitioned King George to allow us a representative in Parliament, but this the king persistently refuses. Indeed, he has openly declared that his American subjects shall be taxed at his will, and that they shall have nothing to say in regard to their own government.

For many years England has taxed us heavily. Beginning with 1764, we were required to pay, yearly, large sums of money into the royal treasury. And that, in spite of our enfeebled condition brought upon us by England herself, through the long war she waged on this land against her enemy, the
French. You know how we came to England's aid in that war. You know how heavily we taxed ourselves, and gave men, money, and provisions. One million pounds were given by this State alone. And the flower of our youth went forth to their death. Does that spell disloyalty to our mother country, friends?

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: No! No!

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: No, we were never disloyal. In deed, I think we pride ourselves on being descendants of Englishmen. No one of us forgets that our forefathers were Englishmen, and came here to establish English life in the wilderness. We were brought up with the love of England in our hearts. And how have we been requited? Our free commerce with other lands has been suppressed-- we must now trade only with England. Our homes can be entered and searched by her agents at any time, and we have no power to prevent it. Our grievances are so many indeed, that I will not attempt to repeat them. You know them all too well. Our courteous petitions asking for a voice in Parliament have been answered by insulting royal orders. His Majesty, who should have been deeply interested in our welfare, commanded us to cease our public meetings. We were prohibited even the right of free speech! We-- free men-- were treated as slaves!

English soldiers were sent here to compel our obedience, and to insult us by their presence. They are a constant reminder that we are only hirelings to fill the king's treasure box. Why, even the English chimney-sweeps speak of us as "their subjects." And now comes this last wrong to us! To be sure the tax is small, and the tea with the tax will not cost us as much as we are paying now for the tea we buy from Holland. But that is not the question.

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: No! No! It is not!

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: The question is the principle at stake. Shall we suffer ourselves to be taxed without representation in Parliament? What say you, my countrymen? What say you?

sp.speaker: PEOPLE.
sp.p: NO! NO! NO!

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: Are there any here who disagree with us?

sp.speaker: TORY.
sp.p: We should obey our king, no matter what he orders.

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: Tory! Tory!

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: And why, pray, should we obey a king so slavishly? No civilized nation does so to-day. England, herself, has her Parliament, which very often opposes the ruling monarch.

sp.speaker: TORY.
sp.p: Ah, but that is different. Parliament is composed of Englishmen. We are only Colonists.

div3.stage: (Indignant murmurs from many.)

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: I fail to see the difference, sir. We are entitled to the same consideration from King George as his subjects who are living in England.

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: Yes! Yes! We are! We are!

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: Then, friends, we must now, for once and all, stand firm to our principle. This must be the hour of our revolt. Indeed, if we submit now, we need never more raise a voice in protest. That tea must not be landed!

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: No! No!

sp.speaker: FIRST CITIZEN.
sp.p: But how can we prevent it, Mr. Adams? Governor Hutchinson has declared he will stand by the king and regard the tax as legal.

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: I will ask the members of my committee to answer that and any other question. Dr. Warren--

sp.speaker: DR. WARREN.
sp.p: Our governor now shows a curious desire to be out of this quarrel entirely. He left yesterday for his summer home in the country. And this is the month of December!

sp.speaker: SECOND ITIZEN.
sp.p: Where are the consignees who were appointed by King George to receive the tea? Why do they not resign?

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS
sp.p: Will you answer that, Mr. Adams?

sp.speaker: JOHN ADAMS.
sp.p:
As some of you know, my friends, we have called on these consignees repeatedly, asking
them to resign. This, they have refused to do, though they know full well that the tea must be sent back to England, if there is no officer here to receive it.

sp.speaker: THIRD CITIZEN.
sp.p: Force them to resign! They are Small Tories!

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: Force them! Force them!

sp.speaker: JOHN ADAMS.
sp.p: Nay, we must proceed quietly and legally, as far as possible, friends. Mr. John Hancock is waiting upon the consignees now to ask them to come to this meeting and resign their com missions publicly.

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: In the mean time, Mr. Quincy has a matter to report to you.

sp.speaker: QUINCY.
sp.p: Friends, be it known to you all, that yesterday, in a great mass meeting, the women of Boston resolved to drink no more tea till the tax be removed.

sp.speaker: FOURTH CITIZEN.
sp.p: They are Patriots-- those women-- Patriots!

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: Aye-- aye! Patriots!

div3.stage: (Enter JOHN HANCOCK, a refined and educated gentleman of some forty years: crosses to elm.)

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: And now, friends, Mr. Hancock has come from the consignees. What have you to report, Mr. Hancock?

sp.speaker: HANCOCK.
sp.p:
Mr. Adams,-- Gentlemen of the
Committee,-- Countrymen,-- I found the three consignees in their warehouse, and put the case before them. I told them that it was the earnest desire of every Patriot in Boston that they resign their office. I asked them, with courtesy, to come here to-day, and resign publicly, that our confidence in them might be renewed, and our respect for them increased, but they refused--

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: Refused!

sp.speaker: HANCOCK.
sp.p: Yes, my friends, they refused with boldness-- indeed, I might say with impudence.

sp.speaker: FIFTH CITIZEN
sp.p: To their warehouse, men!

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: Yes-- yes! To their warehouse!

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: No, no, friends! We cannot compel the consignees to resign through destruction of their property. Besides, if we would have the respect of our sister Colonies, we must show them that our actions are guided by reason. And it may be that King George and his Ministers will realize that we are sober-minded men with whom they cannot trifle. Let us concentrate our energy on one thing alone-- a steady determination to refuse this tea sent by England. Do you all agree to that?

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: We do! We do!

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p:
Then, my countrymen, the purpose of this meeting has been accomplished. Your hearty response proves that you will cooperate with
your committee in any plan they may formulate. And be assured, we will do something.
So, friends, we will now disperse. But be at the docks when the tea ships come. There may be work for you all.

stage.hi: (Applause, and cries of assent. All going.)

div3.head: ACT II
div3.stage: (A handsomely furnished office is seen. The Secretary paces the floor anxiously. Enter the Under-Secretary, a much younger man than the Secretary.)

sp.speaker: UNDER-SECRETARY.
sp.p: Mr. Rotch has come, Mr. Simms.

sp.speaker: SECRETARY
sp.p: Again! This is the third time since noon! The tea, I suppose-- ?

sp.speaker: UNDER-SECRETARY.
sp.p:
Yes, Mr. Simms. I told him the governor was still out of town, and that nothing could be done in his absence, but he says something
must be done. Mr. Rotch is in a towering rage, sir. He insists upon seeing you.

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: What can I do? Does n't Mr. Rotch understand that I am only a secretary? The governor left no instructions in regard to the tea.

sp.speaker: UNDER-SECRETARY.
sp.p: So I told him, but he says he will not leave this office till he has some kind of an order from you.

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: Orders to whom? Haven't the citizens taken things into their own hands? Does he think they will obey us? We are in something of a mess, Mr. Wexton.

sp.speaker: UNDER-SECRETARY.
sp.p: So was the governor. He ran away to get out of it.

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: Mr. Wexton! I am astonished! Do you criticise his Excellency?

sp.speaker: UNDER-SEORETARY.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Mr. Simms.

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: You may show Mr. Rotch in.

sp.speaker: UNDER-SECRETARY.
sp.p: The captain of the ship is with him.

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: I will see them both.
sp.stage: (Exit Under-Secretary. Secretary waits nervously. Enter ROTCH and Captain HALL. ROTCH is a prosperous-looking American merchant. HALL is an English sea captain. Both are now indignant. Secretary bows.)
sp.p: Gentlemen, be seated.

sp.speaker: ROTCH.
sp.p: Sir, I am the owner of that ill-fated tea-ship that came in yesterday--

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: I know, Mr. Rotch. I appreciate your position.

sp.speaker: ROTCH.
sp.p: What is to be done about that tea?

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: I wish I knew, Mr. Rotch.

sp.speaker: ROTCH.
sp.p: Do you know that Captain Hall here was told to unload it at the peril of his life?

sp.speaker: HALL.
sp.p: And in no uncertain language. Some twenty-five men boarded my ship the moment she docked, and served that notice upon me. And they threatened to fire at the first man who attempted to take any of the tea ashore.

sp.speaker: ROTCH.
sp.p: And these armed men are now patrolling the docks and shore. And other armed men relieved them last night.

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: I know-- I am posted on all that has occurred. It is unfortunate that all this should happen while the governor is away.

sp.speaker: ROTCH
sp.p: Why is he away? He knew my ship was coming. And off he runs to his country place!

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: I thought that you were a good Tory, Mr. Rotch.

sp.speaker: ROTCH.
sp.p: I am, of course. I am somewhat unstrung just now-- I scarce know what I am saying.

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: The sheriff has gone to see the governor to ask him what to do.

sp.speaker: ROTCH.
sp.p: When will he return?

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: In about two hours, unless the governor should detain him.

sp.speaker: UNDER-SECRETARY.
sp.p: The consignees have come, Mr. Simms. They are asking for instructions.

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: Tell them the governor left no message for them. And tell them about the sheriff.

sp.speaker: ROTCH
sp.p: Two of these consignees are sons-in-law of Governor Hutchinson's. They will be able to settle the matter, I think.

sp.speaker: UNDER-SECRETARY.
sp.p: The consignees insist upon seeing you, Mr. Simms.

sp.speaker: SECRETARY
sp.p: Let them enter-- certainly.

div3.stage: (Exit Under-Secretary. Pause. Enter the three consignees. They are richly dressed and bear themselves with importance. The Secretary bows to them humbly, but they are too excited to notice salutations.)

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSIGNEE.
sp.p: You say the governor left no instructions for us?

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: No, Mr. Clark, nothing.

sp.speaker: SECOND CONSIGNEE.
sp.p: What are we to do, then? The rebels are calling at us in the streets to resign, and to resign instantly.

sp.speaker: THIRD CONSIGNEE.
sp.p: They will be at our warehouse next, with a mob!

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSIGNEE.
sp.p: Aye, they will! I tell you, Mr. Simms, this matter has got to be settled at once!

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: What can I do, gentlemen? Here's Mr. Rotch and Captain Hall who are saying the same. I tell you I can do nothing. No doubt the sheriff will bring some message from the governor.

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSIGNEE.
sp.p: He may not return for hours, and in the mean time our property is in danger. You must call out the king's troops, Mr. Simms.

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: I have no power to do that, gentlemen!

sp.speaker: SECOND CONSIGNEE.
sp.p: I'll stand responsible for you, Mr. Simms. I am related to his Honor.

sp.speaker: THIRD CONSIGNEE.
sp.p: We will all be responsible for you.

sp.speaker: ROTCH.
sp.p: It would settle the matter at once. The ships could be unloaded then without trouble. The people would n't face two thousand soldiers with muskets.

div3.stage: (The Secretary seems to be impressed. Enter Under-Secretary.)

sp.speaker: UNDER-SECRETARY.
sp.p: A committee of Patriots to see the governor, Mr. Simms--

sp.speaker: SECOND CONSIGNEE
sp.p: Patriots! They are nothing but rabble.

sp.speaker: UNDER-SECRETARY
sp.p: These gentlemen are the leading citizens of Boston, sir. You cannot call them rabble.

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: Mr. Wexton!

sp.speaker: UNDER-SECRETARY
sp.p: Your Tory governor ran away from them-- they were far too clever for him.

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSIGNEE.
sp.p: Mr. Wexton, you will be dismissed when the governor returns, if my influence counts for anything.

sp.speaker: UNDER-SECRETARY.
sp.p: I will go now! My ancestors came over in the Mayflower, sirs, and I'll not disgrace them by staying.

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I apologize. We thought Mr. Wexton a Tory.

sp.speaker: THIRD CONSIGNEE.
sp.p: Oh, we meet that now on every side. They are going mad with their patriotism.

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSIGNEE.
sp.p: Admit the committee, Mr. Simms. They may be ready to compromise.

sp.speaker: SECRETARY
sp.p: Gentlemen, will you enter?

div3.stage: (Enter SAMUEL ADAMS, HANCOCK, and QUINCY. They are dignified and calm; bow formally to consignees and others.)

sp.speaker: HANCOCK
sp.p: We have called to see the governor, thinking he may have returned.

sp.speaker: SECRETARY.
sp.p: He has not come as yet, gentlemen. May I not deliver your message to him?

sp.speaker: HANCOCK.
sp.p: You may tell his Excellency that we have found a way out of this trouble. We desire him to send the ships back to England at once with the tea.

sp.speaker: ROTCH.
sp.p: No, I object to that, sir. I might be held responsible for the loss of the tea to the company.

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: You will not lose a penny, Mr. Rotch. The citizens of Boston will pay you for any loss you may sustain. We are willing, also, to pay the company for the tea.

sp.speaker: ROTCH.
sp.p: In that case, I am willing to have the ships return.

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSIGNEE.
sp.p: The matter cannot be settled so easily. Before the ships can set sail, they must have papers for clearing the harbor, and the consent of the consignees.

sp.speaker: ROTCH.
sp.p: Then, gentlemen, I ask you for your consent. With that, I can easily obtain my papers from the custom-house.

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSIGNEE.
sp.p: Mr. Rotch, we are responsible to King George for the proper care of this business. Therefore, it is my opinion that we cannot give our consent.

sp.speaker: THIRD CONSIGNEE
sp.p: I agree with you, sir.

sp.speaker: SECOND CONSIGNEE.
sp.p: It would be the same as resigning.

sp.speaker: QUINCY
sp.p: Then, since you will do nothing to help us out of this trouble, you would do well to seek safety at once.

sp.speaker: THIRD CONSIGNEE.
sp.p: Seek safety! What do you mean, Mr. Quincy?

sp.speaker: QUINCY.
sp.p:
I mean that the wrath of our people has
been aroused. We may not be able to control them. They look upon you as traitors.

sp.speaker: CONSIGNEES
sp.p: Traitors!

sp.speaker: QUINCY.
sp.p: What else could we call you? You were born in this country; you went to our schools; you have made your living among us. The people have not forgotten these things.

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSIGNEE.
sp.p: We will call out the troops!

sp.speaker: HANCOCK.
sp.p: We are fully prepared for that, sir. For months, Boston men have drilled in secret. And the near-by towns have drilled, and will come to our aid if necessary.

sp.speaker: SECOND CONSIGNEE.
sp.p: I am astonished that you leaders should be willing to bring bloodshed upon your fellow townsmen.

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: We are all willing, sir, to die for our rights.

sp.speaker: ROTCH.
sp.p: I think I know a way out of the trouble, gentlemen. I will, myself, go to the governor and ask for a passport for sailing. I can make the trip in about three hours.

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: We will be glad to have you go, Mr. Rotch. Will you bring the governor's answer to the Old South Meeting-House? The Patriots are in assembly there now, and will wait there for your return.

sp.speaker: ROTCH.
sp.p: I will be there by eight o'clock.

div3.stage: (ROTCH and HALL bow to others and go out quickly.)

sp.speaker: THIRD CONSIGNEE.
sp.p: But, Mr. Adams, what if the governor refuses to let the tea go back?

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: Seven thousand Patriots are, at this moment, in and about the Old South Meeting-House. And these people are all of one mind, and hold the king's troops in disdain. That is your answer, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSIGNEE
sp.p: Perhaps we should flee to the barracks, and claim General Gage's protection--

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: I would strongly advise you to go there.

sp.speaker: FIRST CONSIGNEE.
sp.p: Come then, without delay.

div3.stage: (Consignees go out hurriedly.)

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS
sp.p: Please remind Mr. Rotch of the Old South Meeting-House. We will be there, waiting.

div3.stage: (Secretary bows. The Patriots bow in return and go out.)

div3.head: >ACT III
div3.stage: (A small room back of the auditorium is seen. Room is now dark. Enter LENDALL PITTS with a lantern. PITTS is a serious man of about thirty years. He lights candles on table and wall. A knock is heard at a door back, which opens into church-yard. PITTS crosses to door quickly.)

sp.speaker: PITTS.
sp.p: Who knocks?

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: Paul Revere.

div3.stage: (PITTS opens door. Enter PAUL REVERE, a responsible business man of Boston. He is of middle age: is also serious.)

sp.speaker: PITTS.
sp.p: You are here in good time, Mr. Revere. Are the other men about?

sp.speaker: REVERE.
sp.p: The men with muskets wait in the shade of the belfry.

sp.speaker: PITTS.
sp.p: Tell them to come quietly, and to keep their arms well hidden.

sp.speaker: REVERE.
sp.p: I'll caution them, Mr. Pitts.

div3.stage: (Exit to yard. PITTS lights other candles. Enter REVERE followed by some twenty men; each wears a long cloak.)

sp.speaker: PITTS.
sp.p: Stack your muskets, comrades, but quietly-- quietly-- Remember there's a meeting in the church there--
We must not disturb the speakers.
sp.stage: (Men produce muskets from cloaks; stack them quietly.)
sp.p: Did you see the others, Mr. Revere?

sp.speaker: REVERE.
sp.p: Some of them, but they were in the crowd waiting about the church doors.

sp.speaker: PITTS.
sp.p: It was so arranged, to avoid attracting attention. They are waiting for the signal-- two taps on the arm. For this, I commission you, Joseph Shed, Isaac Simpson, Samuel Sprague, Benjamin Clarke, Moses Grant, Peter Slater, James Brewer, John Carver, and Nathanl Greene.
sp.stage: (These men start off. PITTS follows them to door and continues.)
sp.p: Be cautious, gentlemen-- there are ever Tories hanging about.

stage.hi: (Men go out quietly. PITTS turns to REVERE.)

sp.p: You have your horse ready?

sp.speaker: REVERE.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Pitts, -there in the church yard-- well within the shadows.

sp.speaker: PITTS.
sp.p: Ride at once to the outskirts and watch the road for Mr. Rotch. The instant you see him coming, return post haste to tell us.

sp.speaker: REVERE.
sp.p: You may depend on me, sir.

div3.stage: (Goes out quickly. Enter men who went out with some twenty other men. They enter in small groups. All wear long cloaks, and all are serious and silent.)

sp.speaker: PITTS.
sp.p: Have you brought your blankets and hatchets?
sp.stage: (Murmurs of assent from late arrivals who produce, from beneath cloaks, Indian blankets, Indian head coverings of feathers, and hatchets. They put them on table quietly. PITTS continues.)
sp.p: Attention all-comrades!

It is fitting that we should again speak of our plans, lest there be some misunderstanding. As you know, Mr. Samuel Adams is with us heart and soul, as are also the other leaders. But they caution us to be discreet and to rely on the surprise of our plot rather than the force of arms. Nevertheless, if the sailors attempt to fight, you are to fire immediately. Be careful not to argue. Indeed, no word should be spoken, lest they recognize our voices.
There is bound to be much excitement, but do not forget to open each and every case and throw the tea in the water. Should the crews try to prevent you, force them below and lock them in the cabins.

I will take charge of the first ship, Benjamin Clarke of the second, and Nathanl Greene of the third. The other details you know full well, so I will not repeat them. There is, however, one last matter-- the governor will seek to punish us for this night's work. That is certain, and has been often discussed by us. However, his Honor can make no arrests unless he knows the offenders. Therefore, we must exercise the greatest care to keep his Excellency in ignorance. No name must be spoken, and no word uttered that would give any clew to any eaves-dropping Tory. Indeed, I think we should solemnly
promise never to reveal the name of any man here present.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Yes- yes-- we should!

sp.speaker: PITTS.
sp.p: Then hold up your right hands and repeat these words after me-- I promise--

sp.speaker: OTHERS
sp.p: I promise--

sp.speaker: PITT.
sp.p: Never to reveal--

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Never to reveal--

sp.speaker: PITTS.
sp.p: The name of any one here present.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: The name of any one here present.

sp.speaker: PITTS.
sp.p: 'T is well. It only remains, then, for us to wait till we hear the governor's answer to Mr. Rotch. In the mean time, shall we not open the door to the church a little, and listen to the speakers?
sp.stage: (Murmurs of assent. SAMUEL SPRAGUE opens door to church; holds it slightly ajar. A commotion is heard.)
sp.p: What is it, Samuel? What is the cause of the commotion?

div3.stage: (SAMUEL peeps into church; listens for a moment; turns; shows excitement.)

sp.speaker: SAMUEL.
sp.p: The sheriff has come! He is ordering them to disband!

sp.speaker: PITTS.
sp.p: Look again-- What are they doing now?

sp.speaker: SAMUEL
sp.p: They are hissing the sheriff-- And Mr. Samuel Adams has just risen to speak.

sp.speaker: REVERE.
sp.p: Rotch has come from the governor! He will be here in five minutes!

sp.speaker: PITTS.
sp.p: Then enter the church and wait till you hear the message he brings. If the governor has refused to let the ships return, give us our signal instantly-- the Mohawk Indian war-whoop.

sp.speaker: REVERE.
sp.p: I'll give it to you instantly.

sp.speaker: PITTS.
sp.p: Now, then, comrades-- your blankets-- hatchets-- muskets!

div3.stage: (All put on Indian blankets and feather head-dresses; take up muskets and hatchets. They work swiftly and silently.)

div3.head: ACT IV
div3.stage:
(The large room is well lighted with candles. Every seat is taken, and people are standing around the walls. On the pulpit platform sit SAMUEL ADAMS, who is in the chair presiding, JOHN ADAMS, Dr. WARREN, and JOHN HANCOCK.
JOSIAH QUINCY stands on platform addressing the crowded audience.)

sp.speaker: QINCY
sp.p: No, no, my countrymen, we can no longer hope that resolves, orations, and acclamations will vanquish our foes. Did we not resolve, orate, and acclaim in former days, when other unjust taxes were put upon us by King George and his obedient Parliament? It is true these taxes were finally repealed, but the king will not give up his fondest dream-- that of taxing American Colonists. Do not be deceived into thinking it is the revenue that the king desires this time. It is not. The tax is small and will not yield more than three hundred pounds a year. No, it is simply a question of oppression. The king means to show us for once and all that we must obey him. Do you hear that word-- you free men of America? Obey! and obey like galley slaves chained to their seats, with his royal governors for task-masters. Is this to be borne? No! The blood of free-born Englishmen is in our veins. The spirit of our Puritan fathers is in our breasts. They would not be forced by King James. We will not be forced by King George.

They came as Pilgrims to an unknown land. They faced starvation and savages. Shall we be less brave than they? Shall we sit calmly by and fold our hands while this last insult is being heaped upon us?

sp.speaker: AUDIENCE.
sp.p: No! No!

sp.speaker: QUINCY.
sp.p: Then rise as one man to your own defense! Rise to make this beloved land a fit abode for our children! Rise because you are women and men! Rise because it is your duty!

div3.stage: (QUINCY sits amid long and loud applause. A man passes up aisle to pulpit; hands several letters to SAMUEL ADAMS, who looks at them, rises, and lifts his hand. Applause stops instantly.)

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: A messenger has just arrived with letters from other Colonies. If it is your pleasure, I will briefly state their contents.

sp.speaker: AUDIENCE.
sp.p: Read! Read!

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS
sp.p: Virginia bids us refuse the tea. She will send us troops if we need them.
Rhode Island bids us send the tea whence it came, back to John Bull and his tea-pot.
New York asks us to defy our governor boldly. She will send soldiers if necessary.
Connecticut also asks us to be firm. She is drilling her troops that she may be ready to help us.

Both the Carolinas pray us to defy the king. Likewise do Georgia and all the Southern Colonies. In fact, they all, both South and North, offer us
their support and tell us not to submit to this last great injustice from England.

div3.stage: (A man hurries up aisle to pulpit; whispers for a moment with SAMUEL ADAMS, who seems pleased to see him.)

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: Friends, this gentleman has just arrived from Philadelphia. He brings us a message from our brother Patriots there.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.p: Mr. President--

Patriots-- brothers-- I bear to you the affection of the men of Philadelphia. I bear to you also the unanimous resolution of a great mass meeting held as soon as we received the news of your refusal to accept the tea. It was declared that the Patriots of Philadelphia would come to your aid with an army.

They bade me also to say that their only fear was lest you might shrink at the last moment. And they pray that God may give you the courage to save the liberties, not only of Boston, but of all the Colonies of America.

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS
sp.p: Sir, we thank our Philadelphia brothers. Say to them that we will not shrink. We have made our final stand, and we mean to keep it, come what may.

sp.speaker: JOHN ADAMS
sp.p: Mr. President, I propose that a rising vote be taken to prove again the temper of our patriotism.

sp.speaker: DR. WARREN
sp.p: I second the motion, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: Friends, you have heard the motion--

div3.stage: (There is a commotion at back of church. Enter the sheriff. He comes up aisle quickly, and mounts platform.)

sp.speaker: SHERIFF.
sp.p: Mr. Adams, I am the sheriff of this county. By the power of my office, I bid you to disband this meeting and sends these rebels home.

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: That is your answer, Mr. Sheriff.

sp.speaker: SHERIFF
sp.p: I come direct from your governor, who has bidden me order you to disperse, in the name of his Majesty, King George of England. Here is his Excellency's order.

div3.stage: (Waves paper aloft. Another storm of hisses from audience.)

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: Is that not sufficient, sheriff?

sp.speaker: SHERIFF.
sp.p: You'll pay for this dearly, I warn you! All of you-- leaders and people!

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: Will you please state the question again, Mr. Adams?

sp.speaker: JOHN ADAMS.
sp.p: Will this audience abide by its former resolutions to reject this tea.

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: Patriots, you have heard the question. All in favor will signify by a rising vote.

sp.speaker: AUDIENCE
sp.p: Aye!

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: Unanimous!
sp.stage: (As they sit, PAUL REVERE enters from a small door at right of platform; remains standing by door. SAMUEL ADAMS continues:)
sp.p: And now, my friends, the time draws near when we must be prepared to meet determined resistance. Mr. Rotch will soon return. What if he brings the governor's refusal to send back the tea to England?

sp.speaker: A MAN
sp.p: Mr. Chairman, we are not afraid of bloodshed!

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: No! No!

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS.
sp.p: I pray it will not come to that. Indeed, I think it will not. There is, in fact, a certain plan I may speak of now, but I cannot divulge the details. I can only give you the password, as it were. It is this-- Follow the Mohawk Indians!
sp.stage: (There are murmurs of surprise throughout audience. Enter ROTCH.)
sp.p: Friends, Mr. Rotch has come. We will now hear the governor's answer.

div3.stage: (ROTCH hurries up aisle to platform. There is death-like silence.)

sp.speaker: ROTCH.
sp.p: Mr. Adams, Governor Hutchinson declares he will not permit the tea to be sent back. He says it must be landed.

sp.speaker: SAMUEL ADAMS
sp.p: Friends, you have heard the governor's answer. Our time has come! The hour of liberty has struck for us! Remember my words-- Follow the Mohawk Indians!

div3.stage: (PAUL REVERE at once opens small door at back and gives an Indian war-whoop. Enter from back, forty men disguised as Indians. They pass quickly down aisle, giving the war-whoop. Leaders and people follow them from church.)

div4.p: A vast crowd is seen on a wharf, looking out upon three ships anchored close by. A full moon discloses Mohawk Indians on decks of each ship. Some are opening chests with hatchets; some are throwing tea into sea and others are hoisting chests from hold. On one ship, in foreground, Captain Hall is motioning to his frightened sailors to stop them.
Wharf and ships, as before. Indians hold muskets raised to fire. Sailors in retreat. People on wharf waving hats and handkerchiefs with joy.

head.hi:
WHEN COURAGE WAS NEEDED
OR
THE FIRST CONTINENTAL CONGRESS

div3.head: ACT I

p.hi: PLACE: London, England. Residence of the Honorable Mrs. Howe.

div3.stage: (In a handsomely furnished drawing-room are many ladies and gentlemen in elegant evening attire. They talk together in groups with animation and laughter. Enter two richly dressed ladies from room off. They are unobserved by others.)

sp.speaker: FIRST LADY
sp.p: There are more guests than I expected.

sp.speaker: SECOND LADY.
sp.p:
Yes, there are more than usual, but it is easily explained, Madam. It was well known
that Dr. Franklin was to be here. Every one is curious to see him since he was insulted so deeply by Parliament.

sp.speaker: FIRST LADY.
sp.p: Oh, to be sure, that is it! I venture to say every invitation was accepted. Everywhere I go, I hear talk of this American.

sp.speaker: SECOND LADY.
sp.p: Have you spoken with him to-night?

sp.speaker: FIRST LADY.
sp.p: Not as yet. He is deep in chess with our hostess.

sp.speaker: SECOND LADY.
sp.p: I would not have you repeat me, Madam, but I do think it strange that Mrs. Howe has the Doctor here to-night.

sp.speaker: FIRST LADY.
sp.p: I think it strange she has him here at all. Oh, I know he is a wonderful chess player, and I know that Mrs. Howe is devoted to the game, but even that does not seem sufficient reason for the attention she shows him-- especially now, since he has been cut by the king. But of course you will not repeat me?

sp.speaker: SECOND LADY.
sp.p: You may trust me, Madam. I would not mention it for worlds.

div3.stage: (First Gentleman leaves a group and crosses to ladies.)

sp.speaker: FIRST GENTLEMAN
sp.p: I salute you, ladies.

sp.speaker: LADIES
sp.p: My lord--

sp.speaker: FIRST GENTLEMAN.
sp.p: I hesitated to interrupt you-- you were so deep in conversation.

sp.speaker: FIRST LADY.
sp.p: Oh, we were only remarking upon Dr. Franklin's presence here.

sp.speaker: SECOND LADY.
sp.p: Don't you think it strange, my lord?

sp.speaker: FIRST GENTLEMAN.
sp.p: I do, indeed. He has been snubbed by almost every one of consequence since that fatal day in Parliament.

sp.speaker: SECOND LADY.
sp.p: What was the straight of that matter, my lord? You were present, I believe.

sp.speaker: FIRST GENTLEMAN.
sp.p: I was, Madam, and I assure you that I would not have missed it for anything. You see, Dr. Franklin, as the Colonial agent here in England, had presented to Parliament the complaint of Massachusetts against her royal governors, Hutchinson and Oliver, and this was the day appointed for discussion of the case. The Solicitor-General made a most bitter attack upon Franklin. He insulted him openly and also his countrymen, whom he called rascals and knaves.

sp.speaker: FIRST LADY.
sp.p: They say the Doctor stood it all unflinchingly.

sp.speaker: FIRST GENTLEMAN.
sp.p: He did, Madam. He faced the Solicitor immovable as a statue, though he must have been cruelly hurt.

sp.speaker: SECOND LADY.
sp.p: But there are certain members of Parliament who are favorable to the cause of the Colonies. I cannot understand why they did not arise to defend him.

sp.speaker: FIRST GENTLEMAN.
sp.p:
Two of them did, Madam,
but they were both poor speakers and made no impression. Their voices were soon lost in the torrent of abuse from the eloquent Solicitor-General, and in the applause of the judges and members, who roared with laughter throughout the assault. Oh, it was most amusing!

sp.speaker: SECOND LADY.
sp.p: I would I had heard it myself!

sp.speaker: FIRST LADY.
sp.p: Is it true that the king has ignored the petition presented by Dr. Franklin in regard to the Colonial tea tax?

sp.speaker: FIRST GENTLEMAN.
sp.p: He has ignored it completely, except, as you know, to send additional regiments to Boston and warships to close their port and starve them into submission.

sp.speaker: FIRST LADY.
sp.p: Small wonder, then, that Dr. Franklin is no longer invited to court, nor to the levees of the king's ministers. He represents an unpopular cause.

sp.speaker: FIRST GENTLEMAN.
sp.p: His career is ended here in England, at least so long as he espouses his countrymen's contentions.

sp.speaker: SECOND LADY.
sp.p: Then why is he still invited here? There is no more proper house in London, nor a more particular hostess. Besides, Mrs. Howe is connected with the court through her brother, Lord Howe, who is in close touch with his Majesty.

sp.speaker: FIRST GENTLEMAN.
sp.p:
Oh, it is only because he plays a good game of chess. And that to the
Honorable Mrs. Howe is far more important than quarrels between England and her Colonies.

div3.stage: (They laugh. Several other ladies and gentlemen hear, and cross to them.)

sp.speaker: THIRD LADY.
sp.p: And what is the cause of your merriment, friends? Tell us so we may laugh with you.

sp.speaker: FIRST GENTLEMAN
sp.p: We were merely speaking of our subjects in America.

sp.speaker: SECOND GENTLEMAN.
sp.p: No wonder you laughed. Those poor souls are fast becoming a joke over here, with their petitions for this, and that, and everything.

sp.speaker: THIRD GENTLEMAN.
sp.p: They seem to think they are on an equal footing with us and deserve just as much of the king's favor and protection.

sp.speaker: THIRD LADY.
sp.p: And they are nothing but half-breed Indians, too. I understand there are few white men among them.

sp.speaker: FOURTH LADY.
sp.p: I have heard that their leader in Boston is a terrible desperado. They say he goes armed everywhere, and shoots on the least provocation.

sp.speaker: SECOND GENTLEMAN.
sp.p: That is true, Madam. He is an out-and-out highwayman. His name is Samuel Adams.

sp.speaker: FIRST LADY.
sp.p:
Why, I understood that it was he who wrote that last petition from Boston concerning
the tea tax. It is said to be a very remarkable paper.

sp.speaker: FIRST GENTLEMAN.
sp.p: It was no doubt composed by some Englishman here in London.

sp.speaker: FIRST LADY.
sp.p: But Dr. Franklin is an American, and he is counted one of the most brilliant men of the age. You know that he ranks with our greatest scientists in England, or in all Europe for that matter.

sp.speaker: SECOND LADY.
sp.p: And he does not in the least resemble an Indian.

sp.speaker: THIRD GENTLEMAN.
sp.p: But, Madam, he has been here for many years, and that has changed him completely. He worked here as a boy.

stage.hi: (Nods and murmurs of approval. Enter Butler.)

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Refreshments are being served on the balcony.

div3.stage: (Crosses to the different groups and speaks with each aside. All go out, talking and laughing together. Exit Butler, last. Pause. Enter Butler showing in Lord HOWE who wears his cloak and hat. He removes these; Butler taking them. Lord HOWE is a distinguished-looking man of middle age. He is elegantly dressed, but not in evening attire.)

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: Is my sister engaged?

sp.speaker: BUTLER.
sp.p: Madam is playing chess, Lord Howe.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: BUTLER.
sp.p: With Dr. Franklin, my lord.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: Where are the other guests?

sp.speaker: BUTLER.
sp.p: Some are watching the game and others are on the terrace.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: Speak with my sister privately and say that I must see her at once.
Stay! tell no one else of my presence here. Let this room be closed to the guests for the remainder of the evening.

sp.speaker: BUTLER.
sp.p: I'll see to it, my lord.

div3.stage: (Exit. Pause. Lord HOWE waits, lost in deep thought. Enter the Honorable Mrs. HOWE, a stately and charming woman.)

sp.speaker: MRS. HOWE.
sp.p: Ah, brother--

stage.hi: (Gives her hand to Lord HOWE, who kisses it.)

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: I am sorry to interrupt your beloved game, but business, my dear sister, before pleasure.

sp.speaker: MRS. HOWE.
sp.p: It is nothing unpleasant, I hope--

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: Letters have just come from America bringing news of a serious nature.

sp.speaker: MRS. HOWE
sp.p: Ah! Then it is something unpleasant!

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: The American Colonies have defied the king. They have arranged to hold a Parliament of their own!

sp.speaker: MRS. HOWE
sp.p: It has come to that!

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: Aye, it has come to that. So the time is now ripe to make our secret proposal to Dr. Franklin.

sp.speaker: MRS HOWE.
sp.p: It will require skillful handling.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: What do you mean? Does he suspect us?

sp.speaker: MRS. HOWE.
sp.p: Oh, no-- he believes he has been invited here for the sole purpose of playing chess with me.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: He has no idea that it was a pre-arranged plan?

sp.speaker: MRS. HOWE.
sp.p: I am positive he has not. Indeed, I flatter myself that I have managed the matter very well. Through meeting Dr. Franklin here at my parties, you have been able to hold various friendly talks with him and establish yourself in his confidence. He admires you, I know.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: Then it will seem quite natural that I should ask him to accompany me to America and influence his countrymen to obey the king's commands.

sp.speaker: MRS. HOWE.
sp.p: But suppose he refuses to do this?

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: In that case I am empowered to offer him a handsome sum of money.

sp.speaker: MRS. HOWE.
sp.p: I fear you will have your hands full when it comes to a bribe. Dr. Franklin seems to have as fine a sense of honor as an Englishman.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: Pshaw! He will take a bribe as readily as any of his tribe. Will you please tell him that I wish to speak with him?

sp.speaker: MRS. HOWE.
sp.p: Shall I remain for your interview?

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p:
By no means! I want him to feel that the
matter is between him and me alone. He will take the bribe much quicker.

sp.speaker: MRS. HOWE.
sp.p: I will make some excuse then for withdrawing.

div3.stage: (Exit. Lord HOWE waits anxiously. Enter Mrs. HOWE with Dr. FRANKLIN. He is now sixty-eight years of age, but shows undiminished vigor both physically and mentally. The men bow cordially.)

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: It is a pleasure to find you here in my sister's home, Dr. Franklin.

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: Your sister has been kind enough to give me some very charming evenings, Lord Howe.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: I regret to bring business into this one, but I would confer with you upon certain Colonial matters.

sp.speaker: MRS. HOWE.
sp.p: Then, gentlemen, I will withdraw.

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: No, Madam, I beg you to stay. I have no secret in any business of this nature that I cannot confide to your prudence.

sp.speaker: MRS. HOWE.
sp.p: I thank you, Doctor, for the compliment, but my other guests will notice my absence, and may remark upon it.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: And I prefer this conference to remain unknown to them.

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: I would not embarrass you, Madam, nor you, my lord.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p:
I have just had information that certain
letters arrived to-day from America with news of grave importance. But I presume you have heard--?

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: To what news do you refer?

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: To the proposed meeting of a Colonial Congress next month in Philadelphia.

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: Yes, I have had that news.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: Then you know, of course, that the plan originated in the Massachusetts Assembly in June, and that it has been taken up with enthusiasm by the other Colonies. In fact, they have all held assemblies and elected delegates to this Congress.

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: So I was informed, my lord.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: Then you must be prepared to agree with me that the time has come for a reconciliation.

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: I agree with you heartily in that, Lord Howe, but I am at a loss to know how peace and union can be restored. Various Colonies have sent to his Majesty a respectful statement of abuses, and a humble prayer for their redress, but even this, it seems, is regarded by the king and his ministers as a form of treason, and is utterly ignored.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: His Majesty believes he has the right to govern his subjects as he thinks fit and proper.

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: His Majesty's subjects in America think it impossible for any man or body of men, living so far away, to know their peculiar business and political needs.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p:
But his Majesty has placed royal governors
over every Colony. Certainly they should know what are America's needs.

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: No, my lord, they do not. They are, with few exceptions, Englishmen, and have come to us with that strange idea that seems to prevail over here-- that American Colonists are of a lower order of beings and should therefore be treated as slaves. And also that we are all knaves, rascals, and out-laws.

sp.speaker: HOWE
sp.p: I must confess, Dr. Franklin, that that idea does seem to be held by some--

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN
sp.p: Many of your public men have been in America and know full well the culture and elegance of our leading citizens. They know that a large number of them have been educated in English colleges, and that our colleges in America are of high standing. I cannot understand why the opposite opinion prevails, even in Parliament.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: I am sensible, Doctor, that you and your countrymen have been ill treated by Parliament. But I can assure you that ample satisfaction will one day or other be made you. However, I do not think that it was meant to be personal.

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: As to the matter of its being personal, I do not think it worth mentioning. I am concerned only with the injuries done my country in the Solicitor's attack.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p:
I believe the violence of his speech was
due to the troubles that have arisen over the tea tax. Boston refused to pay it or even receive the tea, thus defying his Majesty and Parliament openly. Then the other Colonies followed her example. Wherever the tea was sent, it was either destroyed or allowed to rot in some warehouse. Naturally, the king and his ministers are indignant.

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: And my countrymen are indignant-- indignant that Boston is now being punished so cruelly. I tell you, my Lord Howe, that the king and his ministers may read the temper of the American Colonists in their call for an American Congress. Only desperate men would have the courage to formulate such a plan, and only desperate men would accept it. They know full well that they may be seized as traitors.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: They do not understand England's motives, Doctor. That is the real basis of their discontent.

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: Have you any plan to propose whereby England's motives can be made clear to us?

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: Yes, I have such a plan. What do you think of sending some person over to inquire into the grievances of America; converse with the leading people, and endeavor, with them, to agree upon some means of settling our differences?

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: The right person might be of great use in such service.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p:
I have just learned that I am being thought
of as this commissioner. But I would not undertake it unless you would consent to accompany me, Doctor. Your influence over your people is wonderful. You can, if any man can, persuade them to listen to reasonable propositions.

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: I thank you, my lord, but I wish to know what propositions are intended for America. If they are reasonable, I may be able to make them appear such to my countrymen. If they are unreasonable, I would not think of undertaking such a mission.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: I would not expect your assistance without a proper consideration. I am, in fact, empowered to make you a firm promise of rewards.

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: My lord, drop all thoughts of rewards for me. They would be considered as so many bribes to betray the interests of my country, and thus would be destroyed the very influence you hope to make use of.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: But, my dear Doctor, no one need know of it but ourselves.

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: I will not accept a reward under any circumstances. Only let me know your propositions for America, and if I approve of them, I will be ready to accompany you at any time you may appoint.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: First of all-- the tea tax must be paid--

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: Your mission to America will be a failure, my lord. My people will pay no more taxes until they can have a voice in Parliament.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: You must influence them to give up that idea, Doctor, for the king will never consent to it. They must also give up this Continental Congress. The leaders would be hung and the lesser members imprisoned.

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: First catch your hare to eat him, my lord.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: How can they possibly escape? They will be arrested by the royal governors before they can reach Philadelphia.

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: No man on earth can prevent them from holding this Congress. And if I could, I would not-- I am wholly in sympathy with them.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: Be careful not to express such sentiments here in England, Doctor. It might be construed as treason.

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: I thank you for the hint, my lord.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: And now I will tell you privately, that you will be in constant danger of arrest if you do not make an attempt to prevent this Congress from meeting.

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: I am ready, then, for prison.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: Shall I tell his Majesty that?

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: If you will, my lord.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: Allow me to suggest, Doctor, that you leave England at once.

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p:
Again I thank you, my lord, but I will be needed here now more than ever, to present the resolutions of our American Congress to Parliament
and King George. I shall remain in London indefinitely.

sp.speaker: HOWE.
sp.p: I trust we part as friends, Doctor?

sp.speaker: FRANKLIN.
sp.p: We do, my lord. And if, at any future time, a game of chess is likely, I am at your sister's service. I wish you good-night, Lord Howe.

div3.stage: (Men bow. Exit FRANKLIN, unruffled and with dignity.)

div3.head: ACT II
div3.stage: (A small dining-room is seen with open doors back, leading into a hall. The room is lighted only by light from hall. Enter Landlord, followed by Waiter bearing a candelabrum, which is blazing with lighted candles.)

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: Place the candelabrum on the table there-- in the center. And use my best linen and silver and china.

div3.stage: (Waiter sets table, getting articles from side-board. Landlord watches critically.)

sp.speaker: WAITER.
sp.p: How many plates shall I lay, Master?

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: Four. And see to it that the service is perfect. The gentlemen are all wealthy and among the prominent citizens of Philadelphia.

sp.speaker: WAITER.
sp.p: Is a regular dinner to be served?

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: No, a supper only. "A slight but elegant repast," was the order.

sp.speaker: WAITER.
sp.p: They are coming here to talk, then-- to discuss some private matter--

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: Without doubt. A private room was desired. And, by the way, it might be well if you could manage to overhear a word or two. I am curious to know what these rich men say.

sp.speaker: WAITER.
sp.p: Leave it to me, Master. The gentlemen are Tories?

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: Of course. Else they would not be coming here. This inn is known far and wide as a Tory gathering place.

sp.speaker: WAITER.
sp.p: But you yourself are a Patriot.

sp.speaker: LANDLORD
sp.p: How dare you! I'll discharge you at once! Come, out of my house, you rascal!

sp.speaker: WAITER
sp.p: Softly, Master, softly. I saw you last night as you crept forth from your door and met a strange man in your barn. I followed you and listened.

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: How dared you!

sp.speaker: WAITER.
sp.p: Because these are troublesome times, sir, and no man trusts another.

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: You say you listened-?

sp.speaker: WAITER.
sp.p: Yes. And I heard you telling your fellow what your Tory guests had been saying about this Continental Congress, and the plans they had made to destroy it.

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: You will not betray me?

sp.speaker: WAITER.
sp.p: Why, I am a Patriot myself! I came here for work that I might watch your Tories. Of course I will not betray you. Here's my hand upon it.

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: You say you came here to watch. Were you sent by any one-- by any of our Committee of Safety?

sp.speaker: WAITER.
sp.p: No, it was just a plan I formed for myself. Every Patriot should help who can, is my motto.

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: Right, my boy, right! The Tories are rich and do not feel the burden of paying the heavy taxes levied by our royal governors. It falls upon us-- the working class and the poor. So we must do our part, or we will never be freed from oppression.

sp.speaker: WAITER.
sp.p: That's the spirit, Master!

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: I consider it my duty to keep the Committee informed. The Tories often come here to plot over a supper in a private room. And the door is not always closed tight.

sp.speaker: WAITER
sp.p: Of course not! Who gives this supper to-night?

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: The rich Mr. Shippen who is a bitter Tory. He has been here often of late with small parties of his Tory friends. I am certain they are planning some harm to our Congress, from words I have overheard.

sp.speaker: WAITER.
sp.p: Some harm to our delegates?

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: I fear so. I would give all I own to know.

sp.speaker: WAITER.
sp.p: I'll listen all I 'm able. You may depend on that.

sp.speaker: LANDLORD
sp.p: Hist! Is not that a carriage stopping?

sp.speaker: WAITER
sp.p: It is, sir. Shall I go?

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: No-- no-- I'll go myself. With guests of such distinction, I cannot be too attentive.

div3.stage: (Exit hastily. Waiter places chairs at table, then waits by open door. Pause. Enter Landlord, bowing in four gentlemen-- richly dressed men of middle age.)

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: This is the room reserved for you and your party, Mr. Shippen. I trust it meets with your approval.

sp.speaker: FIRST TORY.
sp.p: It will do very well, landlord.
Be seated, gentlemen.
sp.stage: (They sit at table, Waiter and Landlord assisting. First Tory turns to Landlord.)
sp.p: Have the dishes been prepared that I ordered?

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Shippen, everything is ready.

sp.speaker: FIRST TORY.
sp.p: We do not wish to be served just now--

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: As you please, sir. You have only to call. I will station a man at your door.

div3.stage: (Bows himself out. Waiter lingers, arranging silver on sideboard. Guests look at him. Pause.)

sp.speaker: FIRST TORY
sp.p: Will you be good enough to withdraw, sir?

sp.speaker: WAITER.
sp.p: Oh! I beg your pardon, gentlemen!

sp.speaker: FIRST TORY.
sp.p: Now let us talk freely, friends. If we mean to stop the rebel Congress from meeting, we must form some plan to-night.

sp.speaker: SECOND TORY.
sp.p: I confess I am discouraged, Mr. Shippen. We have formed many plans, but all have come to nothing.

sp.speaker: THIRD TORY.
sp.p: It seems quite hopeless to me. The delegates have all come, and Congress will convene to-morrow.

sp.speaker: FIRST TORY.
sp.p: It is most vexatious. There are more Tories here than in any other part of the country. Are we to allow them to meet under our very noses?

sp.speaker: FOURTH TORY.
sp.p: I can scarcely endure the thought of it. How dare they so defy our king! How dare they set up their own Parliament!

sp.speaker: FIRST TORY.
sp.p:
Well, they do dare. Here are those arch traitors, Samuel Adams and John Adams, come all the way from Massachusetts. And everywhere
on their passage, bells were ringing, cannon firing, and men, women, and children crowding to see them as if to a coronation. New York would not let them depart till they had devoted six days to the princely entertainments provided for them.

sp.speaker: THIRD TORY.
sp.p: And Philadelphia has been no whit behind in her reception of these rebels. They arrived on the twentieth of August, and have been feasted with magnificence ever since. Last night a young Quaker and his wife had a costly repast for them. The night before, a Roman Catholic. And always toasts are given to the success of the Congress.

sp.speaker: SECOND TORY.
sp.p: Their boldness exceeds anything I ever knew, except that of their rebel supporters.

sp.speaker: FIRST TORY.
sp.p: We should take some bold step ourselves. His Majesty will reward us richly, if we succeed in dispersing these delegates.

sp.speaker: FOURTH TORY.
sp.p: How can we accomplish what the royal governors have tried with such ill success? The different assemblies, called by the rebels to elect delegates, were ordered to dissolve. In Virginia they were especially bold, and met just around the corner.

sp.speaker: SECOND TORY.
sp.p: And in Massachusetts, the governor sent his sheriff to dissolve them, but Samuel Adams had locked the door and had put the key in his pocket. The sheriff was not even allowed to enter.

sp.speaker: THIRD TORY.
sp.p: And that happened with the British general close by!

sp.speaker: FOURTH TORY.
sp.p:
It is strange General Gage did
not arrest this Samuel Adams. The king ordered it some time ago.

sp.speaker: THIRD TORY.
sp.p: It is evident he has not dared to. So what can we do, gentlemen? The rebels have the populace with them. Let us make one move, and we would soon have a mob upon us.

sp.speaker: FIRST TORY.
sp.p: I would not dream of open opposition. But why not kidnap their ringleaders, John and Samuel Adams? It could be done by our men to-night. Congress would hardly convene without them, or, if it did, it would dissolve in confusion-- so dependent are they all upon this brace of Adamses.

sp.speaker: SECOND TORY.
sp.p: You forget Patrick Henry, of Virginia, sir. He took a prominent part in the Virginia Assembly of rebels, and is said to be a marvelous speaker. He could easily lead this Congress. And so could Peyton Randolph or Colonel George Washington, also delegates from Virginia.

sp.speaker: THIRD TORY.
sp.p: And so could Christopher Gadsden, of South Carolina, James Kinsey, of New Jersey, Roger Sherman, of Connecticut, Thomas Mifflin, of Pennsylvania, or Cesar Rodney, of Delaware. They are all leaders in their own Colonies.

sp.speaker: FOURTH TORY.
sp.p: And so are John Jay, James Duane, and Philip Livingston, of New York, Nathaniel Folsom, of New Hampshire, Stephen Hopkins, of Rhode Island, Samuel Chase, of Maryland, and William Hooper, of North Carolina. Can we kidnap them all?

sp.speaker: FIRST TORY.
sp.p: I see that my suggestion is futile-- even foolish under the circumstances. We must depend upon Tories in Congress.

sp.speaker: THIRD TORY.
sp.p: Tories in Congress! The delegates all call themselves Patriots.

sp.speaker: FIRST TORY.
sp.p: True. But some of them will be found to have Tory sympathies, especially men with property. They know they will lose their possessions if it comes to war with England. For that reason they will be conservative and will hold down such rampant rebels as those men from Massachusetts.

sp.speaker: SECOND TORY.
sp.p: I believe you are right, Mr. Shippen. I would not be surprised if Mr. Washington were not at heart a Tory. He is one of the richest men in Virginia.

sp.speaker: THIRD TORY.
sp.p: I believe we can count also on Mr. Joseph Galloway, a delegate from Pennsylvania. He also has large property-holdings and visits Tory families socially.

sp.speaker: FIRST TORY.
sp.p: I know Mr. Galloway very well, so I will talk with him to-morrow. Indeed, we must make it our business to talk privately with several delegates and bring every influence in our power to bear upon them. We must prevent this Congress from declaring its united support of Boston.

sp.speaker: FOURTH TORY.
sp.p: But that is the real purpose of its meeting.

sp.speaker: FIRST TORY.
sp.p:
I know, but we must find members
who will defeat it. We must tell them that such a resolution would mean war with England, and the utter confusion of all business here in America. We must frighten these delegates, gentlemen, and cause them to see clearly their own financial ruin.

sp.speaker: SECOND TORY.
sp.p: It is a good plan, Mr. Shippen, and I believe it will work. Men may rant about patriotism, but when it comes to a question of their own possessions, it is a horse of another color.

sp.speaker: FOURTH TORY
sp.p: Indeed it is! It will make them dissolve in one week.

sp.speaker: FIRST TORY.
sp.p: It certainly cannot last a month. We will need to influence only two or three important men, like Washington and Galloway. The timid ones will follow like sheep. For there will be timid ones, gentlemen. Even some of the leaders you have just mentioned will become confused when faced with the responsibility of bringing a war on this country. And these we can rely on to make a unified action impossible.
sp.stage: (Nods and murmurs of consent. First Tory rising.)
sp.p: And now I will order supper and we can discuss our plans at length, but not before our waiter-- we must watch our words closely, friends.

div3.head: ACT III
div3.stage: (The assembly room is seen with the Congress in session. On a slightly raised platform sits the President-- the Honorable PEYTON RANDOLPH. The Secretary, Mr. CHARLES THOMSON, sits near by at a table. The fifty-four delegates sit on plain wooden benches.)

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Are you ready for the question, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: Question! Question!

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Will the secretary please read the resolution?

sp.speaker: SECRETARY
sp.p: Be it resolved that from and after the 10th day of September, 1775, the exportation of the merchandise and every commodity whatsoever to Great Britain ought to cease, unless the grievances of America are redressed before that time.

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT.
sp.p: You have heard the question. Are there any remarks?

sp.speaker: GALLOWAY
sp.p: Mr. President--

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Mr. Galloway--

sp.speaker: GALLOWAY.
sp.p:
I have waited with great patience to hear some resolution which should tend to produce harmony between England and the Colonies. But to my mortification and distress, a month has been spent in debates on propositions which tend to inflame rather than reconcile-- to produce war instead of peace. The motion just read is manifestly of that order. It is more-- it is undutiful and illegal. It is an insult to Parliament, and it cannot fail to draw on the Colonies the resentment of our mother country. If we will not trade with Great Britain, she will not suffer us to trade at all. In proof of that, see what has happened in Boston! Her people refused to pay the tea tax and destroyed the tea, but her act was resented quickly. Bills were passed by Parliament and signed by his Majesty, to curtail
the freedom of Boston. And then in enforcement of these new laws, battleships were sent to block her port, and four new regiments to patrol her streets, and now her business is utterly ruined. Is it then incredible that other English men-of-war will block all our other ports, and that other English troops will reduce us all to obedience? You know well what that will mean. The produce of labor will perish on our hands: labor itself will soon cease, and then will come absolute ruin to each and every Colony. I therefore reject this motion as being dangerous to the welfare of all our American interests.

div3.stage: (Sits. Several delegates stand quickly. JAMES DUANE is first.)

sp.speaker: DUANE AND OTHERS.
sp.p: Mr. President-- Mr. President!

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Mr. Duane, of New York, has the floor.

sp.speaker: DUANE.
sp.p: Mr. President, I agree with Mr. Galloway. If we vote to cut off all trade with Great Britain, we are virtually voting to throw off our allegiance to our king. Are we ready to do that, gentlemen? It would mean war of the most horrible kind, for it would be between friends and kindred.

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: Mr. President--

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Mr. Henry--

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: I should like to refresh the memories of the gentlemen who have just spoken. Have they forgotten that a state of war already exists in Massachusetts? Why, the war has come! It is here in our midst. Our Colonial agent in England, Dr. Benjamin Franklin, has done all any mortal man could to plead our cause. But our petitions have either been ignored or laughed at. And now our distinguished countryman is himself in constant danger of arrest. So why do you say, Mr. Galloway, that you fear a war will come? I tell you that it has come! It began when those infamous Bills against the liberties of Boston were signed by his Majesty. What, then, are we to do? Shall we bow humbly to our royal king while he uses his lash on Boston? Shall we kiss the royal mantle while the royal hand aims his cannon at the very hearts of our countrymen? No! We will not! We must show that we resent England's policy in this land. Therefore has this motion been made, and therefore must it be carried.

div3.stage: (Sits. Colonel GEORGE WASHINGTON stands. He is a handsome man of forty-two.)

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: Mr. President--

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Colonel Washington--

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p:
Mr. Henry has voiced the sentiments of all the delegates from Virginia. We must indeed show England that we resent her cruel laws against Boston. We are not threatening independence.
It is the wish of us all to create even stronger ties to bind us to our mother country. But it cannot be done at the price of liberty to any one of our Colonies. Therefore, I favor the motion as being the united sentiment of Virginia.

sp.speaker: GALLOWAY.
sp.p: Mr. President--

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Mr. Galloway--

sp.speaker: GALLOWAY.
sp.p: I fail to understand Colonel Washington's logic. Nor do I comprehend the strange ideas of another delegate from Virginia, the Honorable Patrick Henry. Why should Virginia, forsooth, take it upon herself to support Boston in this quarrel? Why should Virginia try to influence the other Colonies?

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: Mr. President--

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Mr. Henry--

sp.speaker: HENRY.
sp.p: I will explain to Mr. Galloway a thing that should not need explanation to any Patriot. At this time, we are not Virginians-- we are Americans!

div3.stage: (Loud applause. President raps for order. Doorkeeper crosses to platform: whispers to Secretary, who in turn whispers to President.)

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Gentlemen, an express has just arrived from Boston with an important letter. What is your pleasure in regard to this? Shall we admit the messenger?

sp.speaker: LIVINGSTON.
sp.p: Mr. President--

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Mr. Livingston--

sp.speaker: LIVINGSTON.
sp.p: I move we lay all other matters aside for the moment.

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN.
sp.p: I second the motion, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT.
sp.p: You have heard the motion. All in favor will signify in the usual way.

sp.speaker: ALL MEMBERS.
sp.p: Aye!

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Carried.
Admit Mr. Revere.
sp.stage: (Exit Doorkeeper. Short pause. Enter PAUL REVERE; crosses to platform; bows to President; gives a legal-looking letter to Secretary, who breaks the seals and reads. REVERE turns to go.)
sp.p: Please remain, Mr. Revere. We may need your testimony as a citizen of Boston.
sp.stage: (REVERE bows assent; remains standing by platform.)
sp.p: Will you read the letter, Mr. Thomson?

sp.speaker: SECRETARY
sp.p: "To the Delegates of the Continental Congress,

"Dear Sirs: Be it known to you that General Gage is fortifying Boston as if we were declared enemies. The entrenchments upon the neck are nearly completed. Cannon are mounted at the en- trance of the town. It is reported that strong fortifications are to be erected on the surrounding hills, so that these, with the ships of war in the harbor, may absolutely command every avenue to the town, both by sea and land. When the city is thus
enclosed, it is feared the inhabitants will be at the mercy of brutal soldiers, who are even now harassing us in many ways. We therefore apply to the Congress for advice. If you advise us to leave our homes and abandon the town, we obey. If it is judged that, by holding our ground, we can better serve the public cause, we will not shrink from hardship and danger.
"(Signed) THE COMMITTEE OF SAFETY,
"JOSEPH WARREN, President."

div3.stage: (There are murmurs of indignation and sympathy.)

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you have heard the letter. Shall we take action concerning it? Our discussion may become informal.

sp.speaker: GALLOWAY.
sp.p: How can we take action, Mr. President? Boston has rebelled against our king. We cannot assist a rebel.

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: Shame! Shame!

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: Mr. President, I offer to equip one thousand men at my own expense and march at their head to relieve Boston.

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
