sp.stage: (Tories get wraps hurriedly and go out. WASHINGTON turns to his officers.)
sp.p: This is a glorious day, gentlemen ! The tide is turned-- the cause of the revolution is saved!

sp.speaker: OFFICERS.
sp.p: Aye! It is! It is!

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: You have supported me bravely, officers. My heart is overflowing with gratitude. But I will speak of this anon. Now we must depart.

div4.stage: (Officers step aside, saluting WASHINGTON as he passes out. They follow.)

div3.head: ACT II

p.hi: PLACE: Valley Forge, Pennsylvania-- twenty miles from Philadelphia. General Washington's headquarters in camp of Continental army.

div3.stage: (Interior of a large field tent is seen. A fire burns in a small stove, but the tent seems cold and cheerless. There is a cot, a table, and several camp chairs. Lieutenant-Colonel HAMILTON is writing at table. He is twenty-one years of age; is brilliant; impetuous. Enter an orderly.)

sp.speaker: ORDERLY
sp.p: Colonel Hamilton--

sp.speaker: HAMILTON
sp.p: Well--

sp.speaker: ORDERLY.
sp.p: A man wishes to see General Washington.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p: The General is engaged.

div3.stage: (Exit Orderly. Pause. HAMILTON writes. Enter Orderly, salutes.)

sp.speaker: ORDERLY.
sp.p: The man insists, Colonel. He says he has an important message.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p: Who is he?

sp.speaker: ORDERLY.
sp.p: He says his name is Craig-- John Craig.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON
sp.p: Ah! Admit him, Orderly.

div3.stage: (Exit Orderly. Pause. Enter JOHN CRAIG, a keen-looking young man of twenty-five. He wears citizen dress. HAMILTON rises; bows. CRAIG bows.)

sp.speaker: CRAIG.
sp.p: I expected to see General Washington.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p: He is going through the soldiers' quarters to see if the men are comfortable this bitter day. Can you not give your message to me? I am the General's aide-de-camp.

sp.speaker: CRAIG.
sp.p: The message is for General Washington alone. I will wait.
It is indeed a bitter day, Colonel. The winter is unusually severe.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p: 'T is especially hard on one of your profession.

sp.speaker: CRAIG
sp.p: My profession! What mean you by that?

sp.speaker: HAMILTON
sp.p:
I knew you the moment I
saw you, though you have changed your name in the mean time.

sp.speaker: CRAIG
sp.p: You speak in riddles, Colonel.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p: Your name is Thomas Dart, and you are a spy in the General's service. In fact, you have just come from Philadelphia, whither General Washington sent you to find out what you could about the British force.

sp.speaker: CRAIG
sp.p: I confess, Colonel, I am guilty.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p: What is the latest news from Philadelphia and Congress?

sp.speaker: CRAIG.
sp.p: There is still much talk over the surrender of the British army in the north to General Gates. He is being hailed as a hero, even by members of Congress.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON
sp.p: They should be reproving him for his insulting treatment of General Washington after his victory was won. He reported his triumph to Congress, forsooth, instead of his commander-in-chief. It makes my blood boil to recall it.

sp.speaker: CRAIG.
sp.p: He takes every opportunity to make himself seem a hero.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p: And General Washington is being discredited!

sp.speaker: CRAIG.
sp.p: I regret to say it, Colonel, but the general is being openly condemned for allowing the British to occupy Philadelphia.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON
sp.p:
And how was he to prevent
it? Is he not hampered at every step by lack of men and provisions? To be sure, the victory at Trenton raised men's hopes for a time, and there were many enlistments. But a few reverses brought things back to where they were. And now conditions are worse than ever. But you know that for yourself, sir.

sp.speaker: CRAIG.
sp.p: I do, Colonel. I was indignant beyond all words when I found that Congress was being told that your men were in splendid condition and that your force equaled that of the British.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p: Could anything be falser? Splendid condition, indeed! When we came to this camp two weeks ago, you could trace our path by the blood-stained snow. Three thousand men marched with naked feet, and with scarce a coat among them.

sp.speaker: CRAIG.
sp.p: It is pitiful. No other man could have kept an army together under such circumstances. But they are saying that the war would have ended long ago had Gates been commander-in-chief.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p: It was General Washington who planned Gates's campaign in the north. He sent Gates his own best troops and officers, and urged men to enlist. And this is the way he is rewarded.

sp.speaker: CRAIG.
sp.p: And that is not all, Colonel. General Charles Lee has been complimented by Congress and is on his way to Valley Forge.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON
sp.p:
What! Charles Lee coming here--! Now does my wrath explode, indeed! Congress knew that Charles Lee
failed to appear at Trenton, though commanded by General Washington to come.

sp.speaker: CRAIG.
sp.p: It seems that he pleaded his capture by the British, prior to the fight.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p: He allowed himself to be captured! He was three miles away from his men accompanied only by an orderly. He hoped to weaken Washington's force and make victory impossible. And Gates pleaded ill-health and the General excused him. We found out afterwards that he went straight-way to Congress to complain of something or other.

sp.speaker: CRAIG.
sp.p: Gates and Lee are both Englishmen, and are impatient at being outranked by General Washington.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p: And each one is thirsting for the General's place at the head of the army. That is known to all our officers.

sp.speaker: CRAIG.
sp.p: Does General Washington suspect them?

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p: If he does he says nothing. But he is very despondent of late. He talks little and never smiles. He is weighted down with the grave responsibilities of these sad times. He is making a sacrifice of his life and it is n't appreciated.

sp.speaker: CRAIG.
sp.p: I should think the fact that he pledged his entire estate to pay the soldiers would prove his patriotism beyond all doubt.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p: Aye, it should! And at the very beginning of the war he refused to accept pay for his services.
sp.stage: (Enter General WASHINGTON, unobserved. HAMILTON continues indignantly:)
sp.p: But it seems that it is not enough that he should have the British to fight-- he must be assailed by enemies within!

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: Why, what has happened, Colonel? You seem to be indignant.

div3.stage: (HAMILTON and CRAIG bow.)

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, General, I have heard unwelcome news. General Lee is returning.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: I have just received a letter from Congress saying General Lee would arrive to-day. Please ask the officers to come for a council, Colonel. Ask them to come at once.
sp.stage: (HAMILTON bows assent. Exit. WASHINGTON offers his hand to CRAIG.)
sp.p: I am glad to see you, Mr. Dart,-- I am glad to see you safely back. You went on a dangerous journey.

sp.speaker: CRAIG.
sp.p: I was willing to take the risk, General.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: Come, be seated and tell me what you have learned.

sp.speaker: CRAIG.
sp.p: The British army in Philadelphia is stronger than ever, General. They have now nineteen thousand men.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: You are certain of that number?

sp.speaker: CRAIG.
sp.p: Absolutely.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: What about their fortifications?

sp.speaker: CRAIG.
sp.p: They are exceedingly strong. The river is protected by batteries and ships of war. The city is surrounded by at least ten redoubts, connected by strong palisades.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: Are all the approaches guarded?

sp.speaker: CRAIG.
sp.p: They are, General, and the discipline is strict.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: It would be impossible to surprise them, then?

sp.speaker: CRAIG.
sp.p: You would lead your men to destruction. I am so certain of all my statements, General, that you may discredit any one who advises you to attack.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: I thank you, Mr. Dart. You have been a faithful agent-- I have complete confidence in you. Now take some rest and refreshment. You may then begin a watch upon the farmers in this vicinity. They refuse to sell us their corn though they know my men are half starved. I suspect them of being Tories and of selling their corn to the British.

sp.speaker: CRAIG.
sp.p: I'll find out, General. I know a mill I can watch to-night. I have suspected the miller myself.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: Be cautious, Mr. Dart, and do not expose yourself needlessly.

sp.speaker: CRAIG.
sp.p: Thank you, General Washington.

div3.stage: (Bows. Exit. Pause. WASHINGTON shows he is troubled.. Enter HAMILTON.)

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p:
General Washington, I must tell you
frankly that the officers are furious that Charles Lee is coming among us again.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: I feared they would be. But we must avoid trouble in our military family, my boy, even at the expense of our private feelings and dislikes.
sp.stage: (Enter officers. They bow to the General with respect, but show indignation.)
sp.p: Gentlemen, be seated, please.
sp.stage: (Officers sit. WASHINGTON sits at table facing them.)
sp.p: My friends, it would be folly to pretend I did not see or understand the feeling your faces so plainly express. You have not forgotten Trenton. But, gentlemen, Congress has accepted General Lee's explanation of his absence, and we must accept the decision. It is to our interest to do so. General Lee is a capable officer and is valuable to our cause. I ask you, then, to be generous in your thoughts of him, and courteous in your actions. Think not one instant of any slight to me. I ask it as a favor, friends.

sp.speaker: VARNUM.
sp.p: I promise you, General Washington, to receive General Lee with civility.

sp.speaker: MCINTOSH.
sp.p: It will go 'gainst the grain, but I will treat him with courtesy.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: And I! And I!

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p:
I thank you, gentlemen. General Lee arrived a half-hour ago. I have talked with him,
and I assure you that he was profuse in his apologies for failing us at Trenton. Orderly, ask General Lee to come. You will find him in the adjutant's office.

sp.speaker: SECOND ORDERLY
sp.p: A messenger has just arrived from York with this letter from Congress, General.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON
sp.p: Excuse me, please, gentlemen.
This letter is serious, officers--
sp.stage: (Enter General LEE-- a brilliant but bold-looking man of forty-seven years.)
sp.p: General Lee, you are welcome to Valley Forge.

sp.speaker: LEE
sp.p: I thank you, General Washington.

div3.stage: (Turns and bows to officers, who rise and bow formally.)

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: You are in good time for our council. I pray you to be seated.
This letter has just come from Congress, General Lee. I was about to tell the officers its contents. Gentlemen, I am censured severely for not attacking Philadelphia and driving the enemy out.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p: It is outrageous!

div3.stage: (Indignant expressions from many.)

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON
sp.p:
Gentlemen-- please-- Congress complains of being obliged to flee from Philadelphia to hold their sittings at York. They
ask why the capital city should fall into the hands of the enemy when I have an army to defend it. Finally, they insist that I attack the British at once.

sp.speaker: SCOTT.
sp.p: I agree with Colonel Hamilton-- it is outrageous!

sp.speaker: HUNTINGTON.
sp.p: Does not Congress know the condition of our army?

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: I have reported it frequently. Indeed, only last week I wrote them of our pitiable condition here. I told them that scarce half our men were able even to build their huts for the winter, and that that half had to borrow clothing from the others to cover their naked bodies.

sp.speaker: LAFAYETTE.
sp.p: Do they know that there is now little less than a famine here? Do they know that our men are living on food commonly given to horses?

sp.speaker: POOR.
sp.p: And that they are growing weak from this steadily? And the officers fare little better.

sp.speaker: VARNUM.
sp.p: Do they know that half our men are obliged to sit up all night by the fire because they have no blankets to cover them?

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: I have kept nothing from them.

sp.speaker: WAYNE.
sp.p: I tell you, General Washington, that the great men who sat in the First and Second Congress are no longer there. They are either serving in the army or they have accepted civil offices in their own States. These Congressmen at York are inferior in ability.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON
sp.p: We must be careful not to abuse our government. I think I know where the trouble lies-- these Congressmen are not military men and so do not realize our necessity. When they once understand, they will change their attitude.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p: How is Congress to understand when it is constantly being told a far different story, General?

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: Different? What do yon mean, Colonel?

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p: They are told that we have a force equal to that of the British and in splendid condition to fight.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: My enemies take an ungenerous advantage of me. They know that I cannot publish to the world the actual number of our soldiers. That is a secret we must conceal, or the British will soon have us at their feet.

sp.speaker: LAFAYETTE.
sp.p: But it is unfair that you should be thus deprived of a word in your own defense.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: Nevertheless, General Lafayette, I must continue to be silent, but I shall request an investigation by Congress. I shall ask them to send a committee here at once.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p: One look at our camp will end all talk of attacking.

sp.speaker: ALL OFFICERS
sp.p: Yes-- yes-- it will-- it will!

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON
sp.p: You do not speak, General Lee. What is your opinion?

sp.speaker: LEE.
sp.p: I do not agree with your other generals, your Excellency. I favor an attack.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: But, General Lee, we have only eleven thousand men, with at least three thousand unfit for duty. The British have nineteen thousand and all in fine condition.

sp.speaker: LEE.
sp.p: I mean a night attack-- a surprise that would rout them completely.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: My spies report the British fortifications so strong and so well guarded that I would not risk the lives of our men against such odds.

sp.speaker: LEE.
sp.p: You will be censured if you do not.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: And condemned if it prove a failure.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p: Perhaps that is what your enemies wish, General. They will urge you on to an attack they know will be disastrous.

sp.speaker: LEE
sp.p: Do you mean to insinuate that I am doing that, sir?

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON
sp.p: Gentlemen-- I will not countenance quarrels.
sp.stage: (HAMILTON rises; bows to WASHINGTON and LEE; sits. LEE bows to WASHINGTON and HAMILTON; sits. WASHINGTON continues:)
sp.p:
It matters not what the public says-- we must be governed by conditions. If we can only keep an army together this winter, we shall do well. And
we will not be idle. We will attack the small troops of British that leave Philadelphia for forage. We must prevent Tory farmers from taking food in to them. In fact, we can harass them in many ways. And then, when spring comes, the British General will still find an American army upon his heels-- still ready to pursue and annoy him. He will find he has gained nothing by seizing Philadelphia; whereas we shall have gained everything. We will have had time to strengthen our army and obtain supplies-- a thing far more necessary to us just now than a victory.

sp.speaker: LEE.
sp.p: But, General, how can we hope to obtain supplies for the winter? Congress cannot borrow money enough now to care for the few men you have.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: We must get loans from individuals. It is my plan to write prominent and wealthy men in every State for money. Indeed, I have already sent many letters, and others must go out to-day. So I pray you to excuse me, gentlemen. Colonel Hamilton, please remain to assist me with these letters.
sp.stage: (Officers bow and go out. HAMILTON crosses to table; prepares to write. WASHINGTON stands lost in deep thought. At last he turns to HAMILTON-- speaks sadly--)
sp.p: Well, my boy, I am being assailed by my own countrymen. I have been wounded in the house of my friends.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON.
sp.p: It is all because of certain men who are jealous of you, General. They are trying to force you to resign.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: It may be--

sp.speaker: ORDERLY
sp.p: General Lee desires to see you at once, your Excellency. He asks for a private interview.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: Admit General Lee, Orderly.

div3.stage: (Exit Orderly. Pause. Enter LEE. He stops upon seeing HAMILTON.)

sp.speaker: LEE.
sp.p: I should like a private interview, General.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: Colonel Hamilton is in my confidence in all military matters.

sp.speaker: LEE.
sp.p: But this is of personal interest to you.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: I prefer him to be present.

sp.speaker: LEE
sp.p: As you please, General. My errand here is due entirely to my consideration for you.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON
sp.p: Be seated, General.

sp.speaker: LEE
sp.p: I have lately had private information as to a certain action Congress contemplates in regard to your Excellency--

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON
sp.p: Are you at liberty to give me this information?

sp.speaker: LEE.
sp.p: I am, General, though I regret to be the bearer of such news--

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON
sp.p: Proceed, General Lee. I wish Colonel Hamilton to hear.

sp.speaker: LEE.
sp.p: To be brief, then,-- Congress means to withdraw your command of the army unless you attack Philadelphia soon.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON
sp.p: I thank you, General, for telling me. Whenever Congress wishes to relieve me, I shall go, and gladly. Domestic life would be sweet, indeed, after the discomforts we are enduring here. And the business of my plantation is far more attractive than the horrors of war. So I repeat-- I shall go and gladly.

sp.speaker: LEE.
sp.p: But, sir, it would be a disgrace unspeakable!

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: Do you think, then, that I should resign to spare myself this disgrace?

sp.speaker: LEE.
sp.p: By no means! I advise you to attack the enemy. If defeat comes, you cannot be blamed, for you have been urged thereto by Congress.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: It is your opinion, then, that I should allow half of my men to be slain to save myself from dismissal?

sp.speaker: LEE.
sp.p: It is not so certain they will be slain.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: It is as certain as night and day. All of my officers agree with me but you.

sp.speaker: LEE.
sp.p: I would save you from disgrace.

sp.speaker: HAMILTON
sp.p: Do you think we are children, sir, that we cannot see through your designs? You are trying to force General Washington into disgrace! You want his position for yourself, sir!

sp.speaker: LEE
sp.p: How dare you! Retract your words, this instant!

div3.stage: (Both draw their swords. WASHINGTON steps between them.)

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON
sp.p: Come-- let us have done with quarrels! Sheathe your swords, I pray you!

sp.speaker: ORDERLY
sp.p: A lady is waiting to see you, General-- a Mrs. Hugh Ferguson, of Philadelphia.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: What is her errand here?

sp.speaker: ORDERLY.
sp.p: She would not say.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: Then I refuse to see her.

div3.stage: (Enter Mrs. FERGUSON just as Orderly is turning to go. She is a woman of refinement; is handsomely dressed, wearing costly furs.)

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSON.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, General Washington, for entering in this way, but I must see you. It is most important--
sp.stage: (LEE and HAMILTON sheathe swords. WASHINGTON bows formally to Mrs. FERGUSON; waits for her to proceed.)
sp.p: I am Mrs. Ferguson, General. You have no doubt heard of my family. My father is Dr. Thomas Graeme, of Philadelphia.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON
sp.p: And your husband is Hugh Ferguson, an officer in the British service. And you are much in the company of Tories.

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSON
sp.p: But I myself am a Patriot. I am devoted to my country. Indeed, it is my devotion that has brought me here. I come with a letter for your Excellency from Mr. Duch.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: The Mr. Duch who was chaplain of our First Congress?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSON.
sp.p: Yes, General,-- the Reverend Jacob Duch, of Philadelphia.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: He has become a Tory. He can have nothing to say to me.

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSON
sp.p: Only read his letter! I promised him I would deliver it into your hands. I pray you to take the letter! The contents are of the greatest importance.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON
sp.p: Be seated, Madam.
sp.stage: (Mrs. FERGUSON sits. WASHINGTON reads letter; shows increasing indignation.)
sp.p: Had I but known what this letter contained, I would not have read it, Madam.

This Jacob Duch informs me that we can never be victorious. So he bids me abandon the dearest hope of this country and reject the Declaration of Independence. He tells me it is our duty to submit to England's King and all his royal orders. And finally he calls upon me to surrender at once to the British.
sp.stage: (Throws letter on table, his eyes blazing with wrath.)
sp.p: Colonel Hamilton, send that letter to Congress at once! Say I advise the arrest of Mr. Duch; say also that Mrs. Hugh Ferguson should be watched, as she is no doubt a spy in the British service.

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSON.
sp.p: No! No! I am a Patriot! I protest I am a Patriot! I did not know what that letter contained. I thought it a plan for making peace.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.
sp.p: Return to Philadelphia, Madam, and tell Mr. Duch that I shall not surrender. Tell him there will be some kind of American army so long as there is a British soldier upon this soil. Tell him if we are beaten here, we will retire to the Alleghanies, and thence to the Mississippi. But surrender-- never! And tell him also I will not resign. My enemies may insult me and heap slight upon slight. No personal thrust shall harm me. My heart tells me that it has been my constant aim to do the best that circumstances would permit. I am in this war because I believe it is right and just, and with God's help I mean to conquer. Tell Mr. Duch that, Madam, and come no more to my camp.

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSON.
sp.p: I did not know-- I am a Patriot-- I protest I am a Patriot--
sp.stage: (WASHINGTON points to door. Exit Mrs. FERGUSON frightened. WASHINGTON turns to LEE.)
sp.p:
You have heard my message to Mr. Duch. In that, you have had your answer. I shall not resign.
Neither shall I attack the British now. Allow me to bid you good-day, sir.

div3.stage: (Bows to LEE, who is thus compelled to retire, vexed and baffled.)

div4.head: CENE I
div4.stage: (State House is surrounded by an immense crowd of people. Enter others constantly.)

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: Do you think we can see him from here, mother?

sp.speaker: MOTHER.
sp.p: Yes-- he will pass this way. He must, to enter the State House.

sp.speaker: GIRL.
sp.p: There are thousands waiting to see him.

sp.speaker: MOTHER.
sp.p: Every one wants to see General Washington, now that he has been victorious.

sp.speaker: FIRST MAN
sp.p: It was a glorious victory at Yorktown, friends! The flower of the British army surrendered to General Washington.

sp.speaker: SECOND MAN.
sp.p: And England has been forced to make peace with us at last, and acknowledge our independence.

sp.speaker: THIRD MAN.
sp.p: No wonder General Washington is a hero. The people seem to worship him.

sp.speaker: FOURTH MAN.
sp.p: They should. No man has made more sacrifices for our cause. For eight years he has carried the burden of the war upon his shoulders. And much of that time envious men were secretly trying to blacken his name and take his command from him.

sp.speaker: SECOND MAN.
sp.p: And where are those men to-day! Congress finally saw Charles Lee in his true light and dismissed him from the service. Gates faded into insignificance, as did all the others.

sp.speaker: FIRST MAN.
sp.p: Their very names will soon be forgotten, but Washington's will last forever.

stage.hi: (They pass on. Enter three young ladies.)

sp.speaker: FIRST YOUNG LADY.
sp.p: Oh, I am so anxious to see him! He is a wonderful hero!

sp.speaker: SECOND YOUNG LADY.
sp.p:
Everybody loves him! They say his officers all wept when the war was over
and he told them good-bye. And the General himself was so moved he could not speak, but embraced the officers and wept with them.

sp.speaker: THIRD YOUNG LADY.
sp.p: And great crowds followed him wherever he went! And there were many banquets in his honor.

sp.speaker: FIRST YOUNG LADY.
sp.p: I believe we can see him better over there.

sp.speaker: FIRST YOUTH
sp.p: It is about time for the General, boys. He was to appear before Congress at noon.

sp.speaker: SECOND YOUTH.
sp.p: I wonder if they will offer to make him king of America.

sp.speaker: THIRD YOUTH.
sp.p: Certainly they will not! Did n't he refuse to accept the crown when it was offered him by Colonel Nicola last year? And the Colonel was supported by a large number of prominent men.

sp.speaker: SECOND YOUTH.
sp.p: Yes, but they were not the Congress. The General might listen now.

sp.speaker: THIRD YOUTH.
sp.p: Congress would n't dare-- they know what the General wrote to Colonel Nicola. He said that the mere suggestion of being made king was hateful to him.

sp.speaker: FIFTH YOUTH.
sp.p: And I believe it was, too! He's not that kind of a man.

div4.stage: (They pass on. Several fashionably dressed women approach.)

sp.speaker: FIRST WOMAN.
sp.p: Is it true that Mrs. Washington is with him?

sp.speaker: SECOND WOMAN.
sp.p: Oh, yes! She will have a place in the gallery while the General is resigning his commission.

sp.speaker: THIRD WOMAN.
sp.p: They will go to Mount Vernon just as soon as the ceremony is over. The Governor of Maryland and his suite will accompany them part of the way, and show them every honor.

sp.speaker: FIRST WOMAN
sp.p: He is coming! There is General Washington!

sp.speaker: SECOND WOMAN
sp.p: He is walking with the Governor!

sp.speaker: THIRD WOMAN.
sp.p: Do you see Mrs. Washington? She is with the Governor's wife.

div4.stage: (Cheers continue. Enter General WASHINGTON with the Governor of Maryland. They are followed by Mrs. WASHINGTON and the Governor's wife. Then comes the Governor's suite. WASHINGTON smiles and lifts his hat to people generally. He enters State House, followed by his party. Cheers continue.)

div4.head: SCENE I

p.hi: PLACE: Senate Chamber in State House.

div4.stage: (The floor of the chamber is filled with Congressmen who are seated, and with spectators who are standing at back Gallery is filled with ladies. Enter General WASHINGTON, accompanied by the Governor. President MIFFLIN and Congressmen rise. The Secretary crosses to meet WASHINGTON and escorts him to platform. Mrs. WASHINGTON appears in gallery and is given a place in front row in center. The Governor's wife accompanies her.)

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN.
sp.p: General Washington, the United States, in Congress assembled, are prepared to receive your communications.

sp.speaker: WASHINGTON.1
sp.p:
Mr. President,-- The great events on which my resignation depended, having at length taken place, I now have the honor of offering my sincere congratulation to Congress, and of presenting myself before them, to surrender into their hands the trust committed to me, and to claim the indulgence of retiring from the service of my country. 1 Washington's actual speech, shortened.
Happy in our new state of independence, and pleased with the opportunity afforded the United States of becoming a respected nation, I resign with satisfaction. Having now finished the work assigned me, I retire from the great theater of action. And, bidding an affectionate farewell to this august body, I here offer my commission, and take my leave of all the employments of public life.

div4.stage: (Hands his commission to President, who receives it.)

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN.1
sp.p: Sir,-- The United States, in Congress assembled, receive with profound emotion the solemn resignation of the commission under which you have led their troops through a perilous and doubtful war. Called upon by your country to defend its invaded rights, you accepted the sacred charge while it was without funds or a government to support you. You have conducted the great war with wisdom. You have persevered, until these United States, aided by the generous King of France, have been enabled to close the war in freedom, safety and independence. And now you retire from military command. But the glory of your virtues will not terminate; it will continue to remotest ages. We pray to Almighty God to foster your life with all his care; to keep your days as happy as they have been illustrious; and to finally give you the reward that this world cannot give.

div4.p: In the parlor at Mount Vernon stands General George Washington receiving, from three members of Congress, the official notice of his election as President of the United States. Standing near by is Mrs. George Washington, happy and proud.

General Washington is seen riding a spirited horse, accompanied by a large number of United States cavalry. They are approaching a triumphal arch in the city of Philadelphia. On the arch is the inscription--

General Washington is seen walking in the main street of Trenton, New Jersey. He is accompanied by many dignitaries. Preceding him are a number of young girls, dressed in white and strewing flowers along his path. Two carry a white silk banner upon which in letters of gold are the words--

General Washington is seen arriving in New York City. He stands on a barge which is manned by thirteen oarsmen dressed in white. On the dock, waiting to receive him, stands the Mayor of New York, accompanied by all officers of state. The shore is crowded with a great mass of cheering and waving people.

The Senate Chamber is seen filled with United States Senators and Congressmen. The gallery is packed with spectators. On the platform stands General Washington. He faces Chancellor Livingston who is giving the oath of office. The Chancellor holds the Bible before Washington, who bows and reverently kisses the book. Immediately the people shout and cheer, bells ring, and the boom of cannon is heard.
